title:
Gaussian entropic optimal transport: Schrödinger bridges and the
  Sinkhorn algorithm

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Entropic optimal transport problems are regularized versions of optimal transport problems. These models play an increasingly important role in machine learning and generative modelling. For finite spaces, these problems are commonly solved using Sinkhorn algorithm (a.k.a. iterative proportional fitting procedure). However, in more general settings the Sinkhorn iterations are based on nonlinear conditional/conjugate transformations and exact finite-dimensional solutions cannot be computed.

This article presents a finite-dimensional recursive formulation of the iterative proportional fitting procedure for general Gaussian multivariate models. As expected, this recursive formulation is closely related to the celebrated Kalman filter and related Riccati matrix difference equations, and it yields algorithms that can be implemented in practical settings without further approximations. We extend this filtering methodology to develop a refined and self-contained convergence analysis of Gaussian Sinkhorn algorithms, including closed form expressions of entropic transport maps and Schrödinger bridges.


Keywords: Entropic optimal transport, Sinkhorn's algorithm, iterative proportional fitting procedure, Gaussian processes, Schrödinger bridges, Monge maps, Riccati matrix difference equations.

Mathematics Subject Classification: Primary 49N05, 49Q22, 94A17, 62J99, 60J20; secondary $62 \mathrm{C} 10,35 \mathrm{Q} 49$.

# 1 Introduction
### 1.1 Transport problems

The optimal transport problem consists in finding the most efficient way of transforming one given probability measure into another one selected as a target. To be specific, let $\mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)$ be the set of probability measures $\mathcal{P}(d(x, y))$ on the product space $\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ for some $d \geqslant 1$, with prescribed first and second coordinate marginals $(\eta, \mu)$ and densities $\left(e^{-U}, e^{-V}\right)$ on $\mathbb{R}^{d}$. Additionally, let $Q(x, d y)=q(x, y) d y$ be a Markov transition kernel on $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ with density $q(x, y)$ with respect to (w.r.t.) the Lebesgue measure $d y$ on $\mathbb{R}^{d}$. The (regularized) entropic transport problem associated with these mathematical objects is formulated as $[27,55]$

$$
\underset{\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)}{\arg \min }\left(-\int \log q(x, y) \mathcal{P}(d(x, y))+\operatorname{Ent}(\mathcal{P} \mid \eta \otimes \mu)\right)
$$

where $\operatorname{Ent}(\mathcal{P} \mid \eta \otimes \mu)$ is the relative entropy of $\mathcal{P}$ w.r.t. the product measure $\eta \otimes \mu$ (we refer to Section 2.1 for the description of the relative entropy). In the optimal transport literature, the function $c(x, y)=-\log q(x, y)$ is sometimes called the cost function. As shown in Section 2.4 dedicated to conditioning principles, the function $c(x, y)$ can also be interpreted as a log-likelihood function. The quadratic cost defined by

$$
c(x, y)=c_{t}(x, y):=\frac{1}{2 t}\|x-y\|^{2}+\frac{d}{2} \log (2 \pi t)
$$

for some given $t>0$ corresponds to Gaussian densities and the heat equation semigroup (see for instance Remark 2.3). The optimal transport problem corresponds to the case $t=0$. Indeed, up to a rescaling, when $t=0$ solving (1.1) is equivalent to solving the optimal transport problem

$$
\underset{\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)}{\arg \min } \int\|x-y\|^{2} \mathcal{P}(d(x, y))
$$

In this context, the parameter $t>0$ is seen as a regularization parameter. For a more thorough discussion on these entropically regularized optimal transport problems, we refer to the pioneering article by Cuturi [27] (see also [42, 43]).

Choose $\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)$ of the form

$$
\mathcal{P}(d(x, y))=\eta(d x) \mathcal{K}(x, d y)
$$

and set

$$
\mathcal{P}_{0}(d(x, y)):=\eta(d x) \mathcal{Q}(x, d y)
$$

where $\mathcal{K}(x, d y)$ and $\mathcal{Q}(x, d y)$ are Markov kernels. In this context, using the decomposition

$$
\frac{d \mathcal{P}}{d \mathcal{P}_{0}}=\frac{d \mathcal{P}}{d(\eta \otimes \mu)} \frac{d(\eta \otimes \mu)}{d \mathcal{P}_{0}}
$$

we readily obtain the entropic cost formula

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{0}\right)+\int \mu(d y) V(y)=-\int \log q(x, y) \mathcal{P}(d(x, y))+\operatorname{Ent}(\mathcal{P} \mid \eta \otimes \mu)
$$

In other words, the solution of the entropic transport problem (1.1) coincides with the solution of the (static) Schrödinger bridge from $\eta$ to $\mu$ w.r.t. the reference measure $\mathcal{P}_{0}$, which is defined by

$$
\underset{\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)}{\arg \min } \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{0}\right)
$$

It is implicitly assumed there exists some $\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)$ such that $\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{0}\right)<\infty$. This condition ensures the existence of a Schrödinger bridge distribution $\mathcal{P}$ that solves (1.3) (cf. the seminal article by Csiszár [26], as well as Section 6 in the Lecture Notes by Nutz [55], see also the survey article by Léonard [51] and references therein).

Schrödinger bridges can rarely be solved analytically. However, solutions can be approximated efficiently using the Sinkhorn algorithm, also referred to as the iterative proportional fitting procedure $[27,60,61]$. Let $\mathcal{C}_{X}(\eta)$ be the set of probability measures $\mathcal{P}(d(x, y))$ with marginal $\mathcal{P}^{X}(d x)=\eta(d x)$ w.r.t. the $x$-coordinate and let $\mathcal{C}_{Y}(\eta)$ be the set of probability measures $\mathcal{P}(d(x, y))$ with marginal $\mathcal{P}^{Y}(d x)=\mu(d y)$ w.r.t. the $y$-coordinate. In this notation, the Sinkhorn algorithm starts from $\mathcal{P}_{0}$ and solves sequentially the following entropic transport problems

$$
\mathcal{P}_{2 n+1}:=\underset{\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{C}_{Y}(\mu)}{\arg \min } \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 n}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{P}_{2(n+1)}:=\underset{\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{C}_{X}(\eta)}{\arg \min } \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 n+1}\right)
$$

When $n \rightarrow \infty$, Sinkhorn bridges $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ converge towards the Schrödinger bridge from $\eta$ to $\mu$.
In the dual formulation, these distributions are often written as

$$
\mathcal{P}_{n}(d(x, y))=e^{-U_{n}(x)} q(x, y) e^{-V_{n}(y)} d x d y
$$

for a pair of Schrödinger potentials $\left(U_{n}, V_{n}\right)$ satisfying a system of integral relations starting from $\left(U_{0}, V_{0}\right)=(U, 0)$ (see Proposition 6.1). The limiting Schrödinger potentials $(\mathbb{U}(x), \mathbb{V}(x)):=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(U_{n}(x), V_{n}(x)\right)$ yield the bridge distribution $\mathcal{P}$ that solves problem (1.3), i.e.,

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \mathcal{P}_{n}(d(x, y))=\mathcal{P}(d(x, y))=e^{-\mathbb{U}(x)} q(x, y) e^{-\mathbb{V}(y)} d x d y
$$

While Sinkhorn iterations as presented in the recursions (1.4) may look appealing and easy to implement, one should note that they are based on nonlinear conditional/conjugate transformations with generally no finite-dimensional recursive solutions and, therefore, they do not lead to a practical algorithm. In this paper, we present a self-contained analysis of Schrödinger bridges and a tractable Sinkhorn algorithm for a general class of Gaussian models. We provide closed form expression of Schrödinger bridges $(\mathbb{U}, \mathbb{V})$ as well as the description of the bridge distribution $\mathcal{P}$ that solves problem (1.3) in terms of transport maps. We also provide a refined convergence analysis with sharp exponential convergence rates for entropic transport distributions $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ and the dual Schrödinger potentials $\left(U_{n}, V_{n}\right)$ in expression (1.5).

# 1.2 Gaussian models 

Let $\mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$ be set of positive semi-definite matrices in $\mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$, and let $\mathcal{S}_{d}^{+} \subset \mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$ be the subset of positive definite matrices. Denote by $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ the Gaussian distribution on $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ with mean

$m \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and covariance matrix $\sigma \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$. In addition, let $g_{\sigma}$ denote the probability density function (pdf) of the distribution $\nu_{0, \sigma}$, with covariance matrix $\sigma \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$. Hereafter, we study general Gaussian models of the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\eta, \mu) & =\left(\nu_{m, \sigma}, \nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}\right) \\
q_{\theta}(x, y) & =g_{\tau}(y-(\alpha+\beta x)) \quad \text { with } \quad \theta=(\alpha, \beta, \tau) \in \Theta:=\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathcal{G} l_{d} \times \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for some given $(m, \bar{m}) \in\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ and $(\sigma, \bar{\sigma}) \in\left(\mathcal{S}_{d}^{+} \times \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}\right)$, where $\mathcal{G} l_{d}$ denotes the general linear group of $(d \times d)$-invertible matrices (hence $\mathcal{S}_{d}^{+} \subset \mathcal{G} l_{d}$ ).

The practical application of the Sinkhorn algorithm requires a finite-dimensional description of the flow of distributions $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ generated by the iteration of (1.4). As expected, for the Gaussian models in (1.7), the entropic transport problem (1.4) is indeed solved by a finite-dimensional family of Gaussian conditional/conjugate distributions. For instance, if $\mathcal{P}_{2 n}:=\operatorname{Law}\left(X_{n}, Y_{n}\right)$ then we have $\mathcal{P}_{2 n+1}(d(x, y))=\mu(d y) \mathbb{P}\left(X_{n} \in d x \mid Y_{n}=y\right)$ and the conditional distribution is Gaussian and can be calculated using least squares and linear regression methods (see for instance the conditioning principles described in Section 2.4 and in Appendix C on page 51). The conditional mean and covariance updates associated with these models coincide with the traditional Kalman update that arises in discrete generation and linear-Gaussian filtering models, see for example Section 9.9.6 in [33].

Hence, one of the main goals of this paper is to apply this filtering methodology to solve Schrödinger bridges and analyze the convergence of the Sinkhorn algorithm for Gaussian models. In the theory of Kalman filtering, the flow of covariance matrices associated with the Sinkhorn algorithm also satisfies offline matrix difference Riccati equations. The stability analysis and the stationary matrices associated with Riccati matrix flows are well understood, see for instance [35] and references therein. In Appendix B we provide a brief discussion on Riccati matrix flows in the context of the Sinhorn algorithm, including the Floquet-type theory developed in [35], as well as several Lipschitz type inequalities and exponential type decays to equilibrium for Riccati flows and their associated exponential semigroups.

# 1.3 Motivation and related work 

Optimal transport and its regularized entropic version have become state-of-the-art tools in a variety of application domains, including generative modeling and machine learning [6, 29, 49, 57], statistical barycenter problems [1, 4, 10, 24, 28, 30], economy [12], computer vision $[38,62]$, control theory $[17,18]$, and many others.

Finding and rigorously understanding closed-form solutions for multivariate Gaussian entropic optimal transport is of fundamental importance. Exact recursions for entropic optimal transport in the Gaussian case can serve as a baseline for testing approximate Sinkhorn algorithms on multivariate models, much like the Kalman filter's role in testing approximate filtering algorithms. They can also form the basis for developing novel entropic optimal transport methods for non-Gaussian distributions using well-established nonlinear Kalman filtering ideas. Furthermore, the problem of finding Gaussian distributions on product spaces with prescribed multivariate marginals and conditional constraints is a surprisingly difficult problem arising in graphical models [4, 23, 50]. Gaussian Schrödinger bridges related entropic transport problems also arise in solving matching problems as well

as in optimal control theory $[12,17,18]$. These articles provide and utilize closed form expressions for some specific classes of Gaussian Schrödinger bridges.

Given its central importance, the convergence of the Sinkhorn algorithm for Gaussian models has been discussed in prior works. The earliest works to discuss the convergence of Sinkhorn algorithm are [24, 25]. However, these works do not present any closed form solutions or any explicit results on the convergence rates. The more recent article [29] also discusses quantitative exponential decays for Gaussian centered models (where $m=\bar{m}=0$ and $\alpha=0$ ) and scalar-type matrices $(\beta=b I, \tau=I$ and $\sigma=t I=\bar{\sigma})$ for some real numbers $t \in] 0, \infty[$ and $b \in \mathbb{R}$. The type of models, with $m=\bar{m}=0,(\alpha, \beta)=(0, I)$ and scalar-type covariance $\tau=t I$, is also studied in [47]. In this context, the authors present a closed form expression of limiting Schrödinger potential functions in terms of the fixed point of a Riccati-type equation.

When $\beta=I$ and for scalar-type covariance $\tau=t I$, similar fixed-point equations are also investigated in the series of recent articles $[1,12,14,30,47,53]$. These articles discuss Gaussian bridges and entropic interpolations of the form in Eq. (1.2). They also discuss the effect of the regularization parameter but they do not seek any closed-form expressions of the iterations in the Sinkhorn algorithm or their convergence rates. The regularity properties of the optimal transport map between Gaussian distributions can also be deduced from Caffarelli's contraction theorem [15] on the Lipschitz's regularity properties of the optimal transport map between Gaussian and strongly log-concave distributions.

Most of the literature on Sinkhorn iterates is concerned with finite state spaces [13, 60, $61,63]$ as well as compact state spaces or bounded cost functions using Hilbert projective metrics techniques [19, 31, 41, 54]. It is out of the scope of this article to review all the contributions in this field -we simply refer to the recent book [57] and the references therein.

There are very few articles on the convergence of Sinkhorn iterates on non-compact spaces and unbounded cost functions that apply to Gaussian models with the notable exception of two recent significant contributions [21, 22]. More precisely, the exponential convergence of the Sinkhorn iterations in (1.4) for cost functions of the form in Eq. (1.2) can be deduced from the recent article [22], which investigate quantitative contraction rates for target marginal distributions $(\eta, \mu)$ with an asymptotically positive log-concavity profile and cost functions of the form in (1.2) associated with a sufficiently large regularization parameter. These exponential decays have been recently refined to apply to all values of the regularization parameter in the more recent article [21]. The entropy estimates presented in Proposition 1.3 of [21] also apply directly to Gaussian models of the form (1.7) when the cost function is symmetric and the parameters are $(\alpha, \beta)=(0, I)$ and $\tau=t \Sigma$, for some symmetric positive-definite matrix $\Sigma$. These exponential decays presented in [22, 21] are closely related but differ from to the ones based on Floquet-type representation of Riccati flows discussed in the present article (see for instance Theorem 5.1 the estimate (5.6) and Remark 5.10).

Extensions of our results to log-concave models have been developed in [34]. The recent article [2] also develops a semigroup contraction analysis based on Lyapunov techniques to prove the exponential convergence of Sinkhorn algorithm on weighted Banach spaces. These Lyapunov approaches also apply to multivariate linear Gaussian models for sufficiently large regularization parameter as well as statistical finite mixture models including Gaussiankernel density estimation of complex data distributions arising in generative models.

In the same context, the convergence of Sinkhorn iterations can also be deduced from

Theorem 6.15 in [55] under an exponential integrability condition [55, condition (6.8)] which is again only met for a sufficiently large regularization parameter. To the best of our knowledge, the weakest regularity conditions that ensure the convergence of Sinkhorn iterations are presented in the recent articles $[45,56]$. These are mild integrability conditions of the cost function w.r.t. the target marginal measures $(\eta, \mu)$, which apply to general Gaussian models and any choice of the regularization parameter (see Remark 6.10). Nevertheless, the article [56] does not provide convergence results in relative entropy but in total variation, without any explicit rates, and the article [45] presents sub-linear relative entropy rates.

# 1.4 Main contributions 

The aim of this paper is to provide a self-contained and refined analysis of the Sinkhorn algorithm and Schrödinger's bridges for general Gaussian multivariate models. We obtain closed-form expressions for Schrödinger potentials and the Sinkhorn iterations, as well as sharp (non asymptotic) convergence rates for the Sinkhorn algorithm, for this class of models. To be specific:

- We construct explicit closed-form expressions for the distribution flow $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ of the Sinkhorn iterations in (1.4), as well as the corresponding Schrödinger potentials $U_{n}$ and $V_{n}$ in (1.5), for general Gaussian models of the form given in (1.7). A sequential formulation of the bridge measures $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ generated by the Gaussian Sinkhorn algorithm is provided in Section 4.1. Then, we provide a complete description of the mathematical objects $\left(\mathcal{P}_{n}, U_{n}, V_{n}\right)$ in terms of Riccati matrix difference equations in Section 4.2 (see Theorem 4.3). Closed-form expressions of the Schrödinger potentials $\left(U_{n}, V_{n}\right)$ are constructed in Section 6 (see Theorem 6.13).
- We analyze the convergence of the Gaussian Sinkhorn algorithm towards the corresponding Schrödinger bridges.
- Gaussian bridge transport maps and Schrödinger potential functions are explicitly described in terms of a reference parameter in Section 3 -see Theorem 3.1 and Corollary 3.6.
- We provide explicit contraction estimates in terms of the fixed-points of Riccati matrix difference equations in Section 5. As shown in [35] these exponential contraction rates based on Floquet-type representation of Riccati flows are sharp -see Theorem 1.3 in [35] and Proposition B. 6 herein. ${ }^{1}$ Quantitative exponential stability estimates for the Gaussian Sinkhorn algorithm are obtained in Theorem 5.1 and Corollary 5.6). Relative entropy, total variation and Wasserstein distance non-asymptotic estimates are given by Corollary 5.7 and Corollary 5.8.
- In Section 4.3 we analyze the stability properties of a class of Gibbs loop-type time-varying Markov chains associated with the Sinkhorn iterations for general (non-necessarily Gaussian) models. We present a rather elementary way to derive sub-linear rates. Sharp exponential convergence rates for Gaussian models are then presented in Corollary 5.4.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ Closed form solutions of Riccati flows for one-dimensional models are also developed in Section 4.2 in [36] (see also Remark 4.4 in the present article).

- For the class of Gaussian models (1.7) where the covariance parameter has the form $\tau=t I$ we carry out a refined analysis of the effects of the entropic regularization parameter $t>0$.
- Convergence rates for the bridge transport maps and Schrödinger potentials towards independent Gaussians as $t \rightarrow \infty$ are presented, respectively, in Corollary 3.10 and Proposition 3.11. The effect of this regularization on the Sinkhorn algorithm and its exponential convergence rates is also discussed in Section 5.3.
- Convergence rates for the Gaussian bridge transport maps and Schrödinger bridge measures towards Monge maps as $t \rightarrow 0$ are presented in Corollary 3.12. Quantitative bounds on the rate of convergence of regularized optimal transport costs to standard Wasserstein optimal transport are presented in Theorem 3.13.

# 1.5 Outline of the paper 

We provide background material in Section 2. Gaussian Schrödinger bridges and entropic transport maps, including regularized models, are analyzed in Section 3. Section 4 is devoted to the Sinkhorn scheme, including the closed-form, finite-dimensional Gaussian Sinkhorn algorithm and the Gibbs loop-type heterogeneous Markov chains associated to general Sinkhorn iterations. In Section 5 we provide quantitative estimates for the iterates of the Gaussian Sinkhorn algorithm and Section 6 is devoted to the analysis of the convergence of the Schrödinger potentials along the Gaussian Sinkhorn iterations. Most of the proofs, as well as extended analyses and numerics, are provided in Appendices A through F.

## 2 Background
### 2.1 Integral operators

Let $\mathbb{X}$ be a Banach space equipped with some norm $\|x\|_{\mathbb{X}}$. Also, let $\mathcal{M}(\mathbb{X})$ be the set of nonnegative bounded measures on $\mathbb{X}$ and let $\mathcal{M}_{1}(\mathbb{X}) \subset \mathcal{M}(\mathbb{X})$ denote the convex subset of probability measures. Let $\mathcal{B}(\mathbb{X})$ be the set of bounded and measurable functions $f$ on $\mathbb{X}$ equipped with the uniform norm $\|f\|:=\sup _{x \in \mathbb{X}}|f(x)|$.

Divergences between probability measures We denote by

$$
\eta(f):=\int_{\mathbb{X}} f(x) \eta(d x)
$$

the Lebesgue integral of a integrable function $f \in \mathcal{B}(\mathbb{X})$ w.r.t. some $\eta \in \mathcal{M}(\mathbb{X})$. We make use of several notions of divergence between pairs of probability measures:

- The total variation distance on $\mathcal{M}_{1}(\mathbb{X})$ is defined for any $\eta_{1}, \eta_{2} \in \mathcal{M}_{1}(\mathbb{X})$ by

$$
\left\|\eta_{1}-\eta_{2}\right\|_{\mathrm{tv}}:=\sup \left\{\left(\eta_{1}-\eta_{2}\right)(f): f \in \mathcal{B}(\mathbb{X}) \text { s.t. } \operatorname{osc}(f) \leqslant 1\right\}
$$

In (2.1), $\operatorname{osc}(f)$ stands for the oscillations of the function $f$, defined as

$$
\operatorname{osc}(f):=\sup _{\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \in \mathbb{X}^{2}}\left|f\left(x_{1}\right)-f\left(x_{2}\right)\right|
$$

- The relative entropy (a.k.a. Kullback-Leibler divergence) between to measures $\eta_{1} \ll \eta_{2}$ is defined by

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta_{1} \mid \eta_{2}\right)=\int \log \left(\frac{d \eta_{1}}{d \eta_{2}}(x)\right) \eta_{1}(d x)
$$

Notation $\eta_{1} \ll \eta_{2}$ indicates that $\eta_{1} \in \mathcal{M}(\mathbb{X})$ is absolutely continuous w.r.t. $\eta_{2} \in \mathcal{M}(\mathbb{X})$, i.e., $\eta_{2}(A)=0$ implies that $\eta_{1}(A)$ for any measurable subset $A \subset \mathbb{X}$. We also write $\eta_{1} \simeq \eta_{2}$ when the measures are equivalent in the sense that $\eta_{1} \ll \eta_{2} \ll \eta_{1}$. When $\eta_{1} \notin \eta_{2}$, we set $\operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta_{1} \mid \eta_{2}\right)=\infty$.

- The $p$-th Wasserstein distance between $\eta_{1}$ and $\eta_{2}$ is given by

$$
\mathbb{W}_{p}\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right):=\inf _{\pi \in \mathcal{C}\left(\nu_{1}, \nu_{2}\right)}\left(\int\left\|x_{1}-x_{2}\right\|_{\mathbb{X}}^{p} \pi\left(d\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)\right)\right)^{1 / p} \quad \text { for } p \geqslant 1
$$

where $\mathcal{C}\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}\right)$ stands for the convex subset of probability measures $\pi \in \mathcal{M}_{1}\left(\mathbb{X}^{2}\right)$ with marginal $\eta_{1}$ w.r.t. the first coordinate and marginal $\eta_{2}$ w.r.t. the second coordinate.

Markov transition kernels Given a probability measure $\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{M}_{1}\left(\mathbb{X}^{n}\right)$ for some $n \geqslant 1$ we denote by $\mathcal{P}^{b}$ the probability measure defined by reversing the coordinate order, that is

$$
\mathcal{P}^{b}\left(d\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)\right):=\mathcal{P}\left(d\left(x_{n}, x_{n-1}, \ldots, x_{1}\right)\right)
$$

In particular, for a Markov transition $\mathcal{K}(x, d y)$ from $\mathbb{X}$ into itself and a measure $\mu \in \mathcal{M}(\mathbb{X})$ we see that

$$
(\mu \times \mathcal{K})(d(x, y)):=\mu(d x) \mathcal{K}(x, d y)
$$

implies

$$
(\mu \times \mathcal{K})^{b}(d(x, y))=\mu(d y) \mathcal{K}(y, d x)
$$

For any pair of Markov transitions $\mathcal{K}_{1}, \mathcal{K}_{2}$ from $\mathbb{X}$ into itself we may also write

$$
\left(\mu \times \mathcal{K}_{1} \times \mathcal{K}_{2}\right)\left(d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right)\right)=\mu\left(d x_{0}\right) \mathcal{K}_{1}\left(x_{0}, d x_{1}\right) \mathcal{K}_{2}\left(x_{1}, d x_{2}\right)
$$

We also denote by $\left(\mathcal{K}_{1} \mathcal{K}_{2}\right)$ the Markov transition defined by the integral composition

$$
\left(\mathcal{K}_{1} \mathcal{K}_{2}\right)\left(x_{0}, d x_{2}\right):=\int \mathcal{K}_{1}\left(x_{0}, d x_{1}\right) \mathcal{K}_{2}\left(x_{1}, d x_{2}\right)
$$

Given a function $f \in \mathcal{B}(\mathbb{X})$, any measure $\mu \in \mathcal{M}(\mathbb{X})$ and any bounded integral positive operator $\mathcal{K}(x, d y)$. We denote by $\mu \mathcal{K} \in \mathcal{M}(\mathbb{X})$ and $\mathcal{K}(f) \in \mathcal{B}(\mathbb{X})$ the measure and the function defined by

$$
(\mu \mathcal{K})(d y):=\int \mu(d x) \mathcal{K}(x, d y) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{K}(f)(x):=\int \mathcal{K}(x, d y) f(y)
$$

respectively.

Transport maps For a given $\pi \in \mathcal{M}_{1}(\mathbb{X})$ and a transport map

$$
\begin{aligned}
& T: \quad \mathbb{X} \quad \mapsto \quad \mathbb{X} \\
& x \quad \rightsquigarrow \quad T(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

we denote by $T \star \pi$ the push forward of $\pi$ by $T$. Specifically, for any $f \in \mathcal{B}(\mathbb{X})$ we have

$$
(T \star \pi)(f):=\left(\pi \circ T^{-1}\right)(f):=\pi(f \circ T)
$$

For a given $\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{M}_{1}\left(\mathbb{X}^{2}\right)$, we denote by $\mathcal{P}^{X} \in \mathcal{M}_{1}(\mathbb{X})$ and $\mathcal{P}^{Y} \in \mathcal{M}_{1}(\mathbb{Y})$ the marginal probability measures

$$
\mathcal{P}^{X}(d x):=\int \mathcal{P}(d(x, y)) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{P}^{Y}(d y):=\int \mathcal{P}(d(x, y))
$$

respectively.

# 2.2 Matrix spaces and Riccati maps 

We denote by $\lambda_{\min }(v)$ and $\lambda_{\max }(v)$ the minimal and the maximal eigenvalues, respectively, of a symmetric matrix $v \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$ for some $d \geqslant 1$. The Frobenius matrix norm of a given matrix $v$ is defined by $\|v\|_{F}^{2}=\operatorname{Tr}\left(v^{\prime} v\right)$, with the trace operator $\operatorname{Tr}(\cdot)$ and $v^{\prime}$ the transpose of the matrix $v$. The spectral norm is defined by $\|v\|_{2}=\sqrt{\lambda_{\max }\left(v^{\prime} v\right)}$. We sometimes use the Löwner partial ordering notation $v_{1} \geqslant v_{2}$ to mean that a symmetric matrix $v_{1}-v_{2}$ is positive semi-definite (equivalently, $v_{2}-v_{1}$ is negative semi-definite), and $v_{1}>v_{2}$ when $v_{1}-v_{2}$ is positive definite (equivalently, $v_{2}-v_{1}$ is negative definite). Given $v \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$we denote by $v^{1 / 2}$ the principal (unique) symmetric square root.

For any $u, v \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$, the Bures-Wasserstein distance [9] on $\mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$is given by

$$
D_{b w}(u, v)^{2}:=\operatorname{Tr}(u)+\operatorname{Tr}(v)-\operatorname{Tr}\left(\left(v^{1 / 2} u v^{1 / 2}\right)^{1 / 2}\right)
$$

and the geometric mean $u \sharp v$ of two positive definite matrices $u, v \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$is defined by

$$
u \sharp v=v \sharp u:=v^{1 / 2}\left(v^{-1 / 2} u v^{-1 / 2}\right)^{1 / 2} v^{1 / 2}
$$

For completeness, a proof of the symmetric property is provided in Appendix F (on page 66). The geometric symmetric mean is the unique solution of the Riccati equation

$$
(u \sharp v) u^{-1}(u \sharp v)=v, \quad \text { or, equivalently, } \quad(v \sharp u) v^{-1}(v \sharp u)=u
$$

For any conformal matrices $(u, v)$, a direct application of Cauchy-Schwarz inequality yields

$$
|\operatorname{Tr}(u v)| \leqslant\|u\|_{F}\|v\|_{F} \quad \text { and } \quad\|u v\|_{F}=\sqrt{\operatorname{Tr}\left(u v v^{\prime} u^{\prime}\right)} \leqslant\|u\|_{2}\|v\|_{F}
$$

We also recall the norm equivalence

$$
\|u\|_{2}^{2} \leqslant\|u\|_{F}^{2} \leqslant d\|u\|_{2}^{2}
$$

that holds for any square $(d \times d)$ matrix $u$. Moreover, for any $u, v \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$ we have

$$
\operatorname{Tr}\left(u^{2}\right) \leqslant \operatorname{Tr}(u)^{2} \leqslant d \operatorname{Tr}\left(u^{2}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \lambda_{\min }(u) \operatorname{Tr}(v) \leqslant \operatorname{Tr}(u v) \leqslant \lambda_{\max }(u) \operatorname{Tr}(v)
$$

We note that (2.5) is also valid when $v$ is positive semi-definite and $u$ is symmetric. This can be verified using an orthogonal diagonalization of $u$ and recalling that $v$ remains positive semi-definite (thus with non negative diagonal entries).

We also quote the following estimate taken from [37]

$$
\|u\|_{F}<\frac{1}{2} \Longrightarrow|\log \operatorname{det}(I-u)| \leqslant \frac{3}{2}\|u\|_{F}
$$

For any $u, v \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$we have the Ando-Hemmen inequality

$$
\left\|u^{1 / 2}-v^{1 / 2}\right\| \leqslant\left[\lambda_{\min }^{1 / 2}(u)+\lambda_{\min }^{1 / 2}(v)\right]^{-1}\|u-v\|
$$

that holds for any unitary invariant matrix norm $\|\cdot\|$, including the spectral and the Frobenius norms - see for instance Theorem 6.2 on page 135 in [46], as well as Proposition 3.2 in [5].

With a slight abuse of notation, we denote by $I$ the $(d \times d)$-identity matrix and by 0 the null $(d \times d)$-matrix and the null $d$-dimensional vector, for any choice of the dimension $d \geqslant 1$. We usually represent points $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ by $d$-dimensional column vectors and $1 \times d$ matrices. In this notation, the Frobenius norm $\|x\|_{F}=\sqrt{x^{\prime} x}$ coincides with the Euclidean norm and we denote by $\mathbb{W}_{p}$ the $p$-th Wasserstein distance on $\mathcal{M}_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ associated with the Euclidean norm. When there is no possible confusion, we use the notation $\|\cdot\|$ for any equivalent matrix or vector norm.

For any given $m_{1}, m_{2} \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2} \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$, we have

$$
\mathbb{W}_{2}\left(\nu_{m_{1}, \sigma_{1}}, \nu_{m_{2}, \sigma_{2}}\right)^{2}=D_{b w}\left(\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}\right)^{2}+\left\|m_{1}-m_{2}\right\|_{F}^{2}
$$

Also recall that the relative entropy of $\nu_{m_{1}, \sigma_{1}}$ w.r.t. $\nu_{m_{2}, \sigma_{2}}$ is given by the formula

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\nu_{m_{1}, \sigma_{1}} \mid \nu_{m_{2}, \sigma_{2}}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(D\left(\sigma_{1} \mid \sigma_{2}\right)+\left\|\sigma_{2}^{-1 / 2}\left(m_{1}-m_{2}\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}\right)
$$

with the Burg (a.k.a. log-det) divergence

$$
D\left(\sigma_{1} \mid \sigma_{2}\right):=\operatorname{Tr}\left(\sigma_{1} \sigma_{2}^{-1}-I\right)-\log \operatorname{det}\left(\sigma_{1} \sigma_{2}^{-1}\right)
$$

We associate with some given $\varpi \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$the increasing map $\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}$ from $\mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$ into $\mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}: \mathcal{S}_{d}^{0} \mapsto \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+} \\
& v \leadsto \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}(v):=(I+(\varpi+v)^{-1})^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

A refined stability analysis of Riccati matrix differences $v_{n+1}:=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}\left(v_{n}\right)$ and the limiting stationary matrices $r=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}(r)$ associated with these maps is provided in Appendix B (on page 45).

These matrix equations belong to the class of discrete algebraic Riccati equations (DARE), and no analytical solutions are available for general models. We present a novel simple

closed-form solution in terms of the matrix $\varpi$. As shown in Proposition B. 3 (see also (B.2)) the unique positive definite fixed point of the Riccati differences is given by

$$
\left(I+\varpi^{-1}\right)^{-1} \leqslant r:=-\frac{\varpi}{2}+\left(\varpi+\left(\frac{\varpi}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \leqslant I
$$

In addition, applying Proposition B. 6 there exists some constant $c_{\varpi}$ such that

$$
\left\|v_{n}-r\right\|_{2} \leqslant c_{\varpi}\left(1+\lambda_{\min }(\varpi+r)\right)^{-2 n}\left\|v_{0}-r\right\|_{2}
$$

The contraction rates in (2.13) are based on Floquet-type representation of Riccati flows and they are sharp (see Theorem 1.3 in [35] as well as Remark 4.4 and Proposition B. 6 in the present article). For further discussion see Appendix B (on page 45), the article [35], and the references therein.

# 2.3 Conjugate Gaussian principles 

We associate with some $\theta=(\alpha, \beta, \tau) \in \Theta$ the Markov transition $K_{\theta}$ from $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ into itself defined by

$$
K_{\theta}(x, d y):=\mathbb{P}\left(Z_{\theta}(x) \in d y\right) \quad \text { and } \quad Z_{\theta}(x):=\alpha+\beta x+\tau^{1 / 2} G \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

where $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, \beta \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}, \tau \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$and $G$ stands for a $d$-dimensional centered Gaussian random variable (r.v.) with unit covariance.

Hereafter, let us assume that $(m, \bar{m}) \in\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ and $(\sigma, \bar{\sigma}) \in\left(\mathcal{S}_{d}^{+} \times \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}\right)$are given fixed parameters. For a given parameter set $\theta \in \Theta$ and Gaussian measures $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ and $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$, we define the probability measures

$$
P_{\theta}:=\nu_{m, \sigma} \times K_{\theta} \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{P}_{\theta}:=\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}} \times K_{\theta}
$$

and observe that

$$
\nu_{m, \sigma} K_{\theta}=\nu_{h_{m, \sigma}(\theta)} \quad \text { with } \quad h_{m, \sigma}(\theta)=\left(a_{m}(\theta), b_{\sigma}(\theta)\right):=\left(\alpha+\beta m, \beta \sigma \beta^{\prime}+\tau\right)
$$

Definition 2.1. To each pair of fixed parameters $(m, \sigma) \in\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}\right)$we associate the map

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}: & \Theta \\
& \theta=(\alpha, \beta, \tau) \quad \mapsto \Theta \\
& \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta)=(\iota, \kappa, \varsigma)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\kappa:=\sigma \beta^{\prime} b_{\sigma}(\theta)^{-1}, \quad \iota=m-\kappa a_{m}(\theta), \quad \text { and } \quad \varsigma^{-1}:=\sigma^{-1}+\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta
$$

Lemma 2.2. The conjugate formula

$$
\left(\nu_{h_{m, \sigma}(\theta)} \times K_{\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta)}\right)^{b}=\nu_{m, \sigma} \times K_{\theta}
$$

holds for any parameter set $\theta \in \Theta$.

The proof of (2.17) follows readily from the construction of the maps $h_{m, \sigma}$ and $\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}$. In statistical theory the transformation (2.17) coincides with the Bayes updates of Gaussian distributions -hence, we use the terminology Bayes maps to refer to these transformations.

The (random) transport map (2.14) associated with $\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta)$ has the form

$$
Z_{\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta)}(x)=m+\kappa\left(x-a_{m}(\theta)\right)+\varsigma^{1 / 2} G
$$

and, using the matrix inversion lemma, we can readily verify that

$$
\varsigma=\sigma-\sigma \beta^{\prime} b_{\sigma}(\theta)^{-1} \beta \sigma=\sigma-\kappa b_{\sigma}(\theta) \kappa^{\prime}
$$

or, equivalently,

$$
\kappa b_{\sigma}(\theta) \kappa^{\prime}+\varsigma=\sigma
$$

Remark 2.3. We underline that the Gaussian transition (2.14) encapsulates all continuous time Gaussian models used in machine learning applications of Schrödinger bridges. Following [11] (see also [14]), let $\mathcal{E}_{s, t}(A)$ be the exponential semi-group (or the state transition matrix) associated with a smooth flow of matrices $A: t \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \mapsto A_{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$ defined for any $s \leqslant t$ by the forward and backward differential equations

$$
\partial_{t} \mathcal{E}_{s, t}(A)=A_{t} \mathcal{E}_{s, t}(A) \quad \text { and } \quad \partial_{s} \mathcal{E}_{s, t}(A)=-\mathcal{E}_{s, t}(A) A_{s}
$$

respectively, where $\mathcal{E}_{s, s}(A)=\mathrm{Id}$. Equivalently in terms of the matrices $\mathcal{E}_{t}(A):=\mathcal{E}_{0, t}(A)$ we have $\mathcal{E}_{s, t}(A)=\mathcal{E}_{t}(A) \mathcal{E}_{s}(A)^{-1}$. We let $\mathcal{X}_{t}(x)$ be the linear diffusion process starting at $\mathcal{X}_{0}(x)=x$ defined by

$$
d \mathcal{X}_{t}(x)=\left(A_{t} \mathcal{X}_{t}(x)+b_{t}\right) d t+\Sigma_{t}^{1 / 2} d W_{t}
$$

where $W_{t}$ a d-dimensional Wiener process, $b: t \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \mapsto b_{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $\Sigma: t \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \mapsto \Sigma_{t} \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$ a flow of positive definite matrices. Observe that the solution of (2.19) at some final time horizon $t$ is provided by the formula

$$
\mathcal{X}_{t}(x) \stackrel{\text { law }}{=} \alpha[t]+\beta[t] x+\tau[t]^{1 / 2} G
$$

with the parameters

$$
\alpha[t]:=\int_{0}^{t} \mathcal{E}_{s, t}(A) b_{s} d s, \quad \beta[t]:=\mathcal{E}_{t}(A) \quad \text { and } \quad \tau[t]:=\int_{0}^{t} \mathcal{E}_{s, t}(A) \Sigma_{s} \mathcal{E}_{s, t}(A)^{\prime} d s
$$

There are some relevant special cases:

- When $A_{t}=0, b_{t}=0$ and $\Sigma_{t}=\Sigma$ we recover the heat equation transition semigroup

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\mathcal{X}_{t}(x) \in d y\right)=(2 \pi t)^{-d / 2} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2 t}(y-x)^{\prime} \Sigma^{-1}(y-x)\right) d y
$$

Note that in this case we have $(\alpha[t], \beta[t])=(0, I)$ and a linear growth variance

$$
\tau[t]=t \Sigma \xrightarrow{t \rightarrow \infty} \infty
$$

- When $\Sigma=I$ the above formula reduces to

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\mathcal{X}_{t}(x) \in d y\right)=\exp \left(-c_{t}(x, y)\right) d y
$$

with the symmetric quadratic cost $c_{t}$ defined in (1.2).

- The Ornstein-Uhlenbeck diffusion corresponds to the case case $b_{t}=0, \Sigma_{t}=\Sigma \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$ and $A_{t}=A$ for some Hurwitz matrix $A$. It yields $\alpha[t]=0, \beta[t]=e^{t A} \frac{t \rightarrow \infty}{0}$ and a uniformly bounded variance $\tau[t] \leqslant \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{s A} \Sigma e^{s A^{\prime}} d s$.

# 2.4 Conditional Gaussian distributions 

For conciseness, let $X \sim \eta$ indicate that $X$ is a r.v. with probability distribution $\eta$ on some state space. We can interpret the Bayes' maps of Section 2.3 in terms of conditional Gaussian distributions. Specifically, assume that the r.v. $X \sim \nu_{m, \sigma}$ is observed by way of some linear-Gaussian transformation, namely,

$$
Y=\alpha+\beta X+\tau^{1 / 2} G
$$

The mean and covariance of $Y$ can readily be written as

$$
\mathbb{E}(Y)=a_{m}(\theta) \quad \text { and } \quad \Sigma_{Y, Y}:=\mathbb{E}\left((Y-\mathbb{E}(Y))(Y-\mathbb{E}(Y))^{\prime}\right)=b_{\sigma}(\theta)
$$

where $\theta:=(\alpha, \beta, \tau)$ and $G \sim \nu_{0, I}$ denotes a centered Gaussian r.v. independent of $X$. The conditional distribution of the r.v. $X$ given an observation $Y=y$ is Gaussian, specifically,

$$
\mathbb{P}(X \in d x \mid Y=y)=\mathbb{P}\left(Z_{\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta)}(y) \in d x\right)
$$

where $\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}$ is the Bayes map in Definition 2.1.
In the Kalman filtering literature, the matrix $\kappa$ is often called the (Kalman) gain matrix as it reflects the degree to which each observation $Y=y$ is incorporated into the estimation of the state $X$. The gain matrix is sometimes given in terms of covariances matrices by the formulae

$$
\kappa=\Sigma_{X, Y} \Sigma_{Y, Y}^{-1}
$$

where

$$
\Sigma_{X, Y}:=\mathbb{E}\left((X-\mathbb{E}(X))(Y-\mathbb{E}(Y))^{\prime}\right)=\Sigma_{X, X} \beta^{\prime} \quad \text { and } \quad \Sigma_{X, X}:=\sigma
$$

Remark 2.4. Gaussian models of the form (2.15) encapsulate general models of the form $\mathcal{X}:=\binom{X}{Y}$ with a mean prescribed mean $\mathbb{E}(\mathcal{X})=\binom{\mathbb{E}(X)}{\mathbb{E}(Y)}$ and given covariance matrix

$$
\Sigma_{\mathcal{X}, \mathcal{X}}:=\mathbb{E}\left((\mathcal{X}-\mathbb{E}(\mathcal{X}))(\mathcal{X}-\mathbb{E}(\mathcal{X}))^{\prime}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\Sigma_{X, X} & \Sigma_{X, Y} \\
\Sigma_{Y, X} & \Sigma_{Y, Y}
\end{array}\right)
$$

In this context, we have $\mathbb{E}(X)=m$ and $\Sigma_{X, X}=\sigma$ as well as

$$
\alpha:=\mathbb{E}(Y)-\beta \mathbb{E}(X) \quad \text { and } \quad \beta=\Sigma_{Y, X} \Sigma_{X, X}^{-1}
$$

We also have the Schur complement

$$
\tau=\Sigma_{Y, Y}-\Sigma_{Y, X} \Sigma_{X, X}^{-1} \Sigma_{X, Y}>0
$$

where $\tau>0$ if, and only if, $\Sigma_{\mathcal{X}, \mathcal{X}}>0$.

We observe that

$$
\theta_{0}=\theta:=(\alpha, \beta, \tau) \quad \text { yields } \quad \pi_{0}:=\nu_{m, \sigma} K_{\theta_{0}}=\nu_{m_{0}, \sigma_{0}}
$$

with the parameters

$$
\left(m_{0}, \sigma_{0}\right)=\left(\alpha+\beta m, \beta \sigma \beta^{\prime}+\tau\right)
$$

In addition, we have the conjugate property

$$
\theta_{1}:=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}\left(\theta_{0}\right)=\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \tau_{1}\right)
$$

with the parameters

$$
\alpha_{1}+\beta_{1} m_{0}=m, \quad \beta_{1}=\sigma \beta^{\prime} \sigma_{0}^{-1} \quad \text { and } \quad \tau_{1}^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta
$$

This yields the Gaussian Markov transport formula

$$
\pi_{1}:=\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}} K_{\theta_{1}}=\nu_{m_{1}, \sigma_{1}}
$$

with the parameters

$$
m_{1}=\alpha_{1}+\beta_{1} \bar{m}=m+\beta_{1}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{1}=\beta_{1} \bar{\sigma} \beta_{1}^{\prime}+\tau_{1}
$$

Combining (2.21) with the matrix inversion lemma we readily see that

$$
\sigma_{0}^{-1}=\tau^{-1}-\tau^{-1} \beta \tau_{1} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}
$$

which implies

$$
\beta_{1}=\sigma \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}-\sigma\left(\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta\right) \tau_{1} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}=\tau_{1} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}, \quad \text { hence } \quad \tau_{1}^{-1} \beta_{1}=\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}
$$

# 2.5 The Gaussian bridge problem 

Consider some probability measures $\eta, \mu \in \mathcal{M}_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ and some reference probability measure $\mathcal{P}_{0} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2 d}\right)$ of the form $\mathcal{P}_{0}=\eta \times \mathcal{K}_{0}$. Assume that the Markov transition $\mathcal{K}_{0}$ from $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ into itself is chosen so that $\mu \ll \eta \mathcal{K}_{0}$. This condition is clearly met for the linear Gaussian model (2.15) with the target marginal measures $(\eta, \mu):=\left(\nu_{m, \sigma}, \nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}\right)$, the product measure $\mathcal{P}=\eta \otimes \mu$ and the reference probability measure

$$
\mathcal{P}_{0}=P_{\theta} \quad \text { for any given } \theta=(\alpha, \beta, \tau) \in \Theta
$$

For a given distribution $P_{\theta}$ associated with some reference parameter $\theta \in \Theta$, the (static) Schrödinger bridge problem (1.3) from $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ to $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ is equivalent to the problem

$$
\mathbb{S}(\theta):=\underset{\theta_{1} \in \Omega_{m, \sigma}(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma})}{\arg \min }\left(P_{\theta_{1}} \mid P_{\theta}\right)
$$

with the subset

$$
\Omega_{m, \sigma}(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}):=\left\{\theta \in \Theta: h_{m, \sigma}(\theta)=(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma})\right\}
$$

Note that there is no need to specify the first coordinate of the parameter $\theta \in \Omega_{m, \sigma}(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma})$ because

$$
(\alpha, \beta, \tau) \in \Omega_{m, \sigma}(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}) \quad \text { implies that } \quad \alpha=\bar{m}-\beta m
$$

Given a reference measure $P_{\theta}$, the measure $P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}$ is the minimal entropy probability distribution with prescribed marginal $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ w.r.t. the second coordinate. Note that $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ is the marginal of both measures $P_{\theta}$ and $P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}$ w.r.t. the first coordinate.

For any parameters

$$
\theta_{0}=(\alpha, \beta, \tau) \in \Theta \quad \text { and } \quad \theta_{1}=(\iota, \kappa, \varsigma) \in \Theta
$$

we have the Boltzmann relative entropy (a.k.a. Kullback Leibler divergence) formula

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Ent}\left(P_{\theta_{1}} \mid P_{\theta_{0}}\right):=\int \log \frac{d P_{\theta_{1}}}{d P_{\theta_{0}}} d P_{\theta_{1}} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} D(\varsigma \mid \tau)+\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}((\iota+\kappa m)-(\alpha+\beta m))\right\|_{F}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(\kappa-\beta) \sigma^{1 / 2}\right\|_{F}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The proof of equality (2.25) follows from elementary manipulations and it is provided in Appendix C (on page 52). We also quote the following estimate

$$
\|\varsigma-\tau\|_{F}\left\|\tau^{-1}\right\|_{F} \leqslant \frac{1}{2}, \quad \text { which implies } \quad D(\varsigma \mid \tau) \leqslant \frac{5}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1}\right\|_{F} \quad\|\varsigma-\tau\|_{F}
$$

A detailed proof of expression (2.26) is provided in Appendix C (see page 52) and Section 11 in [37]). We also note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
H\left(P_{\theta_{1}} \mid P_{\theta_{0}}\right) & :=\operatorname{Ent}\left(P_{\theta_{1}} \mid P_{\theta_{0}}\right)+\int\left(\eta K_{\theta_{1}}\right)(d y) V(y) \\
& =-\int \log q_{\theta_{0}}(x, y) P_{\theta_{1}}(d(x, y))+\operatorname{Ent}\left(P_{\theta_{1}} \mid \eta \otimes \mu\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In addition,

$$
\theta_{1} \in \Omega_{m, \sigma}(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}) \quad \text { if, and only if, } \quad \eta K_{\theta_{1}}=\nu_{m, \sigma} K_{\theta_{1}}=\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}=\mu
$$

which shows that

$$
\mathbb{S}(\theta)=\underset{\theta_{1} \in \Omega_{m, \sigma}(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma})}{\arg \min } H\left(P_{\theta_{1}} \mid P_{\theta}\right)
$$

Switching the role of the parameters $(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma})$ and $(m, \sigma)$, for a given distribution $\bar{P}_{\theta}$ associated with some reference parameter $\theta \in \Theta$, solving the Schrödinger bridge from $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ to $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ is equivalent to solving the minimization problem

$$
\overline{\mathbb{S}}(\theta):=\underset{\theta_{1} \in \Omega_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}(m, \sigma)}{\arg \min }\left(\bar{P}_{\theta_{1}} \mid \bar{P}_{\theta}\right)
$$

# 3 Bridges and transport maps
### 3.1 Entropic transport maps

The solution of the minimization problem (2.24) clearly depends on the choice of the reference parameters $\theta=(\alpha, \beta, \tau)$, as well as on the parameters $(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma})$ and $(m, \sigma)$ of the target marginal measures. To be precise, consider the matrix

$$
\varpi_{\theta}^{-1}:=\gamma_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+} \quad \text { with } \quad \gamma_{\theta}:=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \chi_{\theta} \sigma^{1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \quad \chi_{\theta}:=\tau^{-1} \beta
$$

and denote by $r_{\theta}$ the (unique) positive-definite fixed point of the Riccati map (2.11) associated with $\varpi_{\theta}$, i.e.,

$$
\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi_{\theta}}\left(r_{\theta}\right)=r_{\theta}=-\frac{\varpi_{\theta}}{2}+\left(\varpi_{\theta}+\left(\frac{\varpi_{\theta}}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

A closed form expression of $r_{\theta}$ is given by (2.12), simply replacing $\varpi$ by $\varpi_{\theta}$. A proof of the fixed-point formula (3.2) is provided in Appendix D (on page 46, see Eq. (B.8)).

We are now in position to state the first main result.
Theorem 3.1. The Schrödinger bridge map (2.24) is given by $\mathbb{S}(\theta):=\left(\iota_{\theta}, \kappa_{\theta}, \varsigma_{\theta}\right) \in \Omega_{m, \sigma}(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma})$ with the parameters

$$
\varsigma_{\theta}:=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} r_{\theta} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}, \quad \kappa_{\theta}:=\varsigma_{\theta} \chi_{\theta}, \quad \text { and } \quad \iota_{\theta}=\bar{m}-\kappa_{\theta} m
$$

By the uniqueness of the Schrödinger bridge (2.24), Theorem 3.1 is a direct consequence of the following equivalences

$$
\begin{aligned}
\kappa_{\theta} \sigma \kappa_{\theta}^{\prime}+\varsigma_{\theta}=\bar{\sigma} & \Longleftrightarrow \varsigma_{\theta}+\varsigma_{\theta}\left(\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \varpi_{\theta} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\right)^{-1} \varsigma_{\theta}=\bar{\sigma} \\
& \Longleftrightarrow r_{\theta} \varpi_{\theta}^{-1} r_{\theta}+r_{\theta}=I \Longleftrightarrow r_{\theta}=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi_{\theta}}\left(r_{\theta}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the first assertion comes from the fact that

$$
\left(\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \varpi_{\theta} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\right)^{-1}=\tau^{-1} \beta \sigma \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}=\chi_{\theta} \sigma \chi_{\theta}^{\prime}
$$

and the last assertion is proved in Appendix A, eq. (B.8).
We recall that Schrödinger bridges can also be written in terms of the entropic cost function $H\left(\cdot \mid P_{\theta}\right)$ defined in (2.27). In particular, from Theorem 3.1 and (2.28) we have

$$
H\left(P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)} \mid P_{\theta}\right)=\min _{\theta_{1} \in \Omega_{m, \sigma}(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma})} H\left(P_{\theta_{1}} \mid P_{\theta}\right)
$$

We can also express the bridge transport map between the distributions $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ and $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ in terms of the random transformation (2.14), namely,

$$
Z_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}(x)=\bar{m}+\kappa_{\theta}(x-m)+\varsigma_{\theta}^{1 / 2} G
$$

In particular, for the multivariate Gaussian models discussed in Remark 2.4, the Schrödinger bridge $P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}$ is the distribution of a random variable $\mathcal{X}:=\binom{X}{Y}$ with mean $\mathbb{E}(\mathcal{X})=\binom{m}{\bar{m}}$ and covariance matrix

$$
\Sigma_{\mathcal{X}, \mathcal{X}}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\Sigma_{X, X} & \Sigma_{X, Y} \\
\Sigma_{Y, X} & \Sigma_{Y, Y}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\sigma & \sigma \kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \\
\kappa_{\theta} \sigma & \bar{\sigma}
\end{array}\right)
$$

When $\beta=I$ and $\tau=t I$ the above formula reduces to formula (2) discussed in the recent article [14]. Theorem 3.1 can be seen as a simplification and a generalization of Schrödinger bridge formulae recently presented in the series of articles $[1,12,14,30,47,53]$ when the drift matrix $\beta$ is arbitrary and $\tau$ is an arbitrary positive definite matrix. Following the discussion given in Remark 2.3, this formula also apply to all the continuous time Gaussian models used in machine learning applications of Schrödinger bridges. To the best of our knowledge this general formula is new.
Remark 3.2. Note that $\mathbb{S}(\theta)$ does not depend on $\alpha$. Also observe that

$$
\chi_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}=\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1} \kappa_{\theta}=\chi_{\theta} \quad \text { implies that } \quad \varpi_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}=\varpi_{\theta} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathbb{S}^{2}:=\mathbb{S} \circ \mathbb{S}=\mathbb{S}
$$

# 3.2 Dual bridge maps 

In this section, we discuss dual bridge maps and define several dual quantities which will be used throughout the paper.

Theorem 3.3. The Schrödinger bridges $(\mathbb{S}, \overline{\mathbb{S}})$ defined in (2.24) and (2.29) satisfy the commutation property

$$
\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma} \circ \mathbb{S}=\overline{\mathbb{S}} \circ \mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathbb{B}_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}} \circ \overline{\mathbb{S}}=\mathbb{S} \circ \mathbb{B}_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}
$$

with the Bayes maps $\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}$ and $\mathbb{B}_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ defined in (2.16).
A proof of Theorem 3.3 is provided in Appendix F (on page 66). The commutation property (3.6) also yields the straightforward corollary below.

Corollary 3.4. We have the fixed point properties

$$
\left(\mathbb{B}_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}} \circ \mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}\right) \circ \mathbb{S}=\mathbb{S}=\mathbb{S} \circ\left(\mathbb{B}_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}} \circ \mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}\right)
$$

For Gaussian models, the iterations of the Sinkhorn algorithm coincide with the iterates of Bayes maps (see, e.g., (4.6)) and, in particular, Corollary 5.6 shows that

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\mathbb{B}_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}} \circ \mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}\right)^{n}(\theta)=\mathbb{S}(\theta)
$$

By symmetry arguments we also have

$$
\left(\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma} \circ \mathbb{B}_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}\right) \circ \overline{\mathbb{S}}=\overline{\mathbb{S}}=\overline{\mathbb{S}} \circ\left(\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma} \circ \mathbb{B}_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}\right)
$$

Theorem 3.3 implies that the dual bridge parameter $\overline{\mathbb{S}}\left(\theta_{1}\right)$ between the distributions $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ and $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ and reference parameter $\theta_{1}:=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta)$ can be computed using the Bayes transform $\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\mathbb{S}(\theta))$ of the bridge parameter $\mathbb{S}(\theta)$ between $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ and $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$. As a consequence

$$
\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\mathbb{S}(\theta))=\left(m-\sigma \kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \bar{\sigma}^{-1} \bar{m}, \sigma \kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \bar{\sigma}^{-1},\left(\sigma^{-1}+\kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta}^{-1} \kappa_{\theta}\right)^{-1}\right)
$$

Theorem 3.1 also ensures that the Schrödinger bridge map $\overline{\mathbb{S}}$ from $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ to $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ with reference parameter $\theta_{1}=\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \tau_{1}\right)$ is given by

$$
\overline{\mathbb{S}}\left(\theta_{1}\right):=\left(\bar{\imath}_{\theta_{1}}, \bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}, \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}\right) \quad \text { with } \quad \bar{\imath}_{\theta_{1}}:=m-\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}} \bar{m}
$$

and the parameters

$$
\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}:=\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}} \chi_{\theta_{1}} \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}:=\sigma^{1 / 2} \bar{\tau}_{\theta_{1}} \sigma^{1 / 2} \quad \text { where } \quad \chi_{\theta_{1}}:=\tau_{1}^{-1} \beta_{1}
$$

In (3.7), $\bar{\tau}_{\theta_{1}}$ stands for the positive definite fixed point of the Riccati map associated with the matrix

$$
\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}:=\bar{\gamma}_{\theta_{1}} \bar{\gamma}_{\theta_{1}}^{\prime}, \quad \text { where } \quad \bar{\gamma}_{\theta_{1}}:=\sigma^{1 / 2} \chi_{\theta_{1}} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}
$$

By (3.2) we have

$$
\operatorname{Ricc}_{\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}}\left(\bar{\tau}_{\theta_{1}}\right)=\bar{\tau}_{\theta_{1}}:=-\frac{\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}}{2}+\left(\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}+\left(\frac{\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

and (2.23) implies that

$$
\theta_{1}:=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta) \quad \text { and } \quad \theta=(\alpha, \beta, \tau)
$$

together yield

$$
\chi_{\theta_{1}}=\tau_{1}^{-1} \beta_{1}=\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}=\chi_{\theta}^{\prime}, \quad \bar{\gamma}_{\theta_{1}}=\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{w}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}=\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \gamma_{\theta}
$$

Remark 3.5. Note that for one-dimensional models we have $\bar{w}_{\theta_{1}}=\varpi_{\theta}$ and, therefore, $\operatorname{Ricc}_{\bar{w}_{\theta_{1}}}=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi_{\theta}}$.

The fixed point matrices $\left(r_{\theta}, \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}\right)$ defined in (3.2) and (3.9) are connected with the formulae

$$
r_{\theta}^{-1}=I+\gamma_{\theta} \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}=I+\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} r_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}
$$

The proof of (3.10) is rather technical, thus it is provided in Appendix B (on page 50). In terms of the rescaled fixed points $\left(\varsigma_{\theta}, \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}\right)$ formulae (3.10) take the following form

$$
\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1}=\bar{\sigma}^{-1}+\chi_{\theta} \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}} \chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta} \chi_{\theta}
$$

Finally, we can rewrite Theorem 3.3 in terms of transport maps as shown below.
Corollary 3.6. The dual transport map between the distributions $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ and $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ and reference parameter $\theta_{1}:=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta)$ is given by

$$
Z_{\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{1}\right)}(y):=m+\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}(y-\bar{m})+\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}^{1 / 2} G
$$

with the parameters

$$
\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}=\sigma \kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \bar{\sigma}^{-1}=\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}} \chi_{\theta_{1}} \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}=\left(\sigma^{-1}+\kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta}^{-1} \kappa_{\theta}\right)^{-1}=\sigma^{1 / 2} \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}} \sigma^{1 / 2}
$$

# 3.3 Schrödinger potential functions 

In the context of Gaussian models, the bridge distribution $\mathcal{P}=P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}$ discussed in (1.6) and (2.24) can be expressed in terms of Schrödinger potential functions $\left(\mathbb{U}_{\theta}, \mathbb{V}_{\theta}\right)$ that depend on the reference parameter $\theta \in \Theta$. These potential functions satisfy the bridge equation

$$
P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}(d(x, y))=\mathbb{P}_{\theta}(d(x, y)):=e^{-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(x)} q_{\theta}(x, y) e^{-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(y)} d x d y
$$

Note that the potentials $\left(\mathbb{U}_{\theta}, \mathbb{V}_{\theta}\right)$ in (3.14) are unique up to an additive constant. Choosing $(x, y)=(m, \bar{m})$ and setting $m_{0}:=(\alpha+\beta m)$ we readily check that potential functions satisfy the identity

$$
\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(\bar{m})+\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(m)=\frac{1}{2} \log \operatorname{det}(\sigma)+\frac{1}{2} \log \operatorname{det}\left(\varsigma_{\theta} \tau^{-1}\right)-\frac{1}{2}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)
$$

As in (1.5), the potential functions $\left(\mathbb{U}_{\theta}, \mathbb{V}_{\theta}\right)$ can be estimated using the Sinkhorn algorithm. We refer to Section 6.2 for a refined analysis of these approximations.

Theorem 3.7. For any $\theta=(\alpha, \beta, \tau) \in \Theta$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{V}_{\theta}(y+\bar{m})-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(\bar{m})=y^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)+\frac{1}{2} y^{\prime}\left(\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1}-\tau^{-1}\right) y, \quad \text { and } \\
& \mathbb{U}_{\theta}(x+m)-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(m)=x^{\prime} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2} x^{\prime}\left(\zeta_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}-\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta\right) x
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\theta_{1}=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta), m_{0}$ as in (3.15) and $\left(\varsigma_{\theta}, \zeta_{\theta_{1}}\right)$ defined in (3.3) and (3.7).
Proof. A detailed proof of the theorem is provided in Appendix E on page 59, see also Corollary 6.16. Next, we sketch an elementary and direct proof based on the identification of the quadratic forms involved in (3.14). For instance, using (3.14) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\exp \left(\left(\mathbb{U}_{\theta}-U\right)(x)\right)}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}\left(2 \pi \varsigma_{\theta}\right)}} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\zeta_{\theta}^{-1 / 2}\left((y-\bar{m})-\kappa_{\theta}(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}\right) \\
& =\frac{\exp \left(-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(y)\right)}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}(2 \pi \tau)}} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(y-\bar{m})-\tau^{-1 / 2}\left(\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)+\beta(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The proof of the first assertion simply rely on the identification of the terms of the quadratic function w.r.t. coordinate $(y-\bar{m})$. On the other hand, using (3.14) and the commutation Theorem 3.3 we also have the conjugate formulae

$$
P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}(d(x, y))=e^{-V(y)} d y K_{\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{1}\right)}(y, d x)=e^{-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(y)} q_{\theta}(x, y) e^{-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(x)} d x d y
$$

This yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\exp \left(\left(\mathbb{V}_{\theta}-V\right)(y)\right)}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}\left(2 \pi \zeta_{\theta_{1}}\right)}} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\zeta_{\theta_{1}}^{-1 / 2}\left((x-m)-\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}(y-\bar{m})\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}\right) \\
& =\frac{\exp \left(-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(x)\right)}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}(2 \pi \tau)}} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(y-\bar{m})-\tau^{-1 / 2}\left(\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)+\beta(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The proof of the second assertion simply relies on the identification of the terms of the quadratic function w.r.t. coordinate $(x-m)$.

Remark 3.8. Using (2.23) we have

$$
\tau_{1}^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta \quad \text { and } \quad \tau_{1}^{-1}\left(m_{1}-m\right)=\tau_{1}^{-1} \beta_{1}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)=\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)
$$

Combining the above formula with (2.21) we check that

$$
\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(x+m)-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(m)=(U(x+m)-U(m))+x^{\prime} \tau_{1}^{-1}\left(m_{1}-m\right)+\frac{1}{2} x^{\prime}\left(\zeta_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}-\tau_{1}^{-1}\right) x
$$

# 3.4 Entropic regularization
### 3.4.1 Bridge transport maps

Consider the reference parameter

$$
\theta(t):=(\alpha, \beta, t I) \quad \text { for some } t>0
$$

The bridge transport map (3.5) associated with the reference parameter $\theta(t)$ takes the form

$$
Z_{\mathbb{S}(\theta(t))}(x)=\bar{m}+\kappa_{\theta(t)}(x-m)+\varsigma_{\theta(t)}^{1 / 2} G
$$

with the matrices

$$
\kappa_{\theta(t)}:=\frac{\varsigma_{\theta(t)}}{t} \beta \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{\varsigma_{\theta(t)}}{t}=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \frac{r_{\theta(t)}}{t} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}
$$

If we now consider the conjugate parameter

$$
\theta_{1}(t):=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta(t))=\left(\alpha_{1}(t), \beta_{1}(t), \tau_{1}(t)\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}} K_{\theta_{1}(t)}=\nu_{m_{1}(t), \sigma_{1}(t)}
$$

then the bridge transport map (3.12) associated with $\theta_{1}(t)$ takes the form

$$
Z_{\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{1}(t)\right)}(y):=m+\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}(t)}(y-\bar{m})+\varsigma_{\theta_{1}(t)}^{1 / 2} G
$$

with the parameters

$$
\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}(t)}=\frac{\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}(t)}}{t} \beta^{\prime} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}(t)}}{t}=\sigma^{1 / 2} \frac{\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}(t)}}{t} \sigma^{1 / 2}
$$

Also, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\varpi_{\theta(t)} & =t^{2} \omega \quad \text { with } \quad \omega:=\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{\beta}:=\beta \sigma \beta^{\prime}, \quad \text { and } \\
\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}(t)} & =t^{2} \omega_{1} \quad \text { with } \quad \omega_{1}:=\sigma^{-1 / 2} \bar{\sigma}_{\beta^{\prime}}^{-1} \sigma^{-1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{\sigma}_{\beta^{\prime}}:=\beta^{\prime} \bar{\sigma} \beta .
\end{aligned}
$$

### 3.4.2 Independence property

Next result reflects the independence properties of the bridge maps when the regularization parameter $t \rightarrow \infty$. By (2.12), choosing the parameter $\theta(t)$ defined in (3.17), we have

$$
\left(I+t^{-2} \varpi^{-1}\right)^{-1} \leqslant r_{\theta(t)} \leqslant I \quad \text { and } \quad\left(I+t^{-2} \varpi_{1}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \leqslant \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}(t)} \leqslant I
$$

Remark 3.9. Note that the bridge gain matrix $\kappa_{\theta(t)}$ may be unstable. For instance, for one dimensional models with $\beta=1$, we have $\omega^{-1}:=\bar{\sigma} \sigma$ and using (3.19) we arrive at

$$
\kappa_{\theta(t)}=\frac{\bar{\sigma}}{t} r_{\theta(t)} \geqslant \frac{\bar{\sigma}}{t}\left(1+\frac{\bar{\sigma}}{t} \frac{\sigma}{t}\right)^{-1}
$$

Choosing $\bar{\sigma}$ sufficiently large, we have

$$
\frac{\bar{\sigma}}{t}\left(1-\frac{\sigma}{t}\right)>1 \quad \text { which implies that } \quad \kappa_{\theta(t)}>1
$$

Nevertheless, choosing $t>\bar{\sigma}$ sufficiently large we ensure $\kappa_{\theta(t)} \leqslant \bar{\sigma} / t<1$.

The corollary below is a rather direct consequence of Theorem 3.1 and the closed form expression of the fixed point (2.12). A detailed proof is provided in Appendix F (on page 67).
Corollary 3.10. There exists some constant $c<\infty$ such that, for any $t>0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\mathbb{S}(\theta(t))-(\bar{m}, 0, \bar{\sigma})\| \vee\left\|r_{\theta(t)}-I\right\| & \leqslant c / t, \quad \text { and } \\
\left\|\overline{\mathbb{S}}\left(\theta_{1}(t)\right)-(m, 0, \sigma)\right\| \vee\left\|\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}(t)}-I\right\| & \leqslant c / t
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining (3.14) with the estimate (3.20), for any $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& e^{-\mathbb{U}_{\theta(t)}(x)} q_{\theta(t)}(x, y) e^{-\mathbb{V}_{\theta(t)}(y)}= \\
& e^{-U(x)} \frac{1}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}\left(2 \pi \varsigma_{\theta(t)}\right)}} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\varsigma_{\theta(t)}^{-1 / 2}\left((y-\bar{m})-\kappa_{\theta(t)}(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}\right) \xrightarrow{t \rightarrow \infty} e^{-U(x)} e^{-V(y)}
\end{aligned}
$$

i.e., the two marginal distributions become independent.

Similarly, with the regularized reference parameter $\theta(t)$, condition (3.15) takes the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{V}_{\theta(t)}(\bar{m})+\mathbb{U}_{\theta(t)}(m)+\frac{1}{2} \log \operatorname{det}(t I) \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \log \operatorname{det}(\sigma \bar{\sigma})-\frac{1}{2} \log \operatorname{det}\left(\varsigma_{\theta(t)}^{-1} \bar{\sigma}\right)-\frac{1}{2 t}\left\|m_{0}-\bar{m}\right\|_{F}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and using (3.11) and Theorem 3.7 we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \nabla^{2} \mathbb{V}_{\theta(t)}(y)=\bar{\sigma}^{-1}+\frac{1}{t}\left(\beta \sigma^{1 / 2} \frac{\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}(t)}}{t} \sigma^{1 / 2} \beta^{\prime}-I\right) \xrightarrow{t \rightarrow \infty} \bar{\sigma}^{-1}, \quad \text { and } \\
& \nabla^{2} \mathbb{U}_{\theta(t)}(x)=\sigma^{-1}+\frac{1}{t} \beta^{\prime}\left(\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \frac{r_{\theta(t)}}{t} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}-I\right) \beta \xrightarrow{t \rightarrow \infty} \sigma^{-1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, we can obtain some explicit regularization rates, as shown by the proposition below.

Proposition 3.11. There exists some constant $c_{0}$ and some $t_{0}$ such that for any $t \geqslant t_{0}$ we have the estimate

$$
\left\|2^{-1} \log \operatorname{det}(t I)+\mathbb{V}_{\theta(t)}(\bar{m})+\mathbb{U}_{\theta(t)}(m)-2^{-1} \log \operatorname{det}(\sigma \bar{\sigma})\right\| \leqslant c_{0} / t
$$

In addition, there exist some constants $c_{1}, c_{2}$ such that for any $t>0$ we have the estimates

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\mathbb{U}_{\theta(t)}(x+m)-\mathbb{U}_{\theta(t)}(m)-2^{-1} x^{\prime} \sigma^{-1} x\right\| \leqslant c_{1}\|x\|(1+\|x\|) / t, \quad \text { and } \\
& \left\|\mathbb{V}_{\theta(t)}(y+\bar{m})-\mathbb{V}_{\theta(t)}(\bar{m})-2^{-1} y^{\prime} \bar{\sigma}^{-1} y\right\| \leqslant c_{2}\|y\|(1+\|y\|) / t .
\end{aligned}
$$

The proof of Proposition 3.11 is provided in Appendix F (see page 68).
The estimates in (3.19) yield, for any $t \geqslant 1$, the rather crude lower bounds

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \nabla^{2} \mathbb{V}_{\theta(t)}(y) \geqslant \bar{\sigma}^{-1}+\frac{1}{t}\left(\beta \sigma^{1 / 2} \frac{\left(I+\varpi_{1}^{-1}\right)^{-1}}{t} \sigma^{1 / 2} \beta^{\prime}-I\right), \quad \text { and } \\
& \nabla^{2} \mathbb{U}_{\theta(t)}(x) \geqslant \sigma^{-1}+\frac{1}{t} \beta^{\prime}\left(\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \frac{\left(I+\varpi^{-1}\right)^{-1}}{t} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}-I\right) \beta
\end{aligned}
$$

which imply that there exists some $t_{0}$ sufficiently large such that for any $t \geqslant t_{0}$ both potentials are strongly convex. The parameter associated with the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck diffusion discussed in Remark 2.3 is given by

$$
\theta[t]=(0, \beta[t], \tau[t]) \quad \text { with } \quad \beta[t]=e^{t A} \quad \text { and } \quad \tau[t]:=\int_{0}^{t} e^{s A} \Sigma e^{s A^{\prime}} d s
$$

for some $\Sigma \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$and some Hurwitz matrix $A$. In this context, there exist some $c_{1}, c_{2}>0$ such that for any $t \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
\left\|\sigma_{\beta[t]}\right\|=\left\|e^{t A} \sigma e^{t A^{\prime}}\right\| \leqslant c_{1} e^{-c_{2} t}
$$

Thus, for any $t_{0}$ there exists some constant $c_{3, t_{0}}>0$ such that, for any $t \geqslant t_{0}>0$,

$$
\varpi_{\theta[t]}^{-1}=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \tau[t]^{-1} \sigma_{\beta[t]} \tau[t]^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \Longrightarrow\left\|\varpi_{\theta[t]}^{-1}\right\| \leqslant c_{3, t_{0}} e^{-c_{2} t}
$$

Using (2.12), this yields, for any $t \geqslant t_{0}>0$, the estimate

$$
\left\|r_{\theta[t]}-I\right\| \leqslant c_{3, t_{0}} e^{-c_{2} t} \quad \text { and, therefore, } \quad\left\|\varsigma_{\theta[t]}-\bar{\sigma}\right\| \vee\left\|\kappa_{\theta[t]}\right\| \leqslant c_{4, t_{0}} e^{-c_{2} t}
$$

for some constant $c_{4, t_{0}}>0$. As a consequence, for any $t \geqslant t_{0}>0$ we obtain the exponential decays

$$
\|\mathbb{S}(\theta[t])-(\bar{m}, 0, \bar{\sigma})\| \vee\left\|r_{\theta[t]}-I\right\| \leqslant c_{5, t_{0}} e^{-c_{2} t}
$$

for some constant $c_{5, t_{0}}>0$.

# 3.4.3 Monge maps 

Using (3.18) we find the identities

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \omega^{1 / 2} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} & =\sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \sharp \bar{\sigma}=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\left(\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}\right)^{1 / 2} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \\
& =\bar{\sigma} \sharp \sigma_{\beta}^{-1}=\sigma_{\beta}^{-1 / 2}\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{1 / 2} \bar{\sigma} \sigma_{\beta}^{1 / 2}\right)^{1 / 2} \sigma_{\beta}^{-1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and also note that

$$
\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \sharp \bar{\sigma}\right) \beta \sigma \beta^{\prime}\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \sharp \bar{\sigma}\right)=\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \sharp \bar{\sigma}\right) \sigma_{\beta}\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \sharp \bar{\sigma}\right)=\bar{\sigma}
$$

For any $t>0$, we also have the decompositions

$$
\frac{\varsigma_{\theta(t)}}{t}-\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \sharp \bar{\sigma}\right)=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\left(\frac{r_{\theta(t)}}{t}-\omega^{1 / 2}\right) \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}
$$

and

$$
\kappa_{\theta(t)}-\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \sharp \bar{\sigma}\right) \beta=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\left(\frac{r_{\theta(t)}}{t}-\omega^{1 / 2}\right) \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \beta
$$

On the other hand, using (3.18) we readily check that

$$
\frac{r_{\theta(t)}}{t}-\omega^{1 / 2}=\left(\omega+\left(\frac{t \omega}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}-\omega^{1 / 2}-\frac{t \omega}{2}
$$

and the Ando-Hemmen inequality (2.7) readily yields

$$
\left\|t^{-1} r_{\theta(t)}-\omega^{1 / 2}\right\|_{2} \leqslant \frac{t}{2}\|\omega\|_{2}+\frac{t^{2}}{\lambda_{\min }(\omega)^{1 / 2}}\left(\frac{\left\|\omega^{2}\right\|}{2}\right)
$$

and, therefore,

$$
\left\|t^{-1} r_{\theta(t)}\right\|_{2} \leqslant\left\|\omega^{1 / 2}\right\|_{2}+\frac{t}{2}\|\omega\|_{2}+\frac{t^{2}}{\lambda_{\min }(\omega)^{1 / 2}}\left(\frac{\left\|\omega^{2}\right\|}{2}\right)
$$

The above estimates readily imply the following regularization rates.
Corollary 3.12. There exists some constant $c<\infty$ such that for any $t \in[0,1]$ we have

$$
\left\|\kappa_{\theta(t)}-\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \sharp \bar{\sigma}\right) \beta\right\| \vee\left\|\varsigma_{\theta(t)} / t-\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \sharp \bar{\sigma}\right)\right\| \vee\left\|r_{\theta(t)} / t-\omega^{1 / 2}\right\| \leqslant c t
$$

Note that the limiting transport map from $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ to $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ is given by

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow 0} Z_{\mathbb{S}(\theta(t))}(x)=T_{\beta}(x):=\bar{m}+\left(\sigma_{\beta}^{-1} \sharp \bar{\sigma}\right) \beta(x-m)
$$

Theorem 3.13. For any $t>0$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& t H\left(P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta(t))} \mid P_{\theta(t)}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \mathbb{W}_{2}\left(\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}, \nu_{(\alpha+\beta m), \sigma_{\beta}}\right)^{2} \\
& =\operatorname{Tr}\left(\left(\left(\bar{\sigma} \sharp \sigma_{\beta}^{-1}\right)-\frac{\varsigma_{\theta(t)}}{t}\right) \sigma_{\beta}\right)+\frac{t}{2}\left(d \log (2 \pi)-\log \operatorname{det}\left(\frac{r_{\theta(t)}}{t}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In addition, there exists some constant $c<\infty$ and some $t_{0}$ such that for any $0<t \leqslant t_{0}$ we have

$$
\left|t H\left(P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta(t))} \mid P_{\theta(t)}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \mathbb{W}_{2}^{2}\left(\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}, \nu_{(\alpha+\beta m), \sigma_{\beta}}\right)\right| \leqslant c t
$$

with the rescaled relative entropy $H$ defined in (2.27).
The proof of Theorem 3.13 is provided in the Appendix C (on page 53). The proof of the latter estimate in Theorem 3.13 utilizes Corollary 3.12.

When $\beta=I$ we recover the well known Monge map $\mathcal{Y}_{I}$ between Gaussian distributions. In addition, when $(\alpha, \beta)=(0, I)$ we have

$$
T_{I}=\underset{T:\left(T \bullet \nu_{m, \sigma}\right)=\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}}{\arg \min } \mathbb{W}_{2}\left(\nu_{m, \sigma}, T \star \nu_{m, \sigma}\right)
$$

To the best of our knowledge, the formula and the non asymptotic estimates presented in Theorem 3.13 for general Gaussian models are new. A related result can be found in Theorem 1 in [44], which provides quantitative bounds on the rate of convergence of regularized optimal transport costs to standard optimal transport when the cost function $c(x, y)=-\log q(x, y)$ in (1.1) is Lipschitz and the measures $(\eta, \mu)$ have bounded support.

# 4 Sinkhorn algorithm 

Consider some probability measures $\eta$ and $\mu$ on $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ as well as some Markov transition $\mathcal{K}_{0}(x, d y)$ from $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ into itself such that $\eta \mathcal{K}_{0} \simeq \mu$. The Sinkhorn iterations are defined sequentially for any $n \geqslant 0$ by a collection of probability distributions

$$
\mathcal{P}_{2 n}=\eta \times \mathcal{K}_{2 n} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{P}_{2 n+1}=\left(\mu \times \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}\right)^{y}
$$

starting from $\mathcal{P}_{0}$ at rank $n=0$. For $n \geqslant 1$, the Markov transitions $\mathcal{K}_{n}$ in (4.1) are defined sequentially by the conditioning formulae

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left(\pi_{2 n} \times \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}\right)^{y}=\eta \times \mathcal{K}_{2 n} \quad \text { and } \quad \pi_{2 n+1} \times \mathcal{K}_{2(n+1)}=\left(\mu \times \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}\right)^{y} \\
\text { with the distributions } \quad \pi_{2 n}:=\eta \mathcal{K}_{2 n} \quad \text { and } \quad \pi_{2 n+1}:=\mu \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}
\end{array}\right.
$$

The equivalence between (1.4) and the formulae (4.2) is rather well known [57, 55]. For completeness, a sketch of a proof is provided in Appendix C (on page 51).

### 4.1 Gaussian Sinkhorn equations

For the linear Gaussian model where

$$
(\eta, \mu):=\left(\nu_{m, \sigma}, \nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{K}_{0}:=K_{\theta_{0}} \quad \text { with } \quad \theta_{0}=(\alpha, \beta, \tau) \in \Theta
$$

one readily obtains that

$$
\pi_{0}:=\nu_{m, \sigma} \mathcal{K}_{0}=\nu_{m_{0}, \sigma_{0}} \quad \text { with } \quad\left(m_{0}, \sigma_{0}\right):=h_{m, \sigma}\left(\theta_{0}\right)
$$

Then, by conjugacy arguments, we also have

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\pi_{n}=\nu_{m_{n}, \sigma_{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{K}_{n}=K_{\theta_{n}} \\
\text { for some parameters }\left(m_{n}, \sigma_{n}\right) \in\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \theta_{n}=\left(\alpha_{n}, \beta_{n}, \tau_{n}\right) \in \Theta
\end{array}\right.
$$

To identify the parameters $\theta_{n}$, first we use (4.2) to verify that

$$
\left(m_{2 n}, \sigma_{2 n}\right)=h_{m, \sigma}\left(\theta_{2 n}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad\left(m_{2 n+1}, \sigma_{2 n+1}\right)=h_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}\left(\theta_{2 n+1}\right)
$$

with the functions $h_{m, \sigma}$ and $h_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ defined in (2.15). In terms of the probability measures $P_{\theta}$ and $\bar{P}_{\theta}$ defined in (2.15), the conjugate formula (2.17) applied to (4.2) also shows that

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\mathcal{P}_{2 n}=P_{\theta_{2 n}} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{P}_{2 n+1}=\bar{P}_{\theta_{2 n+1}}^{y} \\
\text { with } \quad \theta_{2 n+1}=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}\left(\theta_{2 n}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \theta_{2(n+1)}=\mathbb{B}_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}\left(\theta_{2 n+1}\right)
\end{array}\right.
$$

and the Bayes' maps $\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}$ and $\mathbb{B}_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ defined in (2.16). This yields for any $n \geqslant 0$ the mean values

$$
m_{2 n+1}=m+\beta_{2 n+1}\left(\bar{m}-m_{2 n}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad m_{2(n+1)}=\bar{m}+\beta_{2(n+1)}\left(m-m_{2 n+1}\right)
$$

which are easily found using the conjugate random map (2.18) and (4.2). A more detailed description of these parameters and the corresponding random maps is provided in Appendix D, on page 54 (see for instance (D.2) and (D.5) as well as (D.3) and (D.6)).

The correction matrices $\beta_{n}$ are called gain matrices, in analogy to Kalman filtering theory. They allow to adjust the mean values of the target marginal measures. As in the Kalman filter, they are also used to sequentially adjust the covariances.

# 4.2 Riccati difference equations 

Next technical lemma is pivotal: it provides a complete description of the gain matrices in terms of the reference parameter $\theta_{0}=(\alpha, \beta, \tau)$ and the flow of covariance matrices $\tau_{n}$.

Lemma 4.1. For any $n \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
\beta_{2 n}=\tau_{2 n} \tau^{-1} \beta \quad \text { and } \quad \beta_{2 n+1}=\tau_{2 n+1} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}
$$

The proof of Lemma 4.1 is rather technical; it is provided in Appendix D, on page 56. Lemma 4.1 shows that the analysis of Sinkhorn algorithm reduces to that of the flow of covariance matrices $\tau_{n}$.

The Bayes' map recursions in (4.6) show that formulae involving the ordered sequence $\left(\theta_{n}\right)_{n \geqslant 0}$ coincide with formulae involving the ordered sequence $\left(\theta_{n}\right)_{n \geqslant 1}$ by changing $(m, \sigma)$ by $(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma})$ (and the initial parameters $\theta_{0}$ by $\theta_{1}$ ).

Our next objective is to show that the flow of covariance matrices $\tau_{n}$ can be computed offline by solving a time-homogeneous Riccati equation. To this end, we first introduce a sequence of suitably rescaled matrices.

Definition 4.2. Let $v_{n}$ be the rescaled covariance matrices defined for any $n \geqslant 0$ by

$$
v_{2 n}:=\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \tau_{2 n} \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \quad v_{2 n+1}:=\sigma^{-1 / 2} \tau_{2 n+1} \sigma^{-1 / 2}
$$

The theorem below is the second key result in this paper. It yields an offline description of the flow of covariance matrices of the Sinkhorn algorithm in terms of the dual Riccati maps $\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi_{\theta}}$ and $\operatorname{Ricc}_{\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}}$ defined in (2.11), with the positive-definite matrices $\left(\varpi_{\theta}, \bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}\right)$ defined in (3.1) and (3.8), respectively.

Theorem 4.3. For any $n \geqslant 0$, we have the recursions

$$
v_{2(n+1)}^{-1}=I+\gamma_{\theta} v_{2 n+1} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \quad \text { and } \quad v_{2 n+1}^{-1}=I+\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} v_{2 n} \gamma_{\theta}
$$

together with the matrix Riccati difference equations

$$
v_{2(n+1)}=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi_{\theta}}\left(v_{2 n}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad v_{2 n+1}=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}}\left(v_{2 n-1}\right)
$$

The proof of Theorem 4.3 is provided in Appendix B on page 50.
