Remark 4.4. Following Remark 3.5, the matrix difference equations (4.11) coincide for one-dimensional models. In this context, Lemma 4.3 in [36] provides closed-form solutions of Riccati difference equations. For instance, for even indices we find the equation

$$
\left(v_{2 n}-r_{\theta}\right)=\left(v_{0}-r_{\theta}\right) \frac{\left(\varpi_{\theta}+2 r_{\theta}\right) \rho_{\theta}^{n}}{\left(v_{0}+\varpi_{\theta}+r_{\theta}\right)\left(1-\rho_{\theta}^{n}\right)+\left(\varpi_{\theta}+2 r_{\theta}\right) \rho_{\theta}^{n}}
$$

with the positive fixed point $r_{\theta}$ defined in (3.2) and the exponential decay parameter

$$
\rho_{\theta}:=\left(1+r_{\theta}+\varpi_{\theta}\right)^{-2}<1
$$

The monotone properties of Riccati maps (see for instance (B.2) in Appendix B) yield the following estimates for the covariance matrices $\tau_{n}$ and $\sigma_{n}$, and the gain matrices $\beta_{n}$.

Corollary 4.5. For any $n \geqslant 1$ we have the uniform estimates

$$
\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\left(I+\varpi_{\theta}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \leqslant \tau_{2 n} \leqslant \bar{\sigma} \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma^{1 / 2}\left(I+\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \sigma^{1 / 2} \leqslant \tau_{2 n+1} \leqslant \sigma
$$

In addition, we have

$$
\left\|\beta_{2 n}\right\|_{2} \leqslant\|\bar{\sigma}\|_{2}\left\|\tau^{-1} \beta\right\|_{2} \quad \text { and } \quad\left\|\beta_{2 n+1}\right\|_{2} \leqslant\|\sigma\|_{2}\left\|\tau^{-1} \beta\right\|_{2}
$$

as well as

$$
\sigma_{2 n} \geqslant \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\left(I+\varpi_{\theta}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{2 n+1} \geqslant \sigma^{1 / 2}\left(I+\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \sigma^{1 / 2}
$$

The last assertion in Corollary 4.5 comes from the fact that

$$
\sigma_{2 n} \geqslant \tau_{2 n} \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{2 n+1} \geqslant \tau_{2 n+1}
$$

Remark 4.6. Following Remark 3.9, when $\lambda_{\min }(\tau)$ is sufficiently large or when $\|\beta\|_{2}$ is sufficiently small the gain matrices $\beta_{n}$ are stable. For instance,

$$
\left\|\tau^{-1}\right\|_{2}\|\beta\|_{2}<\|\sigma\|_{2}^{-1} \wedge\|\bar{\sigma}\|_{2}^{-1} \quad \text { implies } \quad \sup _{n \geqslant 1}\left\|\beta_{n}\right\|_{2}<1
$$

Nevertheless, for one dimensional models with $\beta=1$, we have $\omega^{-1}:=\bar{\sigma} \sigma$ and by Corollary 4.5 we obtain

$$
\beta_{2 n}=\frac{\tau_{2 n}}{t} \geqslant \frac{\bar{\sigma}}{t}\left(1+\frac{\bar{\sigma}}{t} \frac{\sigma}{t}\right)^{-1}
$$

Choosing $\bar{\sigma}$ sufficiently large, we have

$$
\frac{\bar{\sigma}}{t}\left(1-\frac{\sigma}{t}\right)>1 \quad \text { which implies that } \quad \beta_{2 n}>1
$$

A more detailed discussion on these inequalities is provided in Appendix D (see (D.1) and (D.4)). More refined estimates can be obtained using the monotone properties of Riccati maps. For instance, using (B.4) we easily check the following result.

Proposition 4.7. For any $n \geqslant 2$ we have the uniform estimates

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\sigma}^{-1}+\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}\left(\varpi_{\theta}+I\right)^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} & \leqslant \tau_{2 n}^{-1} \leqslant \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}\left(I+\varpi_{\theta}^{-1}\right) \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \\
\sigma^{-1}+\sigma^{-1 / 2}\left(\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}+I\right)^{-1} \sigma^{-1 / 2} & \leqslant \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1} \leqslant \sigma^{-1 / 2}\left(I+\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}\right) \sigma^{-1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

# 4.3 A Gibbs loop process 

For any $n \geqslant 0$ we have the reversibility properties

$$
\begin{aligned}
\eta \times \mathcal{K}_{2 n} \times \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1} & =\left(\eta \times \mathcal{K}_{2 n} \times \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}\right)^{\mathrm{b}} \\
\mu \times \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1} \times \mathcal{K}_{2(n+1)} & =\left(\mu \times \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1} \times \mathcal{K}_{2(n+1)}\right)^{\mathrm{b}}
\end{aligned}
$$

which, in turn, yield the fixed-point equations

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\eta \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}^{\circ} & =\eta \\
\mu \mathcal{K}_{2(n+1)}^{\circ} & =\mu
\end{aligned}\right\} \quad \text { with } \quad \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}^{\circ}:=\mathcal{K}_{2 n} \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{K}_{2(n+1)}^{\circ}:=\mathcal{K}_{2 n+1} \mathcal{K}_{2(n+1)}
$$

The kernels $\mathcal{K}_{n}^{\circ}$ can be used to construct, for $n \geqslant 1$, the Markov evolutions

$$
\pi_{2 n}=\pi_{2(n-1)} \mathcal{K}_{2 n}^{\circ} \quad \text { and } \quad \pi_{2 n+1}=\pi_{2 n-1} \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}^{\circ}
$$

The properties of the random maps associated with the Gibbs-type transitions $\mathcal{K}_{n}^{\circ}$ are discussed in Appendix D.

The Markov evolution equations in (4.14) ensure the decreasing properties of the relative entropies $[32]$,

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mu \mid \pi_{2 n}\right)=\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mu \mathcal{K}_{2 n}^{\circ} \mid \pi_{2(n-1)} \mathcal{K}_{2 n}^{\circ}\right) \leqslant \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mu \mid \pi_{2(n-1)}\right)
$$

and, in the same vein,

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 n+1}\right) \leqslant \operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 n-1}\right)
$$

On the other hand, using (4.2) for any $p<q$ we readily see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \mathcal{P}_{2 q}}{d \mathcal{P}_{2 p}}(x, y) & =\left[\prod_{p \leqslant l<q} \frac{d \mathcal{P}_{2 l+1}}{d \mathcal{P}_{2 l}}(x, y)\right]\left[\prod_{p \leqslant l<q} \frac{d \mathcal{P}_{2(l+1)}}{d \mathcal{P}_{2 l+1}}(x, y)\right] \\
& =\left[\prod_{p \leqslant l<q} \frac{d \mu}{d \pi_{2 l}}(y)\right]\left[\prod_{p \leqslant l<q} \frac{d \eta}{d \pi_{2 l+1}}(x)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, for any given $\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)$ and $q>p$ we have the decomposition

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 p}\right) & \geqslant \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 p}\right)-\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 q}\right) \\
& =\mathcal{P}\left(\log \frac{d \mathcal{P}_{2 q}}{d \mathcal{P}_{2 p}}\right)=\sum_{p \leqslant l<q}\left(\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mu \mid \pi_{2 l}\right)+\operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 l+1}\right)\right) \\
& \geqslant(q-p)\left(\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mu \mid \pi_{2(q-1)}\right)+\operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 q-1}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and choosing $p=0$ in (4.15) yields the following theorem.
Theorem 4.8. Assume there exists some $\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)$ such that $\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{0}\right)<\infty$. Then, for any $n \geqslant 1$ we have

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mu \mid \pi_{2 n}\right) \vee \operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 n+1}\right) \leqslant \frac{1}{n} \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{0}\right)
$$

and, in addition,

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} n \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mu \mid \pi_{2 n}\right)=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} n \operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 n+1}\right)=0
$$

The last assertion is a direct consequence of the convergence of the series (4.15). For instance, for any $\epsilon>0$ there exists some $n_{\epsilon} \geqslant 1$ such that for every $n \geqslant n_{\epsilon}$ we have

$$
n \operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 n+1}\right) \leqslant \sum_{n \leqslant p \leqslant 2 n} \operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 p+1}\right) \leqslant \epsilon
$$

Also by (4.15), for any $p<q$ and $\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)$ we have the monotone properties

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 q}\right) & =\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 p}\right)-\sum_{p \leqslant l<q}\left(\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mu \mid \pi_{2 l}\right)+\operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 l+1}\right)\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 q-1}\right)-\operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 q-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The above formulae are not new, they are sometimes called the Pythagorean law for the relative entropy $[26,58]$ (see also Proposition 6.5 in [55]). They show that the sequence $\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{n}\right)$ is decreasing and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{n}\right) & =\inf _{n \geqslant 0} \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{n}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{0}\right)-\sum_{p \geqslant 0}\left(\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mu \mid \pi_{2 p}\right)+\operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 p+1}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Sublinear rates have been developed in the articles [3, 16, 39]. In the context of finite state spaces, the above linear rates can be deduced from the exponential rates presented in the pioneering article by Fienberg [40] using Hilbert projective metrics, further developed by Franklin and Lorenz in [41]. The extension of these Hilbert projective techniques to general compact space models are developed in [19]. Linear rates with the robust constant $\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{0}\right)$ and $\pi$ solving the minimum entropy problem on non-necessarily compact spaces were first obtained by Léger in [52] using elegant gradient descent and Bregman divergence techniques, see also the recent articles [29, 48]. A refined convergence rate at least one order faster has also been developed in [45].

For Gaussian models of the form in (4.5), the mean and covariance parameters of the Gaussian distributions $\pi_{n}=\nu_{m_{n}, \sigma_{n}}$ are computed sequentially. By (4.7), for any $n \geqslant 1$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
m_{2 n}-\bar{m} & =\beta_{2 n}^{\circ}\left(m_{2(n-1)}-\bar{m}\right) & \text { with } \beta_{2 n}^{\circ}:=\beta_{2 n} \beta_{2 n-1}, \quad \text { and } \\
m_{2 n+1}-m & =\beta_{2 n+1}^{\circ}\left(m_{2 n-1}-m\right) & \text { with } \beta_{2 n+1}^{\circ}:=\beta_{2 n+1} \beta_{2 n}
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider the directed matrix products

$$
\beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}:=\beta_{2 n}^{\circ} \beta_{2(n-1)}^{\circ} \ldots \beta_{2}^{\circ} \quad \text { and } \quad \beta_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ}:=\beta_{2 n+1}^{\circ} \beta_{2 n-1}^{\circ} \ldots \beta_{3}^{\circ}
$$

In this notation, we have

$$
\sigma_{2 n}-\bar{\sigma}=\beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}\left(\sigma_{0}-\bar{\sigma}\right)\left(\beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}\right)^{\prime} \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{2 n+1}-\sigma=\beta_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ}\left(\sigma_{1}-\sigma\right)\left(\beta_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ}\right)^{\prime}
$$

The proof of the above covariance formulae is provided in Appendix D (on page 57).
We finish this section with a technical lemma that is key to the construction of quantitative estimates in Section 5. It yields a description of the gain matrices $\beta_{n}^{\circ}$ of the Gibbs-loop process in terms of matrix Riccati difference equations (4.11).

Lemma 4.9. For any $n \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \beta_{2(n+1)}^{\circ} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} & =\bar{\gamma}_{\theta_{1}}^{\prime}\left(\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}+v_{2 n+1}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \bar{\gamma}_{\theta_{1}}=I-v_{2(n+1)} \quad \text { and } \\
\sigma^{-1 / 2} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\circ} \sigma^{1 / 2} & =\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\left(\varpi_{\theta}^{-1}+v_{2 n}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \gamma_{\theta}=I-v_{2 n+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

with the matrices $\left(\varpi_{\theta}, \gamma_{\theta}\right)$ and $\left(\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}, \bar{\gamma}_{\theta_{1}}\right)$ defined in (3.1) and (3.8).
The proof is provided in Appendix D, on page 58.

# 5 Quantitative estimates
### 5.1 An exponential stability theorem

The exponential stability properties of the matrix Riccati difference equations in (4.11) are well understood. For instance, the Ando-Hemmen inequality (2.7) and the stability estimates stated in Proposition B. 6 readily yield the following estimates.

Theorem 5.1. There exists some $c_{\theta}<\infty$ such that for any $n \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
\left\|\tau_{2 n}-\varsigma_{\theta}\right\| \vee\left\|\tau_{2 n}^{1 / 2}-\varsigma_{\theta}^{1 / 2}\right\| \vee\left\|\beta_{2 n}-\kappa_{\theta}\right\| \leqslant c_{\theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n}\left\|\tau_{0}-\varsigma_{\theta}\right\|
$$

with the parameter

$$
\rho_{\theta}:=\left(1+\lambda_{\min }\left(r_{\theta}+\varpi_{\theta}\right)\right)^{-2}<1
$$

The recursions in Theorem 4.3 (see the formulae in expression (4.10)) also show that the fixed point matrices $\left(r_{\theta}, \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}\right)$ and their rescaled versions defined in (3.3) and (3.7) are connected by the formulae

$$
\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1}=\bar{\sigma}^{-1}+\chi_{\theta} \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}} \chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta} \chi_{\theta}
$$

with the parameter $\chi_{\theta}$ defined in (3.1).
Lemma 4.9 expresses the matrices $\beta_{n}^{\circ}$ in terms of $v_{n}$. The stability properties of these Riccati matrices are discussed in Appendix B (see for instance (B.6) as well as (B.12) and Theorem B.4). There exists some $c_{\theta}<\infty$ such that for any $n \geqslant 1$ we have the inequality

$$
\left\|\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\right\| \leqslant c_{\theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n / 2}
$$

which is a consequence of Lemma 4.9. A detailed proof is provided in Appendix D (see page 58 ).
Remark 5.2. In contrast with the possible instability properties of the gain matrices $\beta_{2 n}$ discussed in Remark 4.6, the matrix product semigroup $\beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}$ is stable for any values of the parameters $(\tau, \beta)$. For instance, the exponential decay estimates (5.3) apply to the linear diffusions discussed in Remark 2.3 for non necessarily stable drift matrices $A_{t}$.
Remark 5.3. Matrices $\left(\tau_{2 n+1}, \beta_{2 n+1}\right)$ as well as $\sigma^{-1 / 2} \beta_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ} \sigma^{1 / 2}$ satisfy the same inequalities as in Theorem 5.1 and in expression (5.3) for some parameter $\bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}$. These inequalities (and the parameter $\bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}$ ) are defined as above by replacing the parameters $\left(\varsigma_{\theta}, \kappa_{\theta}, r_{\theta}, \varpi_{\theta}\right)$ by $\left(\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}, \bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}, \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}, \varpi_{\theta_{1}}\right)$. For instance, we have

$$
\bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}:=\left(1+\lambda_{\min }\left(\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}+\varpi_{\theta_{1}}\right)\right)^{-2}<1 \quad \text { with }\left(\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}, \varpi_{\theta_{1}}\right) \text { defined in (3.8) and (3.9) }
$$

This yields the following corollary.
Corollary 5.4. There exists some $c_{\theta}<\infty$ such that for any $n \geqslant 1$ we have the exponential estimates

$$
\left\|m_{2 n}-\bar{m}\right\| \leqslant c_{\theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n / 2}\left\|m_{0}-\bar{m}\right\| \quad \text { and } \quad\left\|\sigma_{2 n}-\bar{\sigma}\right\| \leqslant c_{\theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n}\left\|\sigma_{0}-\bar{\sigma}\right\|
$$

Parameters $\left(m_{2 n-1}, \sigma_{2 n-1}\right)$ with odd indices satisfy the same inequalities as above by replacing $\left(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}, \rho_{\theta}\right)$ by $\left(m, \sigma, \bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}\right)$ and the initial parameters $\left(m_{0}, \sigma_{0}\right)$ by $\left(m_{1}, \sigma_{1}\right)$.

Remark 5.5. Using the Gaussian entropy formula (2.9) and the estimates stated in Corollary 4.5 and Lemma C. 1 there exists some $n_{0} \geqslant 1$ and some constant $c_{\theta}>0$ such that for any $n \geqslant n_{0}$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Ent}\left(\nu_{\bar{n} \bar{\sigma}} \mid \nu_{m_{2 n}, \sigma_{2 n}}\right) \vee \operatorname{Ent}\left(\nu_{m_{2 n}, \sigma_{2 n}} \mid \nu_{\bar{n} \bar{\sigma}}\right) \leqslant c_{\theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n} \quad \text { and } \\
& \operatorname{Ent}\left(\nu_{m, \sigma} \mid \nu_{m_{2 n+1}, \sigma_{2 n+1}}\right) \vee \operatorname{Ent}\left(\nu_{m_{2 n+1}, \sigma_{2 n+1}} \mid \nu_{m, \sigma}\right) \leqslant c_{\theta} \bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying Corollary 4.5 and Theorem 5.1, there exists some $c_{\theta}$ such that, for any $n \geqslant 1$, the equality

$$
\alpha_{2 n}-\iota_{\theta}=\left(\kappa_{\theta}-\beta_{2 n}\right) m+\beta_{2 n}\left(m-m_{2 n-1}\right)
$$

implies that

$$
\left\|\alpha_{2 n}-\iota_{\theta}\right\| \leqslant c_{\theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n}\left\|\tau_{0}-\varsigma_{\theta}\right\|+c_{\theta} \bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n / 2}\left\|m_{0}-\bar{m}\right\|
$$

Combining the above estimates with Theorem 5.1 we readily obtain the following result.
Corollary 5.6. There exists some $c_{\theta}$ and $c_{1, \theta}<\infty$ such that for any $n \geqslant 1$ we have the exponential estimates

$$
\left\|\theta_{2 n}-\mathbb{S}(\theta)\right\| \leqslant c_{\theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n}\left\|\tau_{0}-\varsigma_{\theta}\right\|+c_{1, \theta} \bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n / 2}\left\|m_{0}-\bar{m}\right\|
$$

where $\mathbb{S}$ stands for the Schrödinger bridge map defined in (3.3).

# 5.2 Relative entropy estimates 

Theorem 5.1 and the estimates stated in Corollary 5.4 can be used to derive a variety of quantitative estimates. For instance, we have the relative entropy formula

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(P_{\theta_{2 n}} \mid P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}\right)=\frac{1}{2} D\left(\tau_{2 n} \mid \varsigma_{\theta}\right)+\left\|\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1 / 2}\left(m_{2 n}-\bar{m}\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left\|\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1 / 2}\left(\beta_{2 n}-\kappa_{\theta}\right) \sigma^{1 / 2}\right\|_{F}^{2}
$$

with the Burg distance $D$ defined in (2.10) and the Schrödinger bridge map $\mathbb{S}$ defined in (3.3). The above formula is a direct consequence of (2.25). A detailed proof is provided in Appendix C (on page 53).

Choose $n_{0} \geqslant 1$ such that

$$
\rho_{\theta}^{n_{0}}\left\|\tau_{0}-\varsigma_{\theta}\right\|_{F} \leqslant 1 \wedge \frac{1}{2 c_{\theta}\left\|\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1}\right\|_{F}}
$$

where the constant $c_{\theta}$ and the parameter $\rho_{\theta}$ are the same as in Theorem 5.1. The following estimates can be readily obtained.

Corollary 5.7. There exists some finite $c_{\theta}<\infty$ such that for any $n \geqslant n_{0}$ we have the entropy estimates

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(P_{\theta_{2 n}} \mid P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}\right) \leqslant c_{\theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n}\left(\left\|\tau_{0}-\varsigma_{\theta}\right\|+\left\|m_{0}-\bar{m}\right\|^{2}\right)
$$

Applying Pinsker's inequality we also easily deduce the total variation estimate

$$
\left\|P_{\theta_{2 n}}-P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}\right\|_{\mathrm{tv}} \leqslant c_{\theta}^{1 / 2} \rho_{\theta}^{n / 2}\left(\left\|\tau_{0}-\varsigma_{\theta}\right\|^{1 / 2}+\left\|m_{0}-\bar{m}\right\|\right)
$$

In terms of the random maps (2.14) and (3.5) we have

$$
Z_{\theta_{2 n}}(x)-Z_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}(x)=\left(m_{2 n}-\bar{m}\right)+\left(\beta_{2 n}-\kappa_{\theta}\right)(x-m)+\left(\tau_{2 n}^{1 / 2}-\varsigma_{\theta}^{1 / 2}\right) G
$$

which yields, for any $p \geqslant 1$, the Wasserstein distance estimate

$$
\mathbb{W}_{p}\left(P_{\theta_{2 n}}, P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}\right) \leqslant\left(\left\|m_{2 n}-\bar{m}\right\|_{F}+e_{d}(p)\left\|\sigma^{1 / 2}\right\|_{F}\left\|\beta_{2 n}-\kappa_{\theta}\right\|_{F}\right)+e_{d}(p)\left\|\tau_{2 n}^{1 / 2}-\varsigma_{\theta}^{1 / 2}\right\|_{F}
$$

with the parameter

$$
e_{d}(p):=\mathbb{E}\left(\|G\|_{F}^{p}\right)^{1 / p}
$$

Applying Theorem 5.1 and Corollary 5.4 to the Frobenius norm, we readily prove the following estimates.

Corollary 5.8. For any $p \geqslant 1$ there exists some finite $c_{1, \theta}(p), c_{2, \theta}<\infty$ such that for any $n \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
\mathbb{W}_{p}\left(P_{\theta_{2 n}}, P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}\right) \leqslant c_{1, \theta}(p) \rho_{\theta}^{n}\left\|\tau_{0}-\varsigma_{\theta}\right\|_{F}+c_{2, \theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n / 2}\left\|m_{0}-\bar{m}\right\|_{F}
$$

Exactly the same analysis can be applied to the random transport maps, to arrive at the equation

$$
Z_{\theta_{2 n+1}}(y)-Z_{\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{1}\right)}(y)=\left(m_{2 n+1}-m\right)+\left(\beta_{2 n+1}-\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}\right)(y-\bar{m})+\left(\tau_{2 n+1}^{1 / 2}-\varsigma_{\theta_{1}}^{1 / 2}\right) G
$$

with the function $\overline{\mathbb{S}}$ defined in (2.29).

# 5.3 Regularization effects 

Denote by $v_{n}(t)$ the solution of the matrix Riccati difference equations (4.11) associated with the parameter $\theta(t)$ defined in (3.17). In this case, we have

$$
v_{0}(t)=t \bar{\sigma}^{-1} \quad \text { and } \quad \tau_{0}(t)=t I
$$

Let $\theta_{n}(t)=\left(\alpha_{n}(t), \beta_{n}(t), \tau_{n}(t)\right)$ be the flow of Sinkhorn parameters associated with the initial parameter $\theta_{0}=\theta(t)$. In this notation, for any $n \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
\tau_{2 n}(t):=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} v_{2 n}(t) \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \quad \tau_{2 n+1}(t):=\sigma^{1 / 2} v_{2 n+1}(t) \sigma^{1 / 2}
$$

Combining (3.18) with Proposition 4.7 for any $n \geqslant 2$ we readily obtain the estimates

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\sigma}^{-1}+\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}\left(t^{2} \omega+I\right)^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} & \leqslant \tau_{2 n}(t)^{-1} \leqslant \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}\left(I+t^{-2} \omega^{-1}\right) \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \\
\sigma^{-1}+\sigma^{-1 / 2}\left(t^{2} \omega_{1}+I\right)^{-1} \sigma^{-1 / 2} & \leqslant \tau_{2 n+1}(t)^{-1} \leqslant \sigma^{-1 / 2}\left(I+t^{-2} \omega_{1}^{-1}\right) \sigma^{-1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

with the matrices $\left(\omega, \omega_{1}\right)$ defined in (3.18).
Equivalently, following (B.5) in Lemma B. 1 we also have the following result.

Proposition 5.9. For any $t \geqslant 0$ and $n \geqslant 2$ we have the uniform estimates

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\left(I+\left(t^{2} \omega+I\right)\right)^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} & \leqslant \bar{\sigma}-\tau_{2 n}(t) \leqslant \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\left(I+t^{2} \omega\right)^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \\
\sigma^{1 / 2}\left(I+\left(t^{2} \omega_{1}+I\right)\right)^{-1} \sigma^{1 / 2} & \leqslant \sigma-\tau_{2 n+1}(t) \leqslant \sigma^{1 / 2}\left(I+t^{2} \omega_{1}\right)^{-1} \sigma^{1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

This shows that the flow of covariance matrices $\left(\tau_{2 n}(t), \tau_{2 n+1}(t)\right)$ converges towards $(\bar{\sigma}, \sigma)$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$ uniformly w.r.t. the parameter $n \geqslant 0$.

Combining (4.8) with Proposition 5.9 we also see that

$$
\left\|\beta_{2 n}(t)\right\| \leqslant \frac{1}{t}\|\beta\|\|\bar{\sigma}\| \quad \text { and } \quad\left\|\beta_{2 n+1}(t)\right\| \leqslant \frac{1}{t}\|\beta\|\|\sigma\|
$$

In this context, we also have

$$
t \omega^{1 / 2} \leqslant r_{\theta(t)}+\varpi_{\theta(t)}=t\left(\frac{t \omega}{2}+\left(\omega+\left(\frac{t \omega}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}\right)
$$

As expected from (5.1), $\rho_{\theta(t)} \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$, while $\rho_{\theta(t)} \rightarrow 1$ as $t \rightarrow 0$. We also have the exponential estimate

$$
\rho_{\theta(t)} \leqslant\left(1+t \lambda_{\min }(\omega)^{1 / 2}\right)^{-2} \leqslant \exp \left(-2 t \lambda_{\min }(\omega)^{1 / 2}\right)
$$

The estimation constant $c_{\theta(t)}$ in Theorem 5.1 can be estimated using Propositions B. 5 and B. 6 in Appendix B (see Eqs. (B.13) and (B.15), respectively). We also note that in the case $\beta=I$ we readily have

$$
r_{\theta(t)}+\varpi_{\theta(t)}=t\left(\frac{t \omega}{2}+\left(\omega+\left(\frac{t \omega}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}\right)
$$

where $\omega:=\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \sigma^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}$, and the identity (5.5) yields the lower bound

$$
r_{\theta(t)}+\varpi_{\theta(t)}>t\left(\sigma^{-1 / 2} \bar{\sigma}^{-1} \sigma^{-1 / 2}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

and, in turn, the (simpler) estimate

$$
\rho_{\theta(t)}=\left(1+\lambda_{\min }\left(r_{\theta(t)}+\varpi_{\theta(t)}\right)\right)^{-2}<\left(1+t \lambda_{\min }\left(\sigma^{-1 / 2} \bar{\sigma}^{-1} \sigma^{-1 / 2}\right)^{1 / 2}\right)^{-2}
$$

Remark 5.10. In the special case of one-dimensional Gaussian models, the r.h.s. estimate in (5.6) is the square of the entropy exponential decay rate presented in Proposition 1.3, part (i), of Ref. [21] for general log-concave marginal models and sufficiently small values of $t$. As shown above, we also have $\rho_{\theta(t)} \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$. When applied to Gaussian models, for large values of $t$, the estimate (i) stated in Theorem 1.2 of Ref. [21] also yields an entropy exponential decay rate of $1 / 2$.

# 6 Schrödinger potential functions
### 6.1 Integral recursive formulations

The iterative proportional fitting procedure can be defined in terms of Schrödinger potential functions as long as $\eta$ and $\mu$ are defined by some Gibbs measures, namely,

$$
\eta(d x)=e^{-U(x)} d x \quad \text { and } \quad \mu(d y)=e^{-V(y)} d y
$$

for some potential functions $U$ and $V$ on $\mathbb{R}^{d}$. We also assume that the Markov transition $\mathcal{K}_{0}(x, d y)$ is defined by a positive operator $Q(x, d y)$ with density $q(x, y)$, in the sense that

$$
\mathcal{K}_{0}(x, d y)=Q(x, d y):=q(x, y) d y
$$

and we set

$$
R(y, d x):=r(y, x) d x \quad \text { with } \quad q(x, y)=r(y, x)
$$

These conditions are clearly met for the Gaussian model (4.3) with

$$
\begin{aligned}
q(x, y) & =r(y, x)=g_{r}(y-(\alpha+\beta x)) \quad \text { and } \\
U(x) & =-\log g_{\sigma}(x-m) \quad \text { and } \quad V(y):=-\log g_{\bar{\sigma}}(y-\bar{m})
\end{aligned}
$$

Proposition 6.1. For every $n \geqslant 0$ we have the distributions $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ described in (1.5) with the initial potential functions $\left(U_{0}, V_{0}\right)=(U, 0)$ and the recursions

$$
\begin{aligned}
U_{2 n+1} & =U_{2 n}:=U+\log Q\left(e^{-V_{2 n}}\right), \text { and } \\
V_{2(n+1)} & =V_{2 n+1}:=V+\log R\left(e^{-U_{2 n+1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Equivalently, we have

$$
\mathcal{K}_{2 n}(x, d y)=\frac{Q(x, d y) e^{-V_{2 n}(y)}}{Q\left(e^{-V_{2 n}}\right)(x)} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}(y, d x)=\frac{R(y, d x) e^{-U_{2 n+1}(x)}}{R\left(e^{-U_{2 n+1}}\right)(y)}
$$

The above proposition is rather well known. For completeness, we provide a detailed proof in Appendix E (see page 60).

In the literature, Schrödinger potential functions are sometimes written in terms of the functions

$$
\mathcal{U}_{n}=U_{n}-U \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{V}_{n}=V_{n}-V
$$

and the integral operators

$$
\mathcal{Q}(x, d y):=q(x, y) \mu(d y) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{R}(y, d x):=r(y, x) \eta(d x)
$$

In this context, the recursive formulae stated in Proposition 6.1 take the form

$$
\mathcal{U}_{2 n+1}=\mathcal{U}_{2 n}=\log \mathcal{Q}\left(e^{-\mathcal{V}_{2 n}}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{V}_{2(n+1)}=\mathcal{V}_{2 n+1}=\log \mathcal{R}\left(e^{-\mathcal{U}_{2 n+1}}\right)
$$

Remark 6.2. In terms of the potential functions $\left(\mathcal{U}_{n}, \mathcal{V}_{n}\right)$, the probability measures in (1.5) can be rewritten as

$$
\mathcal{P}_{n}(d(x, y))=e^{-\left(\mathcal{U}_{n}(x)+\mathcal{V}_{n}(y)\right)} \mathcal{O}(d(x, y))
$$

with $\left(\mathcal{U}_{0}, \mathcal{V}_{0}\right)=(0,-V)$ and the reference bounded measure

$$
\mathcal{O}(d(x, y)):=q(x, y)(\eta \otimes \mu)(d(x, y))=e^{-V(y)} \mathcal{P}_{0}(d(x, y))
$$

For any $\mathcal{P} \ll \mathcal{O}$, we have

$$
\operatorname{Ent}(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{O})=-\int \log q(x, y) \mathcal{P}(d(x, y))+\operatorname{Ent}(\mathcal{P} \mid \eta \otimes \mu)
$$

In this case, the entropic transport problem with reference measure $\mathcal{O}$ consists in finding $\mathcal{P} \in \mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)$ with minimal entropy $\operatorname{Ent}(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{O})$. For the Gaussian model (6.1), in terms of the parameter $\theta=(\alpha, \beta, \tau)$, we have

$$
\mathcal{O}(d(x, y))=e^{-V(y)} P_{\theta}(d(x, y))
$$

Choosing $\mathcal{P}=P_{\theta_{1}} \in \mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)$ yields

$$
\int V(y) P_{\theta_{1}}(d(x, y))=\mu(V)
$$

and we obtain

$$
\operatorname{Ent}(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{O})=\mu(V)+\operatorname{Ent}\left(P_{\theta_{1}} \mid P_{\theta}\right)
$$

This shows that the entropic transport problem is equivalent to the (static) Schrödinger bridge with reference measure $P_{\theta}$, as shown in (2.24).

Proposition 6.1 combined with the Sinkhorn iterations as defined in (4.1) and (4.2) yields the formulae

$$
\frac{d \mathcal{P}_{2 n}}{d \mathcal{P}_{2 n+1}}(x, y)=\frac{d \pi_{2 n}}{d \mu}(y)=\exp \left(V_{2 n+1}(y)-V_{2 n}(y)\right)
$$

In the same vein, using (4.2) we verify that

$$
\frac{d \mathcal{P}_{2 n+1}}{d \mathcal{P}_{2(n+1)}}(x, y)=\frac{d \pi_{2 n+1}}{d \eta}(x)=\exp \left(U_{2(n+1)}(x)-U_{2 n+1}(x)\right)
$$

We summarize the above discussion with the following proposition.
Proposition 6.3. For every $n \geqslant 0$, we obtain

$$
V_{2 n}=V_{0}+\sum_{0 \leqslant p<n} \log \frac{d \pi_{2 p}}{d \mu} \quad \text { and } \quad U_{2 n}=U_{0}+\sum_{0 \leqslant p<n} \log \frac{d \pi_{2 p+1}}{d \eta}
$$

In addition, we have the monotone properties

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mu\left(V_{2(n+1)}\right) \leqslant \mu\left(V_{2 n}\right)=\mu\left(V_{2(n+1)}\right)+\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mu \mid \pi_{2 n}\right) \leqslant \mu\left(V_{0}\right)=0, \quad \text { and } \\
& \eta\left(U_{2(n+1)}\right) \leqslant \eta\left(U_{2 n}\right)=\eta\left(U_{2(n+1)}\right)+\operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 n+1}\right) \leqslant \eta\left(U_{0}\right)=\eta(U)
\end{aligned}
$$

Example 6.4. Consider the cost function $c(x, y)=-\log q(x, y)$ and set

$$
c_{\eta}(y):=\int \eta(d x) c(x, y) \quad \text { with } \quad c^{\mu}(x):=\int \mu(d y) c(x, y)
$$

For the Gaussian model in (6.1) we readily verify that

$$
c_{\eta}(y)=\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}\left(y-m_{0}\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\tau^{-1} \sigma_{\beta}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \log \operatorname{det}(2 \pi \tau)
$$

with $m_{0}:=(\alpha+\beta m)$ and $\sigma_{\beta}:=\left(\beta \sigma \beta^{\prime}\right)$, as well as

$$
c^{\mu}(x)=\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(\bar{m}-(\alpha+\beta x))\|_{F}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\tau^{-1} \bar{\sigma}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \log \operatorname{det}(2 \pi \tau)
$$

Equations (6.2) and (6.3) are obtained by way of elementary calculations. We sketch proofs in Appendix F (see page 69).

The proposition below applies to Gaussian models of the form (6.1). It provides some rather crude uniform estimates -more refined estimates that also apply to Gaussian models are presented in Section 5 of [45].
Proposition 6.5. Assume that, for any $z \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, the inequalities

$$
\mathcal{Q}\left(\exp \left(c_{\eta}\right)\right)(z)<\infty \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{R}\left(\exp \left(c^{\mu}\right)\right)(z)<\infty
$$

are satisfied. Then, the uniform estimates

$$
\begin{aligned}
-c^{\mu}+\mu(V) & \leqslant U_{2 n}-U \leqslant \log \mathcal{Q}\left(\exp \left(c_{\eta}\right)\right) \\
-c_{\eta} & \leqslant V_{2 n}-V \leqslant-\mu(V)+\log \mathcal{R}\left(\exp \left(c^{\mu}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

hold for every $n \geqslant 1$.
Proof. Applying Jensen's inequality we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log Q\left(\exp \left(-V_{2 n}\right)\right)(x) & =\log \int \mu(d y) \exp \left(-c(x, y)+V(y)-V_{2 n}(y)\right) \\
& \geqslant-c^{\mu}(x)+\mu(V)-\mu\left(V_{2 n}\right) \\
& \geqslant-c^{\mu}(x)+\mu(V)
\end{aligned}
$$

and, in a similar manner,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log R\left(\exp \left(-U_{2 n}\right)\right)(y) & =\log \int \eta(d x) \exp \left(-c(x, y)+U(x)-U_{2 n}(x)\right) \\
& \geqslant-c_{\eta}(y)+\eta(U)-\eta\left(U_{2 n}\right) \\
& \geqslant-c_{\eta}(y)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second inequality follows from Proposition 6.3. Hence, combining Proposition 6.1 with (6.4) and (6.5) above we arrive at

$$
U_{2 n} \geqslant U-c^{\mu}+\mu(V) \quad \text { and } \quad V_{2 n} \geqslant V-c_{\eta}
$$

which imply that

$$
\begin{aligned}
-c^{\mu}+\mu(V) & \leqslant U_{2 n}-U \leqslant \log Q\left(\exp \left(c_{\eta}-V\right)\right) \\
-c_{\eta} & \leqslant V_{2 n}-V \leqslant-\mu(V)+\log R\left(\exp \left(c^{\mu}-U\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, we observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q\left(\exp \left(c_{\eta}-V\right)\right)(x) & =\int \mu(d y) \exp \left(c_{\eta}(y)-c(x, y)\right)=\mathcal{Q}\left(\exp \left(c_{\eta}\right)\right)(x) \quad \text { and } \\
R\left(\exp \left(c^{\mu}-U\right)\right)(y) & =\int \eta(d x) \exp \left(c^{\mu}(x)-c(x, y)\right)=\mathcal{R}\left(\exp \left(c^{\mu}\right)\right)(y)
\end{aligned}
$$

Example 6.6. Consider the Gaussian model (6.1) and the integrated cost functions $\left(c_{\eta}, c^{\mu}\right)$ defined in (6.2) and (6.3). We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \log \mathcal{Q}\left(\exp \left(c_{\eta}\right)\right)(x)-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\tau^{-1} \sigma_{\beta}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{2}\left(\chi_{\theta}(x-m)\right)^{\prime}(\bar{\sigma}-\tau)\left(\chi_{\theta}(x-m)\right)+\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)^{\prime} \chi_{\theta}(x-m)
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\chi_{\theta}$ defined in (3.1), as well as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \log \mathcal{R}\left(\exp \left(c^{\mu}\right)\right)(y)-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\tau^{-1} \bar{\sigma}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{2}\left(y-\bar{m}\right)^{\prime}\left(\chi_{\theta} \sigma \chi_{\theta}^{\prime}-\tau^{-1}\right)(y-\bar{m})-(y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Equations (6.6) and (6.7) follow elementary calculations. Proofs are sketched in Appendix F (see page 69).

We further assume that the series in Proposition 6.3 converge almost everywhere, i.e., for almost every $x$ and $y \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $q \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} U_{2 n}(x)=\mathbb{U}(x) & :=U_{2 q}(x)+\sum_{p \geqslant q} \log \frac{d \pi_{2 p+1}}{d \eta}(x) \quad \text { and } \\
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} V_{2 n}(y)=\mathbb{V}(y) & :=V_{2 q}(y)+\sum_{p \geqslant q} \log \frac{d \pi_{2 p}}{d \mu}(y)
\end{aligned}
$$

For Gaussian models, the convergence of the above series can be easily verified following the arguments provided in Remark 5.5. We refer to Section 6.2 for more refined convergence rates of these series in the context of Gaussian models.

Following the discussion in Section 6 of [55], the uniform estimates presented in Proposition 6.5 can also be used to check the boundedness property of the sequences of potentials $U_{2 n}$ and $V_{2 n}$ in Lebesgue spaces. By the uniqueness property of the Schrödinger bridge $\mathcal{P}$, all the extracted convergent sub-sequences converge to $\mathbb{U}$ and $\mathbb{V}$. In this context, the bridge distribution the $\mathcal{P}$ has the form (1.6) and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 n}\right) & =\eta\left(U_{2 n}-\mathbb{U}\right)+\mu\left(V_{2 n}-\mathbb{V}\right) \\
& =\mu\left(\sum_{p \geqslant n} \log \frac{d \mu}{d \pi_{2 p}}\right)+\eta\left(\sum_{p \geqslant n} \log \frac{d \eta}{d \pi_{2 p+1}}\right)=\mathcal{P}\left(\log \frac{d \mathcal{P}}{d \mathcal{P}_{2 n}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark 6.7. As shown in Corollary 3.4 in the context of Gaussian models, (6.8) also implies that the bridge distribution $\mathcal{P}$ in (1.6) can be computed at any level of Sinkhorn iterations, in the sense that for any $q \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
\mathcal{P}=\underset{\mathbb{P} \in \mathcal{C}(\eta, \mu)}{\arg \min } \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathbb{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 q}\right)
$$

On the other hand, choosing $q>p=n$ in (4.15) we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{P}\left(\log \frac{d \mathcal{P}_{2 q}}{d \mathcal{P}_{2 n}}\right) & =\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 n}\right)-\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 q}\right) \\
& =\sum_{n \leqslant p<q}\left(\mu\left(\log \frac{d \mu}{d \pi_{2 p}}\right)+\eta\left(\log \frac{d \eta}{d \pi_{2 p+1}}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The above decompositions readily imply the following equivalence property.
Theorem 6.8. Assume that the series in (6.8) converges a.s. Then, we have

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 q}\right) \xrightarrow{q \rightarrow \infty} 0
$$

if, and only if,

$$
\sum_{p \geqslant n} \mu\left(\log \frac{d \mu}{d \pi_{2 p}}\right)+\sum_{p \geqslant n} \eta\left(\log \frac{d \eta}{d \pi_{2 p+1}}\right)=\mu\left(\sum_{p \geqslant n} \log \frac{d \mu}{d \pi_{2 p}}\right)+\eta\left(\sum_{p \geqslant n} \log \frac{d \eta}{d \pi_{2 p+1}}\right)
$$

for every $n \geqslant 0$. Moreover, for any $n \geqslant 0$ we have the entropy formulae

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 n}\right)=\sum_{p \geqslant n}\left(\operatorname{Ent}\left(\eta \mid \pi_{2 p+1}\right)+\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mu \mid \pi_{2 p}\right)\right)
$$

As a direct consequence of the dominated convergence theorem, Proposition 6.10 below provides a sufficient condition to interchange summation and integration.
Proposition 6.9. Assume that the series in (6.8) converges a.s. and

$$
\sum_{p \geqslant 0} \eta\left(\left|\log \frac{d \eta}{d \pi_{2 p+1}}\right|\right) \vee \sum_{p \geqslant 0} \mu\left(\left|\log \frac{d \mu}{d \pi_{2 p}}\right|\right)<\infty
$$

Then, the bridge distribution $\mathcal{P}$ in (1.6) satisfies the entropy formulae (6.9).
In terms of potential functions, condition (6.10) takes the form of the inequalities

$$
\sum_{p \geqslant 0} \eta\left(\left|U_{2(p+1)}-U_{2 p}\right|\right)<\infty \quad \text { and } \quad \sum_{p \geqslant 0} \mu\left(\left|V_{2(p+1)}-V_{2 p}\right|\right)<\infty
$$

which are clearly verified when

$$
\sum_{p \geqslant 0} \eta\left(\left|U_{2 p}-\mathbb{U}\right|\right)<\infty \quad \text { and } \quad \sum_{p \geqslant 0} \mu\left(\left|V_{2 p+1}-\mathbb{V}\right|\right)<\infty
$$

An application of Proposition 6.9 to the the Gaussian model (6.1) is presented in Corollary 6.15 .

Remark 6.10. Integrability conditions for the convergence $\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P} \mid \mathcal{P}_{2 q}\right) \xrightarrow{q \rightarrow \infty} 0$ are presented in Section 3 in [58] as well as in [45] and [55] (see for instance Theorem 6.15 in [55]). We remark that some sufficient integrability conditions discussed in the literature rely on global minorisation conditions or exponential-type uniformly integrability conditions which are generally not satisfied for the Gaussian model discussed in the present article. For instance, in terms of the cost function $c(x, y)=-\log q(x, y)$, the condition presented in Theorem 6.15 in [55] takes the form

$$
\exists \epsilon>1 \quad \text { such that } \int \eta(d x) \mu(d y) e^{\epsilon c(x, y)}<\infty
$$

This condition is not met for the simple quadratic cost (1.2) in one dimension with $t=1$ and the centered Gaussian $\eta=\mu=\nu_{0,1}$. We underline that the above condition is met when the regularization parameter $t$ is chosen sufficiently large. In a more recent article [56], the authors show the convergence of Sinkhorn iterates $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ to the bridge distribution $\mathcal{P}$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ when condition (6.12) is met for some $\epsilon>0$.

# 6.2 Gaussian potential functions 

The main objective of this section is to obtain a closed form expression of the Schrödinger potential functions in (1.5) for the Gaussian model described by (4.3) and (6.1). Recall that the Sinkhorn algorithm discussed in Section 4.1 starts at some reference parameter $\theta_{0}=\theta:=(\alpha, \beta, \tau) \in \Theta$ and consider the integral operators

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q_{\theta}(x, d y):=q_{\theta}(x, y) d y, \quad \text { and } \\
& R_{\theta}(x, d y):=r_{\theta}(x, y) d y \quad \text { with } \quad q_{\theta}(x, y)=r_{\theta}(y, x):=g_{\tau}(y-(\alpha+\beta x))
\end{aligned}
$$

In what follows $\left(m_{n}, \sigma_{n}\right)$ and $\theta_{n}=\left(\alpha_{n}, \beta_{n}, \tau_{n}\right)$ stands for the flow of Sinkhorn parameters (4.5) starting at $\theta_{0}=\theta$.

Our approach is based on the series expansions presented in Proposition 6.3. By Proposition 6.1 it suffices to analyze potential functions indexed by even indices.
Lemma 6.11. For any $n \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
\sigma_{2 n}^{-1}-\bar{\sigma}^{-1}=\tau_{2 n}^{-1}-\tau_{2(n+1)}^{-1} \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\sigma^{-1}=\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\tau_{2 n+3}^{-1}
$$

We also have the determinant formulae

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\sigma^{-1} \sigma_{2 n+1}\right)=\operatorname{det}\left(v_{2 n+1} v_{2(n+1)}^{-1}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{det}\left(\bar{\sigma}^{-1} \sigma_{2 n}\right)=\operatorname{det}\left(v_{2 n} v_{2 n+1}^{-1}\right)
$$

as well as the variance equations

$$
\sigma_{2 n}^{-1} \beta_{2 n}=\tau^{-1} \beta\left(I-\beta_{2 n+1} \beta_{2 n}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{2 n+1}^{-1} \beta_{2 n+1}=\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(I-\beta_{2(n+1)} \beta_{2 n+1}\right)
$$

A proof is provided in Appendix E -see page 61.
Using (6.14), we readily find that

$$
\begin{aligned}
V_{2 n}(\bar{m}) & =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{0 \leqslant p<n} \log \operatorname{det}\left(v_{2 p+1} v_{2 p}^{-1}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{0 \leqslant p<n}\left\|\sigma_{2 p}^{-1 / 2}\left(m_{2 p}-\bar{m}\right)\right\|_{F}^{2} \quad \text { and } \\
U_{2 n}(m) & =U(m)+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{0 \leqslant p<n} \log \operatorname{det}\left(v_{2(p+1)} v_{2 p+1}^{-1}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{0 \leqslant p<n}\left\|\sigma_{2 p+1}^{-1 / 2}\left(m_{2 p+1}-m\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking the sum of the above expressions we obtain the following decomposition.

Proposition 6.12. For every $n \geqslant 0$ we have
$V_{2 n}(\bar{m})+U_{2 n}(m)=U(m)+\frac{1}{2} \log \operatorname{det}\left(\tau_{2 n} \tau_{0}^{-1}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau_{2 n}^{-1 / 2}\left(m_{2 n}-\bar{m}\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau_{0}^{-1 / 2}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}$.
The proof of the above proposition is rather technical; it is in Appendix E, on page 62. Let us set

$$
\epsilon_{2 n}^{V}(\bar{m}):=V_{2 n}(\bar{m})-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(\bar{m}) \quad \text { and } \quad \epsilon_{2 n}^{U}(m):=U_{2 n}(m)-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(m)
$$

with the limiting infinite series

$$
\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(\bar{m}):=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} V_{2 n}(\bar{m}) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathbb{U}_{\theta}(m):=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} U_{2 n}(m)
$$

Recalling that $\tau_{2 n}$ converges towards $\varsigma_{\theta}$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ and $U(m)=\frac{1}{2} \log \operatorname{det}(\sigma)$, Proposition 6.12 also yields the formula (3.15).

Consider now the potential functions defined in Theorem 3.7 with the parameters $\left(\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(m), \mathbb{V}_{\theta}(\bar{m})\right)$ defined in (6.16). We are now in position to state the main result of this section.
Theorem 6.13. For every $n \geqslant 1$ we have

$$
V_{2 n}(y)=\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(y)+\epsilon_{2 n}^{V}(y) \quad \text { and } \quad U_{2 n}(x)=\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(x)+\epsilon_{2 n}^{U}(x)
$$

with the remainder functions

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \epsilon_{2 n}^{V}(y+\bar{m}):=\epsilon_{2 n}^{V}(\bar{m})+y^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta \beta_{2 n-1,1}^{\circ}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2} y^{\prime}\left(\tau_{2 n}^{-1}-\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1}\right) y \\
& \epsilon_{2 n}^{U}(x+m):=\epsilon_{2 n}^{U}(m)+x^{\prime} \tau_{1}^{-1} \beta_{1} \beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}\left(m-m_{1}\right)+\frac{1}{2} x^{\prime}\left(\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}\right) x
\end{aligned}
$$

and the directed products $\beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}$ and $\beta_{2 n-1,1}^{\circ}$ defined in (4.18).
See Appendix E (page 63) for a proof.
Next corollary is a direct consequence of the exponential estimates presented in Section 5. A detailed proof is provided in Appendix E -see page 64.
Corollary 6.14. There exists some constants $c_{\theta}^{U}, c_{\theta}^{V}$ and some parameter $n_{\theta}$ such that for any $n \geqslant n_{\theta}$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|V_{2 n}(y)-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(y)\right| & \leqslant c_{\theta}^{V}\left(\rho_{\theta}^{n}+\bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n / 2}\|y-\bar{m}\|+\rho_{\theta}^{n}\|y-\bar{m}\|^{2}\right) \quad \text { and } \\
\left|U_{2 n}(x)-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(x)\right| & \leqslant c_{\theta}^{V}\left(\bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n}+\rho_{\theta}^{n / 2}\|x-m\|+\bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n}\|x-m\|^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying Proposition 6.9 to the Gaussian model (6.1) we have $(\eta, \mu):=\left(\nu_{m, \sigma}, \nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}\right)$, $\pi_{n}=\nu_{m_{n}, \sigma_{n}}$ as well as $\left(\mathcal{P}, \mathcal{P}_{2 n}\right)=\left(P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}, P_{\theta_{2 n}}\right)$. In this context, condition (6.11) is clearly satisfied. Using the entropy estimates stated in Remark 5.5 we readily find the following estimate.

Corollary 6.15. There exists some constant $c_{\theta}>0$ and some $n_{0}$ such that for any $n \geqslant n_{0}$ we have

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)} \mid P_{\theta_{2 n}}\right) \leqslant c_{\theta}\left(\rho_{\theta} \vee \bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}\right)^{n}
$$

Applying Lebesgue's dominated convergence theorem, the integral equations stated in Proposition 6.1 converge as $n \rightarrow \infty$ to a system of integral equations

$$
\mathbb{U}_{\theta}=U+\log Q_{\theta}\left(e^{-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathbb{V}_{\theta}=V+\log R_{\theta}\left(e^{-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}}\right)
$$

with the integral operators

$$
Q_{\theta}(x, d y):=q_{\theta}(x, y) d y \quad \text { and } \quad R_{\theta}(x, d y):=r_{\theta}(x, y) d y
$$

The corollary below is a direct consequence of Theorem 6.13 and Corollary 6.14.
Corollary 6.16. For any $\theta \in \Theta$, the Schrödinger bridge (3.14) between the distributions $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ and $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ with reference parameter $\theta$ satisfies the equation

$$
P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}=\mathbb{P}_{\theta} \quad \text { and } \quad K_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}(x, d y)=\frac{Q_{\theta}(x, d y) e^{-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(y)}}{Q_{\theta}\left(e^{-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}}\right)(x)}
$$

For any $\theta \in \Theta$, the dual Schrödinger bridge associated with (2.29) between the distributions $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$ and $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ with reference parameter $\theta_{1}=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta)$ satisfies the equation

$$
\overline{\mathcal{P}}_{\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{1}\right)}=\mathbb{P}_{\theta}^{\lambda} \quad \text { and } \quad K_{\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{1}\right)}(x, d y)=\frac{R_{\theta}(x, d y) e^{-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(y)}}{R_{\theta}\left(e^{-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}}\right)(x)}
$$

The second assertion is also a direct consequence of the commutation property (3.6). An alternative and more direct proof of the above corollary based on the closed-forms of the Schödinger potentials $\left(\mathbb{U}_{\theta}, \mathbb{V}_{\theta}\right)$ is provided in Appendix E (see page 65).

# Appendix
## A Pseudocode and simulations of the Gaussian Sinkhorn algorithm

We provide below a pseudocode of the Gaussian Sinkhorn algorithm for practical implementation.

```
Algorithm 1 The Gaussian Sinkhorn algorithm
    Input: \((m, \sigma)\) and \(\left(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}\right)\), reference parameters \(\theta_{0}=\left(\beta_{0}, \tau_{0}\right)\), the number of iterations
    \(T\).
    \(\gamma_{\theta_{0}}=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \tau_{0}^{-1} \beta_{0} \sigma^{1 / 2}\)
    Initialize \(m_{0}, \sigma_{0}\).
    Compute \(v_{0}=\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \tau_{0} \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}\).
    for \(n=1, \ldots, T\) do
        if \(n\) is even then
            \(v_{n}=\left(I_{d}+\gamma_{\theta_{0}} v_{n-1} \gamma_{\theta_{0}}^{\prime}\right)^{-1}\).
            \(\tau_{n}=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} v_{n} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\).
            \(\beta_{n}=\tau_{n} \tau_{0}^{-1} \beta_{0}\).
            \(m_{n}=\bar{m}+\beta_{n}\left(m-m_{n-1}\right)\).
            \(\sigma_{n}=\beta_{n} \sigma \beta_{n}^{\prime}+\tau_{n}\).
        else
            \(v_{n}=\left(I_{d}+\gamma_{\theta_{0}}^{\prime} v_{n-1} \gamma_{\theta_{0}}\right)^{-1}\).
            \(\tau_{n}=\sigma^{1 / 2} v_{n} \sigma^{1 / 2}\)
            \(\beta_{n}=\tau_{n} \beta^{\prime} \tau_{0}^{-1}\).
            \(m_{n}=m+\beta_{n}\left(\bar{m}-m_{n-1}\right)\).
            \(\sigma_{n}=\beta_{n} \bar{\sigma} \beta_{n}^{\prime}+\tau_{n}\).
        end if
    end for
```

For simplicity, we describe the algorithm with an if statement to separate the case when $n$ is even $(n=2 k)$ from the case when for $n$ is odd $(n=2 k+1)$. As discussed, this algorithm exactly, iteratively, solves the entropic optimal transport problem and provides estimates of the sufficient statistics of $\nu_{m, \sigma}$ and $\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$. Specifically, the sequence $\left(m_{2 n}, \sigma_{2 n}\right)_{n \geqslant 0}$ provides the estimates of $(\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma})$ and converges as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Similarly, the sequence $\left(m_{2 n+1}, \sigma_{2 n+1}\right)_{n \geqslant 0}$ provides estimates for $(m, \sigma)$ and similarly converges as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Below, we demonstrate the convergence behaviour in a simple 2D setting. This simulation also shows that this is a stable numerical algorithm that can be used to assess the performance of optimal transport methods.

The results of a numerical simulation in a 2D Gaussian setting can be seen in Fig. 1. The iteration is initialized with

$$
m_{0} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0,10 I_{2}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{0}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}
10 & 9.99 \\
9.99 & 10
\end{array}\right]
$$

# B Riccati difference equation
## Some terminology

We associate with some given $\varpi \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$the matrix recursions

$$
u_{n+1}:=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{-}\left(u_{n}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad v_{n+1}=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}\left(v_{n}\right)
$$

with the increasing maps $\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{-}$and $\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}$ from $\mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$ into itself defined by

$$
\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{-}(u)=\varpi+(I+u)^{-1} u \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}(v):=\left(I+(\varpi+v)^{-1}\right)^{-1}
$$

Observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{-}(0)=\varpi \leqslant \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{-}(u) \leqslant \varpi+I \quad \text { and } \\
& \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}(0)=\left(I+\varpi^{-1}\right)^{-1} \leqslant \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}(v) \leqslant I
\end{aligned}
$$

This shows that for any $n \geqslant 1$ and any $u_{0}, v_{0} \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$ we have

$$
\varpi \leqslant u_{n} \leqslant \varpi+I \quad \text { and } \quad\left(I+\varpi^{-1}\right)^{-1} \leqslant v_{n} \leqslant I
$$

These inequalities yield, for any $n \geqslant 1$, the upper bound

$$
v_{n+1}=\left(I+\left(\varpi+v_{n}\right)^{-1}\right)^{-1} \leqslant\left(I+(\varpi+I)^{-1}\right)^{-1}=I-(I+(\varpi+I))^{-1}
$$

and, therefore, the estimates below.
Lemma B.1. For any $v \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
\left(I+\varpi^{-1}\right)^{-1} \leqslant v_{n+1} \leqslant\left(I+(\varpi+I)^{-1}\right)^{-1}
$$

or, equivalently,

$$
(I+(\varpi+I))^{-1} \leqslant I-v_{n+1} \leqslant I-\left(I+\varpi^{-1}\right)^{-1}=(I+\varpi)^{-1}
$$

The r.h.s. assertion in (B.5) comes from the fact that

$$
I-\left(I+\varpi^{-1}\right)^{-1}=\left(I+\varpi^{-1}\right)^{-1}\left(\left(I+\varpi^{-1}\right)-I\right)=(I+\varpi)^{-1}
$$

In addition, $u_{0}>0$ implies that $u_{n}>\varpi$ for every $n \geqslant 1$ and, in the same vein, $v_{0}>0$ yields

$$
v_{n}>\left(I+\varpi^{-1}\right)^{-1} \quad \text { and } \quad I-v_{n}<(I+\varpi)^{-1} \quad \text { for every } n \geqslant 1
$$

Recalling that the Riccati flow starting at the null matrix is increasing while le one starting at $I$ is decreasing we readily find the following estimates.

Lemma B.2. For any $n \geqslant 1$ and $v \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
0 \leqslant \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{n-1}(0) \leqslant \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{n}(0) \leqslant \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{n}(v) \leqslant \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{n-1}(I) \leqslant I
$$

as well as

$$
\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{n}(v) \leqslant \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{n-1}(I)
$$

The recursions in (B.1) are connected by the inductive formulae

$$
u_{n} \longrightarrow v_{n}=\left(I+u_{n}\right)^{-1} u_{n} \longrightarrow u_{n+1}=v_{n}+\varpi \longrightarrow v_{n+1}=\left(I+u_{n+1}\right)^{-1} u_{n+1}
$$

Starting from $v_{0}=0$, for every $n \geqslant 0$ we also have

$$
v_{n} \longrightarrow u_{n+1}:=v_{n}+\varpi \longrightarrow v_{n+1}=\left(I+u_{n+1}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \geqslant\left(I+\varpi^{-1}\right)^{-1}
$$

The assertions above are easily verified if we note that

$$
v_{n+1}=\left(I+u_{n+1}^{-1}\right)^{-1}=\left(I+\left(\varpi+\left(I+u_{n}^{-1}\right)^{-1}\right)^{-1}\right)^{-1}=\left(I+\left(\varpi+v_{n}\right)^{-1}\right)^{-1}
$$

and

$$
u_{n+1}=v_{n}+\varpi=\varpi+\left(I+u_{n}^{-1}\right)^{-1}
$$

For any given $s \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$, if we let $\tau_{n}:=s^{1 / 2} v_{n} s^{1 / 2}$ then we obtain the recursion

$$
\tau_{n+1}=\operatorname{Ricc}_{s, \varpi_{s}}\left(\tau_{n}\right):=\left(s^{-1}+\left(\varpi_{s}+\tau_{n}\right)^{-1}\right)^{-1}, \quad \text { with } \quad \varpi_{s}:=s^{1 / 2} \varpi s^{1 / 2}
$$

Also note that

$$
v_{n}=\left(I+u_{n}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \Longleftrightarrow I-v_{n}=\left(I+u_{n}\right)^{-1}
$$

# Fixed point matrices 

Riccati matrix difference equations of the form (B.1) are rather well understood (cf. [35] and references therein). For instance, $u_{n}$ and $v_{n}$ converge exponentially fast, as $n \rightarrow \infty$, to the unique positive definite fixed points

$$
u_{\infty}=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{-}\left(u_{\infty}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad r_{\infty}=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}\left(r_{\infty}\right)
$$

The fixed points are connected by the formula

$$
r_{\infty}:=\left(I+u_{\infty}^{-1}\right)^{-1}
$$

which implies that

$$
r_{\infty}+\varpi=u_{\infty} \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}\left(r_{\infty}\right)=\left(I+\left(\varpi+r_{\infty}\right)^{-1}\right)^{-1}=\left(I+u_{\infty}^{-1}\right)^{-1}=r_{\infty}
$$

Also notice that

$$
\begin{aligned}
r_{\infty}=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}\left(r_{\infty}\right) & \Longrightarrow r_{\infty}^{-1}=I+\left(\varpi+r_{\infty}\right)^{-1} \\
& \Longrightarrow \varpi r_{\infty}^{-1}+I=\left(\varpi+r_{\infty}\right) r_{\infty}^{-1}=\left(\varpi+r_{\infty}\right)+I \\
& \Longrightarrow \varpi r_{\infty}^{-1}=\varpi+r_{\infty} \Longrightarrow r_{\infty}^{-1}=I+\varpi^{-1} r_{\infty}
\end{aligned}
$$

hence we conclude that

$$
I=r_{\infty}+r_{\infty} \varpi^{-1} r_{\infty}
$$

More interestingly, the fixed point $r_{\infty}$ can be explicitly computed in terms of $\varpi$. Indeed, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
r_{\infty} & =\left(I+\left(\varpi+r_{\infty}\right)^{-1}\right)^{-1} \\
& =\left(\left(\varpi+r_{\infty}\right)^{-1}\left(\left(\varpi+r_{\infty}\right)+I\right)\right)^{-1}=\left(\left(\varpi+r_{\infty}\right)+I\right)^{-1}\left(\varpi+r_{\infty}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which implies the equivalence

$$
\left(\left(\varpi+r_{\infty}\right)+I\right) r_{\infty}=\varpi+r_{\infty} \Longleftrightarrow r_{\infty}^{2}+\varpi r_{\infty}=\varpi
$$

We may also note that

$$
\varpi=\varpi^{\prime} \quad \text { and } \quad r_{\infty}=r_{\infty}^{\prime} \Longrightarrow \varpi r_{\infty}=r_{\infty} \varpi
$$

and, as a consequence,

$$
r_{\infty}^{2}+\varpi r_{\infty}=\left(r_{\infty}+\frac{\varpi}{2}\right)^{2}-\left(\frac{\varpi}{2}\right)^{2}=\varpi
$$

We summarize the above discussion with the following proposition.
Proposition B.3. The unique positive definite fixed points of the matrix equations (B.7) are given by the formulae

$$
r_{\infty}=-\frac{\varpi}{2}+\left(\varpi+\left(\frac{\varpi}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \quad u_{\infty}=\frac{\varpi}{2}+\left(\varpi+\left(\frac{\varpi}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

Let us also note that

$$
\varpi r_{\infty}=r_{\infty} \varpi \Longleftrightarrow \varpi^{-1}\left(\varpi+\left(\frac{\varpi}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \varpi=\left(\varpi+\left(\frac{\varpi}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

where the r.h.s. assertion is a direct consequence of the formula

$$
\left(\varpi^{-1}\left(\varpi+\left(\frac{\varpi}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \varpi\right)^{2}=\varpi^{-1}\left(\varpi+\left(\frac{\varpi}{2}\right)^{2}\right) \varpi=\varpi+\left(\frac{\varpi}{2}\right)^{2}
$$

Finally observe that, for any given $s \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{+}$, we have

$$
r_{s, \infty}:=s^{1 / 2} r_{\infty} s^{1 / 2}=\operatorname{Ricc}_{s, \varpi_{s}}\left(r_{s, \infty}\right) \quad \text { which implies } \quad r_{s, \infty}+r_{s, \infty} \varpi_{s}^{-1} r_{s, \infty}=s
$$

# Stability analysis 

By monotone arguments one can show that that

$$
v_{0} \leqslant r_{\infty} \Longleftrightarrow v_{n} \leqslant r_{\infty} \quad \forall n \geqslant 0
$$

Also for any $u_{1}, u_{2} \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{-}\left(u_{1}\right)-\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{-}\left(u_{2}\right) & =\left(I+u_{1}\right)^{-1} u_{1}-\left(I+u_{2}\right)^{-1} u_{2} \\
& =\left(I+u_{1}\right)^{-1}\left(u_{1}\left(I+u_{2}\right)-\left(I+u_{1}\right) u_{2}\right)\left(I+u_{2}\right)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

which yields the formulae

$$
\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{-}\left(u_{1}\right)-\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{-}\left(u_{2}\right)=\mathcal{E}\left(u_{1}\right)\left(u_{1}-u_{2}\right) \mathcal{E}\left(u_{2}\right)^{\prime} \quad \text { with } \quad \mathcal{E}(u):=(I+u)^{-1}
$$

Consider the directed matrix product $\mathcal{E}_{n}\left(u_{0}\right)$ defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{E}_{n+1}\left(u_{0}\right):=\left(I+u_{n}\right)^{-1} \ldots\left(I+u_{1}\right)^{-1}\left(I+u_{0}\right)^{-1}, \quad \text { hence } \\
& \mathcal{E}_{n}\left(u_{\infty}\right) \quad=\left(I+u_{\infty}\right)^{-n}
\end{aligned}
$$

for the fixed point $u_{\infty}$. In (B.11), $u_{n}$ solves the matrix recursion in the l.h.s. of (B.1) starting from some $u_{0} \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$. In terms of the matrices $v_{n}$ defined in (B.1) using (B.6) we have the directed product formula

$$
\mathcal{E}_{n+1}\left(u_{0}\right):=\left(I-v_{n}\right) \ldots\left(I-v_{1}\right)\left(I-v_{0}\right)
$$

From the discussion above, it follows that

$$
\text { if } u_{\infty}>\lambda_{\min }(\varpi) I \quad \text { then } \quad\left\|\mathcal{E}_{n}\left(u_{\infty}\right)\right\|_{2} \leqslant\left(1+\lambda_{\min }\left(u_{\infty}\right)\right)^{-n} \leqslant\left(1+\lambda_{\min }(\varpi)\right)^{-n}
$$

More refined estimates can be obtained using Proposition B.3. In our context, the Floquettype formula presented in Theorem 1.3 in [35] takes the form given below.
Theorem B. 4 ([35]). For any $n \geqslant 0$, we have

$$
\mathcal{E}_{n}(u)=\left(I+u_{\infty}\right)^{-n}\left(I+\left(u-u_{\infty}\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}\right)^{-1} \quad \text { with } \quad \mathbb{G}_{n}:=\sum_{0 \leqslant k<n}\left(I+u_{\infty}\right)^{-(2 k+1)}
$$

Note that

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{G}_{n}=\mathbb{G}:=\left(I+u_{\infty}\right)^{-1}\left(I-\left(I+u_{\infty}\right)^{-2}\right)^{-1}>\mathbb{G}_{n}
$$

which, rewritten in a slightly different form, yields

$$
\mathbb{G}_{n}^{-1}>\mathbb{G}^{-1}=u_{\infty}+\widehat{u}_{\infty}^{-1}, \quad \text { where } \quad \widehat{u}_{\infty}^{-1}:=I-\left(I+u_{\infty}\right)^{-1}=\left(I+u_{\infty}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \leqslant I
$$

Using (B.7), we check the fix point equations

$$
\widehat{u}_{\infty}=I+u_{\infty}^{-1} \Longrightarrow \varpi+\widehat{u}_{\infty}^{-1}=u_{\infty} \Longrightarrow \widehat{u}_{\infty}=I+\left(\varpi+\widehat{u}_{\infty}^{-1}\right)^{-1}
$$

and using the decomposition

$$
I+\left(u-u_{\infty}\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}=\left(\left(\mathbb{G}_{n}^{-1}-\mathbb{G}^{-1}\right)+\left(\mathbb{G}^{-1}-u_{\infty}\right)+u\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}
$$

we verify that

$$
I+\left(u-u_{\infty}\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}=\left(\left(\mathbb{G}_{n}^{-1}-\mathbb{G}^{-1}\right)+\widehat{u}_{\infty}^{-1}+u\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}
$$

This yields the uniform estimates

$$
\left\|\left(I+\left(u-u_{\infty}\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}\right)^{-1}\right\|_{2} \leqslant\left\|\widehat{u}_{\infty}\right\|_{2}\left\|\mathbb{G}^{-1}\right\|_{2} \leqslant\left(1+\left\|u_{\infty}^{-1}\right\|_{2}\right)\left(1+\left\|u_{\infty}\right\|_{2}\right)
$$

We summarize the above discussion with the following proposition.
Proposition B.5. For any $n \geqslant 0$ and any $u \in \mathcal{S}_{+}^{0}$, we have the inequality

$$
\left\|\mathcal{E}_{n}(u)\right\|_{2} \leqslant \psi\left(u_{\infty}\right)\left(1+\lambda_{\min }\left(u_{\infty}\right)\right)^{-n}
$$

with the parameter

$$
\psi\left(u_{\infty}\right):=\left(1+\left\|u_{\infty}^{-1}\right\|_{2}\right)\left(1+\left\|u_{\infty}\right\|_{2}\right)
$$

Denote by $u_{n}$ and $\bar{u}_{n}$ the solutions of the matrix recursion defined in the l.h.s. of (B.1) starting from some $u_{0}, \bar{u}_{0} \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$, respectively. Using (B.10), for any $u_{0}, \bar{u}_{0} \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$ we have

$$
u_{n}-\bar{u}_{n}=\mathcal{E}_{n}\left(u_{0}\right)\left(u_{0}-\bar{u}_{0}\right) \mathcal{E}_{n}\left(\bar{u}_{0}\right)^{\prime}
$$

which yields the estimate

$$
\left\|u_{n}-\bar{u}_{n}\right\|_{2} \leqslant \psi\left(u_{\infty}\right)^{2}\left(1+\lambda_{\min }\left(u_{\infty}\right)\right)^{-2 n}\left\|u_{0}-\bar{u}_{0}\right\|_{2}
$$

Similarly, denote by $v_{n}$ and $\bar{v}_{n}$ the solutions of the matrix recursion defined in the r.h.s. of (B.1) starting from some $v_{0}$ and $\bar{v}_{0} \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$, respectively. We note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
v_{n}-\bar{v}_{n} & =\left(I+u_{n}\right)^{-1} u_{n}-\bar{u}_{n}\left(I+\bar{u}_{n}\right)^{-1} \\
& =\left(I+u_{n}\right)^{-1} \bar{u}_{n}^{-1}\left(u_{n}-\bar{u}_{n}\right) u_{n}^{-1}\left(I+\bar{u}_{n}\right)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $u_{n}$ and $\bar{u}_{n}$ are solutions of the matrix recursion defined in the l.h.s. of (B.1) starting from some $u_{1}=v_{0}+\varpi$ and $\bar{u}_{1}=\bar{v}_{0}+\varpi \in \mathcal{S}_{d}^{0}$, respectively, at rank $n=1$. The above decomposition combined with the estimates (B.3) yields the following result.
Proposition B.6. For every $n \geqslant 0$, we have the exponential estimates

$$
\left\|\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{n+1}\left(v_{0}\right)-\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{n+1}\left(\bar{v}_{0}\right)\right\|_{2} \leqslant \varphi_{\varpi}\left(u_{\infty}\right)^{2}\left(1+\lambda_{\min }\left(u_{\infty}\right)\right)^{-2 n}\left\|v_{0}-\bar{v}_{0}\right\|_{2}
$$

with the semigroup $\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{n+1}:=\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi} \circ \operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi}^{n}$ and the parameter

$$
\varphi_{\varpi}\left(u_{\infty}\right):=\left(1+\lambda_{\min }(\varpi)\right)^{-1} \quad \lambda_{\max }(\varpi) \psi\left(u_{\infty}\right)
$$

In the above display, $u_{\infty}$ stands for the fixed point matrix defined in Proposition B. 3 and $\psi\left(u_{\infty}\right)$ is the parameter defined in (B.13).

Using (B.3) we see that

$$
\psi\left(u_{\infty}\right) \leqslant\left(1+\left(1+\lambda_{\min }(\varpi)\right)^{-1}\right)\left(2+\lambda_{\max }(\varpi)\right)
$$

which yields the rather crude estimate

$$
\varphi_{\varpi}\left(u_{\infty}\right) \leqslant\left(1+\left(1+\lambda_{\min }(\varpi)\right)^{-1}\right)^{2}\left(1+\lambda_{\max }(\varpi)\right)^{2}
$$

# Proof of Theorem 4.3 

Formula (4.8) yields the matrix Riccati difference equations

$$
\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\left(\tau_{2 n}^{-1} \beta_{2 n}\right)^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}\left(\tau_{2 n}^{-1} \beta_{2 n}\right)=\sigma^{-1}+\chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n} \chi_{\theta}
$$

with the parameter $\chi_{\theta}$ defined in (3.1) so that

$$
\gamma_{\theta}=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \chi_{\theta} \sigma^{1 / 2}
$$

In the same vein, using (4.8) we obtain

$$
\tau_{2(n+1)}^{-1}=\bar{\sigma}^{-1}+\chi_{\theta} \tau_{2 n+1} \chi_{\theta}^{\prime}
$$

This ends the proof of (4.10) up to a rescaling.
Next, observe that

$$
u=\left(I+\gamma^{\prime} v \gamma\right)^{-1} \Longrightarrow\left(I+\gamma u \gamma^{\prime}\right)^{-1}=\left(I+(\varpi+v)^{-1}\right)^{-1}, \quad \text { with } \quad \varpi:=\left(\gamma \gamma^{\prime}\right)^{-1}
$$

To verify this claim, we first use the matrix inversion lemma to prove that

$$
u=I-\gamma^{\prime}\left(v^{-1}+\gamma \gamma^{\prime}\right)^{-1} \gamma
$$

This implies that

$$
\gamma u \gamma^{\prime}=\gamma \gamma^{\prime}-\gamma \gamma^{\prime}\left(v^{-1}+\gamma \gamma^{\prime}\right)^{-1} \gamma \gamma^{\prime}=\left(\left(\gamma \gamma^{\prime}\right)^{-1}+v\right)^{-1}=(\varpi+v)^{-1}
$$

and completes the proof of (B.16). Formulae (4.11) are now a direct consequence of the above decompositions.

## Dual Riccati fixed point matrices

By (4.10), the fixed point matrices $\left(r_{\theta}, \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}\right)$ defined in (3.2) and (3.9) are connected with the formulae (3.10). We can check directly this assertion if we let

$$
\widehat{r}_{\theta}^{-1}:=I+\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} r_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}
$$

and then apply the matrix inversion lemma to arrive at

$$
\begin{aligned}
\gamma_{\theta} \widehat{r}_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} & =\gamma_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}-\gamma_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\left(r_{\theta}^{-1}+\gamma_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} \gamma_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \\
& =\left(\left(\gamma_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\right)^{-1}+r_{\theta}\right)^{-1}=\left(\varpi_{\theta}+r_{\theta}\right)^{-1}=r_{\theta}^{-1}-I
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies the equivalences

$$
\left(I+\gamma_{\theta} \widehat{r}_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\right)^{-1}=r_{\theta} \Longleftrightarrow r_{\theta}^{-1}=\gamma_{\theta} \widehat{r}_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}+I \Longleftrightarrow \widehat{r}_{\theta}+\left(\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \gamma_{\theta}\right)^{-1}=\left(\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} r_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}\right)^{-1}
$$

from where we see that

$$
I+\left(\widehat{r}_{\theta}+\left(\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \gamma_{\theta}\right)^{-1}\right)^{-1}=I+\left(\widehat{r}_{\theta}+\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}\right)^{-1}=I+\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} r_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}=\widehat{r}_{\theta}^{-1}
$$

By uniqueness of the positive fixed point we conclude that

$$
\widehat{r}_{\theta}=\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}} \Longrightarrow \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}=I+\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} r_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}
$$

This completes the proof of (3.10).
The matrix inversion lemma also yields the formulae

$$
\begin{aligned}
r_{\theta} & =I-\gamma_{\theta}\left(\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}+\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \text { and } \\
\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}} & =I-\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\left(r_{\theta}^{-1}+\varpi_{\theta}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \gamma_{\theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

which imply that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} r_{\theta} & =\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}-\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}\left(\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}+\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \\
& =\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}-\left(\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}+\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}\right)^{-1} \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \\
& =\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}-\left(\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}-I\right) \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}=\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

This yields the commutation property

$$
\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} r_{\theta}=\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \Longleftrightarrow r_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}=\gamma_{\theta} \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}}
$$

# C Relative entropy
## Sinkhorn conditioning formulae

With some abuse of notation, consider the conditional decompositions

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{P}_{1,2}\left(d\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)\right):=\mathcal{P}_{2}\left(d x_{2}\right) \mathcal{P}_{1 \mid 2}\left(x_{2}, d x_{1}\right)=\mathcal{P}_{1}\left(d x_{1}\right) \mathcal{P}_{2 \mid 1}\left(x_{1}, d x_{2}\right) \\
& \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1,2}\left(d\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)\right):=\overline{\mathcal{P}}_{2}\left(d x_{2}\right) \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1 \mid 2}\left(x_{2}, d x_{1}\right)=\overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1}\left(d x_{1}\right) \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{2 \mid 1}\left(x_{1}, d x_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Observe that

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P}_{1,2} \mid \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1,2}\right)=\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P}_{2} \mid \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{2}\right)+\int \mathcal{P}_{2}\left(d x_{2}\right) \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P}_{1 \mid 2}\left(x_{2} . .\right) \mid \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1 \mid 2}\left(x_{2} . .\right)\right)
$$

Thus, given $\overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1,2}$ and a prescribed marginal $\mathcal{P}_{2}$, we obtain

$$
\left(\mathcal{P}_{2} \times \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1 \mid 2}\right)^{\prime}=\underset{\mathcal{P}_{1,2}}{\arg \min } \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P}_{1,2} \mid \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1,2}\right)
$$

In the same way,

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P}_{1,2} \mid \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1,2}\right)=\operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P}_{1} \mid \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1}\right)+\int \mathcal{P}_{1}\left(d x_{1}\right) \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P}_{2 \mid 1}\left(x_{1} . .\right) \mid \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{2 \mid 1}\left(x_{1} . .\right)\right)
$$

and, given $\mathcal{P}_{1,2}$ and a prescribed marginal $\overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1}$, we have

$$
\overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1} \times \mathcal{P}_{2 \mid 1}=\underset{\overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1,2}}{\arg \min } \operatorname{Ent}\left(\mathcal{P}_{1,2} \mid \overline{\mathcal{P}}_{1,2}\right)
$$

# Some inequalities 

Taking together (2.6) and $A=I-\sigma_{2}^{-1} \sigma_{1}$ we see that

$$
\left\|\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}\right\|_{F} \leqslant \frac{1}{2\left\|\sigma_{2}^{-1}\right\|_{F}} \quad \text { implies } \quad\left\|I-\sigma_{2}^{-1} \sigma_{1}\right\|_{F} \leqslant\left\|\sigma_{2}^{-1}\right\|_{F}\left\|\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}\right\|_{F} \leqslant \frac{1}{2}
$$

which, in turn, yields

$$
\left|\log \operatorname{det}\left(\sigma_{2}^{-1} \sigma_{1}\right)\right| \leqslant \frac{3}{2}\left\|\sigma_{2}^{-1}\right\|_{F}\left\|\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}\right\|_{F}
$$

Thus, we have the following lemma.
Lemma C.1. If

$$
\left\|\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}\right\|_{F} \leqslant \frac{1}{2\left\|\sigma_{2}^{-1}\right\|_{F}}
$$

we have the estimate

$$
\left|\log \operatorname{det}\left(\sigma_{1}^{-1} \sigma_{2}\right)\right| \leqslant \frac{3}{2}\left\|\sigma_{2}^{-1}\right\|_{F}\left\|\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}\right\|_{F}
$$

On the other hand, we have

$$
\left|\operatorname{Tr}\left(\sigma_{2}^{-1} \sigma_{1}-I\right)\right| \leqslant\left\|\sigma_{2}^{-1}\right\|_{F}\left\|\sigma_{2}-\sigma_{1}\right\|_{F}
$$

which yields the implication

$$
\left\|\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}\right\|_{F} \leqslant \frac{1}{2\left\|\sigma_{2}^{-1}\right\|_{F}} \Longrightarrow D\left(\sigma_{1} \mid \sigma_{2}\right) \leqslant \frac{5}{2}\left\|\sigma_{2}^{-1}\right\|_{F}\left\|\sigma_{2}-\sigma_{1}\right\|_{F}
$$

We summarize the above discussion with the following proposition
Proposition C.2. Assume that

$$
\left\|\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}\right\|_{F} \leqslant \frac{1}{2\left\|\sigma_{2}^{-1}\right\|_{F}}
$$

Then, we have

$$
\operatorname{Ent}\left(\nu_{m_{1}, \sigma_{1}} \mid \nu_{m_{2}, \sigma_{2}}\right) \leqslant \frac{5}{4}\left\|\sigma_{2}^{-1}\right\|_{F}\left(\left\|\sigma_{2}-\sigma_{1}\right\|_{F}+\left\|m_{1}-m_{2}\right\|^{2}\right)
$$

# D Gaussian Sinkhorn algorithm
## Conjugate formulae

Assume that $\mathcal{P}_{2 n}=P_{\theta_{2 n}}$ (equivalently, $\mathcal{K}_{2 n}=K_{\theta_{2 n}}$ ). In this case, we have $\pi_{2 n}=\eta K_{\theta_{2 n}}=$ $\nu_{m_{2 n}, \sigma_{2 n}}$ with the parameters

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(m_{2 n}, \sigma_{2 n}\right) & =\left(\alpha_{2 n}+\beta_{2 n} m, \beta_{2 n} \sigma \beta_{2 n}^{\prime}+\tau_{2 n}\right) \\
& =\left(a_{m}\left(\theta_{2 n}\right), b_{\sigma}\left(\theta_{2 n}\right)\right) \\
& =h_{m, \sigma}\left(\theta_{2 n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The conjugate formula (2.17) yields

$$
\left(\nu_{h_{m, \sigma}\left(\theta_{2 n}\right)} \times K_{\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}\left(\theta_{2 n}\right)}\right)^{b}=\nu_{m, \sigma} \times K_{\theta_{2 n}}
$$

which implies that

$$
\mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}=K_{\theta_{2 n+1}}, \quad \text { with } \quad \theta_{2 n+1}=\left(\alpha_{2 n+1}, \beta_{2 n+1}, \tau_{2 n+1}\right):=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}\left(\theta_{2 n}\right)
$$

\end{array}\right.
$$

In terms of the random map (2.18) we have

$$

with

$$

This implies that

$$

with the parameters

$$

The conjugate formula (2.17) yields

ans, as a consequence,

$$
