$$

Equivalently, we have

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\alpha_{2(n+1)} & =\bar{m}-\beta_{2(n+1)} m_{2 n+1}=\bar{m}-\beta_{2(n+1)} a_{\bar{m}}\left(\theta_{2 n+1}\right) \\
\beta_{2(n+1)} & =\bar{\sigma} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \sigma_{2 n+1}^{-1}=\bar{\sigma} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} b_{\bar{\sigma}}\left(\theta_{2 n+1}\right)^{-1} \\
\tau_{2(n+1)}^{-1} & :=\bar{\sigma}^{-1}+\beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1} \beta_{2 n+1}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

and, in terms of the random map (2.18),

$$
K_{\theta_{2(n+1)}}(x, d y)=\mathbb{P}\left(Z_{\theta_{2(n+1)}}(x) \in d y\right)
$$

with

$$
Z_{\theta_{2(n+1)}}(x)=\bar{m}+\beta_{2(n+1)}\left(x-m_{2 n+1}\right)+\tau_{2(n+1)}^{1 / 2} G
$$

# Proof of Lemma 4.1 

Applying the matrix inversion lemma to (D.1) we find that

$$
\sigma_{2 n}^{-1}=\left(\beta_{2 n} \sigma \beta_{2 n}^{\prime}+\tau_{2 n}\right)^{-1}=\tau_{2 n}^{-1}-\tau_{2 n}^{-1} \beta_{2 n} \tau_{2 n+1} \beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}^{-1}
$$

and, on the other hand, by (D.2) we have

$$
\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\sigma^{-1}=\beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}^{-1} \beta_{2 n}
$$

which together imply the equalities

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta_{2 n+1}=\sigma \beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \sigma_{2 n}^{-1} & =\sigma \beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}^{-1}-\sigma\left(\beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}^{-1} \beta_{2 n}\right) \tau_{2 n+1} \beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}^{-1} \\
& =\sigma \beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}^{-1}-\sigma\left(\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\sigma^{-1}\right) \tau_{2 n+1} \beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}^{-1}=\tau_{2 n+1} \beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

This yields the commutation formula

$$
\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1} \beta_{2 n+1}=\beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}^{-1}
$$

In the same vein, using (D.4) we see that

$$
\sigma_{2 n+1}^{-1}=\left(\beta_{2 n+1} \bar{\sigma} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime}+\tau_{2 n+1}\right)^{-1}=\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1} \beta_{2 n+1} \tau_{2(n+1)} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}
$$

and, by (D.5),

$$
\tau_{2(n+1)}^{-1}-\bar{\sigma}^{-1}=\beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1} \beta_{2 n+1}
$$

The equations above lead to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta_{2(n+1)}=\bar{\sigma} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \sigma_{2 n+1}^{-1} & =\bar{\sigma} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\bar{\sigma}\left(\beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1} \beta_{2 n+1}\right) \tau_{2(n+1)} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1} \\
& =\bar{\sigma} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\bar{\sigma}\left(\tau_{2(n+1)}^{-1}-\bar{\sigma}^{-1}\right) \tau_{2(n+1)} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1} \\
& =\tau_{2(n+1)} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

which yields the commutation formula

$$
\tau_{2(n+1)}^{-1} \beta_{2(n+1)}=\beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}=\tau_{2 n}^{-1} \beta_{2 n}
$$

We complete the proof of (4.8) by choosing $n=0$ in the r.h.s. of (D.10).

## Sinkhorn Gibbs-loop process

The Gibbs transitions discussed in (4.13) can also be rewritten as

$$
\mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}^{\circ}\left(x_{1}, d x_{2}\right)=\mathbb{P}\left(\mathcal{Z}_{2 n+1}^{\circ}\left(x_{1}\right) \in d x_{2}\right)
$$

with the random maps

$$
\mathcal{Z}_{2 n+1}^{\circ}(x)=m+\beta_{2 n+1}^{\circ}(x-m)+\left(\tau_{2 n+1}^{\circ}\right)^{1 / 2} G
$$

defined in terms of the parameter $\beta_{2 n+1}^{\circ}$ in (4.17) and

$$
\tau_{2 n+1}^{\circ}:=\tau_{2 n+1}+\beta_{2 n+1} \tau_{2 n} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime}
$$

The above assertion is a direct consequence of the linear-Gaussian structure of the random maps discussed in (D.3) and (D.6).

In the same vein, for any $n \geqslant 1$ we have

$$
\mathcal{K}_{2 n}^{\circ}\left(y_{1}, d y_{2}\right):=\mathbb{P}\left(\mathcal{Z}_{2 n}^{\circ}\left(y_{1}\right) \in d y_{2}\right)
$$

with the random maps

$$
\mathcal{Z}_{2 n}^{\circ}(y)=\bar{m}+\beta_{2 n}^{\circ}(y-\bar{m})+\left(\tau_{2 n}^{\circ}\right)^{1 / 2} G
$$

defined in terms of the matrix $\beta_{2 n}^{\circ}$ in (4.16) and

$$
\tau_{2 n}^{\circ}:=\tau_{2 n}+\beta_{2 n} \tau_{2 n-1} \beta_{2 n}^{\prime}
$$

# Proof of (4.19) 

Iterating the random maps (D.12) we readily find that

$$
\pi_{2 n}=\operatorname{Law}\left(\mathcal{X}_{2 n}^{\circ}\right)=\pi_{2(n-1)} \mathcal{K}_{2 n}^{\circ}
$$

with the random variables

$$
\mathcal{X}_{2 n}^{\circ}-\bar{m}=\beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}\left(\mathcal{X}_{0}^{\circ}-\bar{m}\right)+\left(\tau_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}\right)^{1 / 2} G
$$

In the above display, $\beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}$ stands for the directed matrix product defined in (4.18). In addition, using the fixed point equations (4.13) we also see that

$$
\left(\beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}\right) \bar{\sigma}\left(\beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}\right)^{\prime}+\tau_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}=\bar{\sigma}
$$

The l.h.s. assertion in (4.19) is a direct consequence of the above formula. In the same vein, using (4.14), for any $n \geqslant 1$ we arrive at

$$
\pi_{2 n+1}=\operatorname{Law}\left(\mathcal{X}_{2 n+1}^{\circ}\right)=\pi_{2 n-1} \mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}^{\circ}
$$

with the initial condition

$$
\pi_{1}=\operatorname{Law}\left(\mathcal{X}_{1}^{\circ}\right)=\nu_{m_{1}, \sigma_{1}}
$$

Iterating the map (D.11) we obtain

$$
\mathcal{X}_{2 n+1}^{\circ}-m=\beta_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ}\left(\mathcal{X}_{1}^{\circ}-m\right)+\left(\tau_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ}\right)^{1 / 2} G
$$

with the directed matrix product $\beta_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ}$ defined in (4.18). Using the fixed point equations (4.13) we also see that

$$
\beta_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ}:=\beta_{2 n+1}^{\circ} \beta_{2 n-1}^{\circ} \ldots \beta_{3}^{\circ} \quad \text { and } \quad\left(\beta_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ}\right) \sigma\left(\beta_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ}\right)^{\prime}+\tau_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ}=\sigma
$$

The r.h.s. assertion in (4.19) is a direct consequence of the above formula.

# Proof of Lemma 4.9 

Using (D.4) and (4.8) we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta_{2 n-1}^{\prime} \sigma_{2 n-1}^{-1} \beta_{2 n-1} & =\beta_{2 n-1}^{\prime}\left(\beta_{2 n-1} \bar{\sigma} \beta_{2 n-1}^{\prime}+\tau_{2 n-1}\right)^{-1} \beta_{2 n-1} \\
& =\tau^{-1} \beta \tau_{2 n-1}\left(\tau_{2 n-1} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \bar{\sigma} \tau^{-1} \beta \tau_{2 n-1}+\tau_{2 n-1}\right)^{-1} \tau_{2 n-1} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

and, using the l.h.s. description of $\beta_{2 n}$ given in (D.5), this implies that

$$
\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \beta_{2 n}^{\circ} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}=\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \beta_{2 n-1}^{\prime} \sigma_{2 n-1}^{-1} \beta_{2 n-1} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}=\gamma_{\theta}\left(\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \gamma_{\theta}+v_{2 n-1}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}
$$

with the matrices $\gamma_{\theta}$ and $v_{2 n-1}$ defined in (3.1) and (4.9). On the other hand, combining (4.10) with the matrix inversion lemma we also have

$$
v_{2 n}=\left(I+\gamma_{\theta} v_{2 n-1} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\right)^{-1}=I-\gamma_{\theta}\left(v_{2 n-1}^{-1}+\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \gamma_{\theta}\right)^{-1} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}
$$

Recalling that $\bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}=\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \gamma_{\theta}$ and $\bar{\gamma}_{\theta_{1}}=\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}$, this ends the proof of (4.20).
In the same vein, using (D.1) and (4.8) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \sigma_{2 n}^{-1} \beta_{2 n} & =\beta_{2 n}^{\prime}\left(\beta_{2 n} \sigma \beta_{2 n}^{\prime}+\tau_{2 n}\right)^{-1} \beta_{2 n} \\
& =\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \tau_{2 n}\left(\tau_{2 n} \tau^{-1} \beta \sigma \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \tau_{2 n}+\tau_{2 n}\right)^{-1} \tau_{2 n} \tau^{-1} \beta
\end{aligned}
$$

and, using the l.h.s. description of $\beta_{2 n+1}$ given in (D.2), this yields

$$
\sigma^{-1 / 2} \beta_{2 n+1}^{\circ} \sigma^{1 / 2}=\sigma^{1 / 2} \beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \sigma_{2 n}^{-1} \beta_{2 n} \sigma^{1 / 2}=\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\left(\gamma_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}+v_{2 n}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \gamma_{\theta}
$$

with the matrices $\gamma_{\theta}$ and $v_{2 n}$ defined in (3.1) and (4.9). Combining (4.10) with the matrix inversion lemma we also have

$$
v_{2 n+1}=\left(I+\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} v_{2 n} \gamma_{\theta}\right)^{-1}=I-\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\left(v_{2 n}^{-1}+\gamma_{\theta} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} \gamma_{\theta}
$$

This ends the proof of (4.21).

## Proof of (5.3)

Using (4.20) and (4.21) we check that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} & =\left(I-v_{2 n}\right)\left(I-v_{2(n-1)}\right) \ldots\left(I-v_{2}\right) \quad \text { and } \\
\sigma^{-1 / 2} \beta_{2 n+1,1}^{\circ} \sigma^{1 / 2} & =\left(I-v_{2 n+1}\right)\left(I-v_{2 n-1}\right) \ldots\left(I-v_{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The estimate (5.3) is now a direct consequence of the product formula (B.12), Proposition B. 3 and Proposition B.5.

# E Schrödinger potentials
## Proof of Theorem 3.7

Using the decomposition

$$
y-(\alpha+\beta x)=(y-\bar{m})-\left(\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)+\beta(x-m)\right)
$$

we readily check that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(y-(\alpha+\beta x))\right\|_{F}^{2}= & \left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(y-\bar{m})\right\|_{F}^{2}+\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}\left(\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)+\beta(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2} \\
& -2(y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)+\beta(x-m)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Recalling that $\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1} \kappa_{\theta}=\tau^{-1} \beta$ (with $\kappa_{\theta}$ defined in (3.3)), this implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(y-(\alpha+\beta x))\right\|_{F}^{2}-\left(\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(y)-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(\bar{m})\right) \\
& =-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(y-(\alpha+\beta x))\right\|_{F}^{2} \\
& -\left((y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left\|\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1 / 2}(y-\bar{m})\right\|_{F}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(y-\bar{m})\right\|_{F}^{2}\right) \\
& =-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}\left(\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)+\beta(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2} \\
& -\frac{1}{2}\left\|\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1 / 2}(y-\bar{m})\right\|_{F}^{2}+(y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta}^{-1}\left(\kappa_{\theta}(x-m)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and, rewriting in a slightly different form, we have proved that

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(y-(\alpha+\beta x))\right\|_{F}^{2}-\left(\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(y)-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(\bar{m})\right)= & -\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}\left(\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)+\beta(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2} \\
& +\frac{1}{2}\left\|\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1 / 2}\left(\kappa_{\theta}(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2} \\
& -\frac{1}{2}\left\|\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1 / 2}\left((y-\bar{m})-\kappa_{\theta}(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

By (2.22) and (2.23) we have

$$
\tau_{1}^{-1}\left(m_{1}-m\right)=\tau_{1}^{-1} \beta_{1}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)=\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)
$$

and, on the other hand, using (2.21) (3.3) and (3.11) we readily check that

$$
\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta}^{-1} \kappa_{\theta} \quad \text { and } \quad \tau_{1}^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta
$$

which implies

$$
\kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta}^{-1} \kappa_{\theta}-\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta=\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}-\tau_{1}^{-1}
$$

This yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}\left(\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)+\beta(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left\|\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1 / 2}\left(\kappa_{\theta}(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2} \\
& =-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}+(x-m)^{\prime} \tau_{1}^{-1}\left(m_{1}-m\right)+\frac{1}{2}(x-m)^{\prime}\left(\mathbb{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}-\tau_{1}^{-1}\right)(x-m) \\
& =-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}+\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(x)-\left(\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(m)+(U(x)-U(m))\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

from where we find that

$$
\begin{gathered}
-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(y-(\alpha+\beta x))\right\|_{F}^{2}-\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(y)-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(x) \\
=-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}-\left(\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(\bar{m})+\left(\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(m)-U(m)\right)\right) \\
-U(x)-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1 / 2}\left((y-\bar{m})-\kappa_{\theta}(x-m)\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

We end the proof of (3.14) using the fact that

$$
\frac{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}(\tau)}}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}\left(\varsigma_{\theta}\right)}} \exp \left(\mathbb{V}_{\theta}(\bar{m})+\left(\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(m)-U(m)\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)\right\|_{F}^{2}\right)=1
$$

# Proof of Proposition 6.1 

Assume that at some rank $n \geqslant 0$ we have

$$
\mathcal{P}_{2 n}(d(x, y))=e^{-U_{2 n}(x)} q(x, y) e^{-V_{2 n}(y)} d x d y
$$

for some potential functions $\left(U_{2 n}, V_{2 n}\right)$ such that

$$
U_{2 n}=U+\log Q\left(e^{-V_{2 n}}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{K}_{2 n}(x, d y)=Q_{V_{2 n}}(x, d y):=\frac{Q(x, d y) e^{-V_{2 n}(y)}}{Q\left(e^{-V_{2 n}}\right)(x)}
$$

This condition is met at rank $n=0$ with $\left(U_{0}, V_{0}\right)=(U, 0)$. By (4.2) we have

$$
\mathcal{K}_{2 n+1}(y, d x)=R_{U_{2 n+1}}(y, d x):=\frac{R(y, d x) e^{-U_{2 n+1}(x)}}{R\left(e^{-U_{2 n+1}}\right)(y)} \quad \text { with } \quad U_{2 n+1}=U_{2 n}
$$

which yields

$$
\mathcal{P}_{2 n+1}(d(x, y))=e^{-U_{2 n+1}(x)} q(x, y) e^{-V_{2 n+1}(y)} d x d y
$$

with the potential function

$$
V_{2 n+1}=V+\log R\left(e^{-U_{2 n+1}}\right)
$$

In this case, using (4.2) we see that

$$
\mathcal{K}_{2(n+1)}=Q_{V_{2(n+1)}} \quad \text { with } \quad V_{2(n+1)}=V_{2 n+1}
$$

and, as a consequence,

$$
\mathcal{P}_{2(n+1)}(d(x, y))=e^{-U_{2(n+1)}(x)} q(x, y) e^{-V_{2(n+1)}(y)} d x d y
$$

with

$$
U_{2(n+1)}:=U+\log Q\left(e^{-V_{2(n+1)}}\right)
$$

This ends the proof of the proposition.

# Proof of Lemma 6.11 

Following (4.9), consider the rescaled covariance matrices

$$
\xi_{2 n+1}:=\sigma^{-1 / 2} \sigma_{2 n+1} \sigma^{-1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \quad \xi_{2 n}:=\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \sigma_{2 n} \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}
$$

Combining (D.1) with (4.8) we can write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\xi_{2 n} & =\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}\left(\tau_{2 n} \tau^{-1} \beta\right) \sigma\left(\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \tau_{2 n}\right) \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}+v_{2 n} \\
& =\bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \tau_{2 n} \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}\left(\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \tau^{-1} \beta \sigma^{1 / 2}\right)\left(\sigma^{1 / 2} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\right) \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2} \tau_{2 n} \bar{\sigma}^{-1 / 2}+v_{2 n}
\end{aligned}
$$

which yields the formula

$$
\xi_{2 n}=v_{2 n}+v_{2 n} \varpi_{\theta}^{-1} v_{2 n}
$$

with the matrix $\varpi_{\theta}$ defined in (3.1). Using the matrix sum inversion formula

$$
\left(v+v \varpi^{-1} v\right)^{-1}=v^{-1}-(\varpi+v)^{-1}
$$

we readily see that

$$
\xi_{2 n}^{-1}-I=v_{2 n}^{-1}-\left(I+\left(\varpi_{\theta}+v_{2 n}\right)^{-1}\right)=v_{2 n}^{-1}-\left(\operatorname{Ricc}_{\varpi_{\theta}}\left(v_{2 n}\right)\right)^{-1}
$$

This ends the proof of the l.h.s. assertion in (6.13).
In the same vein, combining (D.4) with (4.8) leads to

$$
\xi_{2 n+1}=v_{2 n+1}+v_{2 n+1} \bar{\varpi}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1} v_{2 n+1} \quad \text { and } \quad \xi_{2 n+1}^{-1}-I=v_{2 n+1}^{-1}-v_{2 n+3}^{-1}
$$

which, rewritten in terms of $\sigma_{n}$, yields the r.h.s. of (6.13).
Next, observe that

$$
\xi_{2 n}=v_{2 n}+v_{2 n} \varpi_{\theta}^{-1} v_{2 n}
$$

Combining (3.1) and (4.10) with the l.h.s. formula in (E.3) we also have the factorisation

$$
\gamma_{\theta} \xi_{2 n+1} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}=\gamma_{\theta} v_{2 n+1} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\left(I+\gamma_{\theta} v_{2 n+1} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\right)=\left(\gamma_{\theta} v_{2 n+1} \gamma_{\theta}^{\prime}\right) v_{2(n+1)}^{-1}
$$

The l.h.s. assertion in (6.14) now follows elementary arguments. The proof of the r.h.s. assertion in (6.14) follows exactly from the same argument.

Finaly, using (4.8) we obtain

$$
\left(\tau_{2 n}^{-1} \beta_{2 n}\right) \tau_{2 n+1}\left(\beta_{2 n}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}^{-1}\right)=\tau^{-1} \beta\left(\tau_{2 n+1} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\right)=\tau^{-1} \beta \beta_{2 n+1}
$$

and combining the equation above with (D.7) we arrive at

$$
\sigma_{2 n}^{-1}=\left(\beta_{2 n} \sigma \beta_{2 n}^{\prime}+\tau_{2 n}\right)^{-1}=\tau_{2 n}^{-1}-\tau^{-1} \beta \beta_{2 n+1}
$$

Then, using (4.8), we conclude that

$$
\sigma_{2 n}^{-1} \beta_{2 n}=\tau^{-1} \beta\left(I-\beta_{2 n+1} \beta_{2 n}\right)
$$

In the same vein, from (4.8) we have

$$
\left(\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1} \beta_{2 n+1}\right) \tau_{2(n+1)}\left(\beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}\right)=\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(\tau_{2(n+1)} \tau^{-1} \beta\right)=\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta_{2(n+1)}
$$

and combining the above with (D.9) we find that

$$
\sigma_{2 n+1}^{-1}=\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta_{2(n+1)}
$$

Using (4.8), we conclude that

$$
\sigma_{2 n+1}^{-1} \beta_{2 n+1}=\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(I-\beta_{2(n+1)} \beta_{2 n+1}\right)
$$

This ends the proof of (6.15).

# Proof of Proposition 6.12 

Using (D.5) and (6.13) we check that

$$
\sigma_{2 n}^{-1}=\tau_{2 n}^{-1}-\left(\tau_{2(n+1)}^{-1}-\bar{\sigma}^{-1}\right)=\tau_{2 n}^{-1}-\beta_{2 n+1}^{\prime} \tau_{2 n+1}^{-1} \beta_{2 n+1}
$$

and combining the above with (4.7) we arrive at
$\left(m_{2 p}-\bar{m}\right)^{\prime} \sigma_{2 p}^{-1}\left(m_{2 p}-\bar{m}\right)=\left(m_{2 p}-\bar{m}\right)^{\prime} \tau_{2 p}^{-1}\left(m_{2 p}-\bar{m}\right)-\left(m_{2 p+1}-m\right)^{\prime} \tau_{2 p+1}^{-1}\left(m_{2 p+1}-m\right)$.
In the same vein, using (D.2) and (6.13) we obtain

$$
\sigma_{2 n+1}^{-1}=\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\left(\tau_{2 n+3}^{-1}-\sigma^{-1}\right)=\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\beta_{2(n+1)}^{\prime} \tau_{2(n+1)}^{-1} \beta_{2(n+1)}
$$

and, therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(m_{2 p+1}-m\right)^{\prime} \sigma_{2 p+1}^{-1}\left(m_{2 p+1}-m\right)= & \left(m_{2 p+1}-m\right)^{\prime} \tau_{2 p+1}^{-1}\left(m_{2 p+1}-m\right) \\
& -\left(m_{2(p+1)}-\bar{m}\right)^{\prime} \tau_{2(p+1)}^{-1}\left(m_{2(p+1)}-\bar{m}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
2\left(V_{2 n}(\bar{m})+U_{2 n}(m)-U(m)\right)= & \log \operatorname{det}\left(v_{2 n} v_{0}^{-1}\right)+\left(m_{2 n}-\bar{m}\right)^{\prime} \tau_{2 n}^{-1}\left(m_{2 n}-\bar{m}\right) \\
& -\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)^{\prime} \tau_{0}^{-1}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and concludes the proof.

# Proof of Theorem 6.13 

Combining the decomposition

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(y-m_{2 p}\right)^{\prime} \sigma_{2 p}^{-1}\left(y-m_{2 p}\right)-\left(\bar{m}-m_{2 p}\right)^{\prime} \sigma_{2 p}^{-1}\left(\bar{m}-m_{2 p}\right) \\

$$

with (6.13) we obtain

$$
V_{2(n+1)}(y)-V_{2(n+1)}(\bar{m})=\sum_{0 \leqslant p \leqslant n}(y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \sigma_{2 p}^{-1}\left(m_{2 p}-\bar{m}\right)+\frac{1}{2}(y-\bar{m})^{\prime}\left(\tau_{2(n+1)}^{-1}-\tau_{0}^{-1}\right)(y-\bar{m})
$$

On the other hand, using (4.16) and (E.4) for find that

$$
\sigma_{2 p}^{-1}\left(m_{2 p}-\bar{m}\right)=\sigma_{2 p}^{-1} \beta_{2 p, 0}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{0}^{-1}=\tau_{0}^{-1}-\tau^{-1} \beta \beta_{1}
$$

for any $p \geqslant 1$, with the directed matrix product

$$
\beta_{q, 0}:=\beta_{q} \beta_{q-1} \ldots \beta_{1}
$$

Now, using (6.15) we readily check that

$$
\sigma_{2 p}^{-1} \beta_{2 p, 0}=\tau^{-1} \beta\left(\beta_{2 p-1,0}-\beta_{2 p+1,0}\right)
$$

and this yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
V_{2(n+1)}(y)-V_{2(n+1)}(\bar{m})= & (y-\bar{m})^{\prime}\left(\tau_{0}^{-1}-\tau^{-1} \beta \beta_{1}\right)\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right) \\
& +\frac{1}{2}(y-\bar{m})^{\prime}\left(\tau_{2(n+1)}^{-1}-\tau_{0}^{-1}\right)(y-\bar{m}) \\
& +(y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta\left(\beta_{2 n+1,0}-\beta_{1,0}\right)\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We conclude that

$$
\begin{aligned}
V_{2(n+1)}(y)-V_{2(n+1)}(\bar{m})= & (y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \tau_{0}^{-1}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right) \\
& +\frac{1}{2}(y-\bar{m})^{\prime}\left(\tau_{2(n+1)}^{-1}-\tau_{0}^{-1}\right)(y-\bar{m}) \\
& +(y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta \beta_{2 n+1,0}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which completes the proof of the first assertion.
In the same vein, combining the decomposition

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(x-m_{2 p+1}\right)^{\prime} \sigma_{2 p+1}^{-1}\left(x-m_{2 p+1}\right)-\left(m-m_{2 p+1}\right)^{\prime} \sigma_{2 p+1}^{-1}\left(m-m_{2 p+1}\right) \\
& =2(x-m)^{\prime} \sigma_{2 p+1}^{-1}\left(m-m_{2 p+1}\right)+(x-m)^{\prime} \sigma_{2 p+1}^{-1}(x-m)
\end{aligned}
$$

with (6.13) we arrive at

$$
\begin{aligned}
U_{2 n}(x)-U_{2 n}(m)= & (U(x)-U(m)) \sum_{0 \leqslant p<n}(x-m)^{\prime} \sigma_{2 p+1}^{-1}\left(m_{2 p+1}-m\right) \\
& +\frac{1}{2}(x-m)^{\prime}\left(\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\tau_{1}^{-1}\right)(x-m)
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand, using (4.17) and (E.5), for any $p \geqslant 0$ we check that

$$
\sigma_{2 p+1}^{-1}\left(m_{2 p+1}-m\right)=\sigma_{2 p+1}^{-1} \beta_{2 p+1,1}\left(m_{1}-m\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{1}^{-1}=\tau_{1}^{-1}-\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta_{2}
$$

with the directed matrix product

$$
\beta_{q, 1}:=\beta_{q} \beta_{q-1} \ldots \beta_{2}
$$

Equivalently, in terms of the directed products (4.18) we have

$$
\beta_{2 n, 1}=\beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ} \quad \text { and } \quad \beta_{2 n-1,0}=\beta_{2 n-1,1}^{\circ}
$$

Using (6.15) we can write

$$
\sigma_{2 p+1}^{-1} \beta_{2 p+1,1}=\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(\beta_{2 p, 1}-\beta_{2(p+1), 1}\right)
$$

which implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& U_{2 n}(x)-U_{2 n}(m) \\
& =(U(x)-U(m))+(x-m)^{\prime}\left(\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta_{2}-\tau_{1}^{-1}\right)\left(m-m_{1}\right) \\
& +\left(x-m)^{\prime}\left(\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}\left(\beta_{2 n, 1}-\beta_{2,1}\right)\right)\left(m-m_{1}\right)+\frac{1}{2}(x-m)^{\prime}\left(\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\tau_{1}^{-1}\right)(x-m)\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, we conclude that

$$
\begin{aligned}
U_{2 n}(x)-U_{2 n}(m)= & (U(x)-U(m))+(x-m)^{\prime} \tau_{1}^{-1}\left(m_{1}-m\right) \\
& +\frac{1}{2}(x-m)^{\prime}\left(\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\tau_{1}^{-1}\right)(x-m) \\
& +(x-m)^{\prime} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta_{2 n, 1}\left(m-m_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

# Proof of Corollary 6.14 

The proof if based on the following technical lemma.
Lemma E.1. There exists some constant $c_{\theta}$ and some parameter $n_{\theta}$ such that for every $n \geqslant n_{\theta}$ we have

$$
\left|\epsilon_{2 n}^{V}(\bar{m})\right| \leqslant c_{\theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n} \quad \text { and } \quad\left|\epsilon_{2 n}^{U}(m)\right| \leqslant c_{\theta} \bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n}
$$

Proof. Using Corollary 4.5 and Corollary 5.4 we can find some finite constant $c_{1, \theta}$ such that

$$
\left\|\sigma_{2 n}^{-1 / 2}\left(m_{2 n}-\bar{m}\right)\right\| \leqslant c_{1, \theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n / 2} \quad \text { for every } n \geqslant 0
$$

Next, we choose $n_{0}$ such that

$$
\left\|\sigma_{2 n_{0}}-\bar{\sigma}\right\| \leqslant c_{\theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n_{0}}\left\|\sigma_{0}-\bar{\sigma}\right\| \leqslant \frac{1}{2\left\|\bar{\sigma}^{-1}\right\|_{F}}
$$

with the constant $c_{\theta}$ as in Corollary 5.4. Then, by (6.14) and Lemma C. 1 there exists some $c_{2, \theta}$ such that for any $n \geqslant n_{0}$ we have

$$
\left|\log \operatorname{det}\left(v_{2 n+1} v_{2 n}^{-1}\right)\right| \leqslant c_{2, \theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n} \quad \text { and, therefore, } \quad\left|\epsilon_{2 n}^{V}(\bar{m})\right| \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \frac{c_{1, \theta}+c_{2, \theta}}{1-\rho_{\theta}} \rho_{\theta}^{n}
$$

This completes the proof of the first assertion. The proof of the second estimate follows exactly the same argument.

Now we come to the proof of Corollary 6.14 .
Proof. The estimates stated in Corollary 4.5 as well as in (5.3) and Theorem 5.1 imply that

$$
\left\|\beta_{2 n, 0}^{\circ}\right\| \leqslant c_{0, \theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n / 2} \quad \text { and } \quad\left\|\beta_{2 n-1,1}^{\circ}\right\| \leqslant c_{1, \theta} \bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n / 2}
$$

as well as

$$
\left\|\tau_{2 n}^{-1}-\varsigma_{\theta}^{-1}\right\| \leqslant c_{0, \theta} \rho_{\theta}^{n} \quad \text { and } \quad\left\|\tau_{2 n+1}^{-1}-\widetilde{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}\right\| \leqslant c_{1, \theta} \bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n}
$$

for some constants $c_{0, \theta}$ and $c_{1, \theta}$. Using Theorem 6.13 we also check that

$$
\left|\epsilon_{2 n}^{V}(y)\right| \leqslant c_{\theta}\left(\rho_{\theta}^{n}+\bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n / 2}\|y-\bar{m}\|+\rho_{\theta}^{n}\|y-\bar{m}\|^{2}\right)
$$

and

$$
\left|\epsilon_{2 n}^{U}(x)\right| \leqslant c_{\theta}\left(\bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n}+\rho_{\theta}^{n / 2}\|x-m\|+\bar{\rho}_{\theta_{1}}^{n}\|x-m\|^{2}\right)
$$

# Proof of Corollary 6.16 

The optimal bridge $\mathbb{S}(\theta)$ yields

$$
P_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}(d(x, y))=\nu_{m, \sigma}(d x) K_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}(x, d y)=e^{-\mathbb{U}_{\theta}(x)} q_{\theta}(x, y) e^{-\nabla_{\theta}(y)} d x d y
$$

and

$$
Q_{\theta}(x, d y):=q_{\theta}(x, y) d y \Longrightarrow K_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}(x, d y)=\frac{Q_{\theta}(x, d y) e^{-\nabla_{\theta}(y)}}{Q_{\theta}\left(e^{-\nabla_{\theta}}\right)(x)}
$$

On the other hand, by (3.6) we have $\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}\left(\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{0}\right)\right)=\overline{\mathbb{S}}\left(\theta_{1}\right)$ with $\theta_{1}=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}\left(\theta_{0}\right)$. Recalling that $\nu_{m, \sigma} K_{\mathbb{S}(\theta)}=\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}$, the conjugate formula (2.17) implies that

$$
P_{\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{0}\right)}=\bar{P}_{\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{1}\right)}^{\mathfrak{b}}
$$

Equivalently, we have

$$
\bar{P}_{\overline{\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{1}\right)}}(d(x, y))=\nu_{\bar{m}, \bar{\sigma}}(d x) K_{\overline{\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{1}\right)}}(x, d y)=e^{-\nabla_{\theta_{0}}(x)} r_{\theta_{0}}(x, y) e^{-\mathbb{U}_{\theta_{0}}(y)} d x d y
$$

and

$$
K_{\overline{\mathbb{S}\left(\theta_{1}\right)}}(x, d y)=\frac{R_{\theta_{0}}(x, d y) e^{-\mathbb{U}_{\theta_{0}}(y)}}{R_{\theta_{0}}\left(e^{-\mathbb{U}_{\theta_{0}}}\right)(x)}
$$

This completes the proof of the corollary.

## Proof of Theorem 3.3

By Theorem 3.1 we have

$$
\overline{\mathbb{S}}\left(\theta_{1}\right):=\left(\bar{\iota}_{\theta_{1}}, \bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}, \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}\right)
$$

with the parameters $\left(\bar{\iota}_{\theta_{1}}, \bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}, \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}\right)$ defined in (3.7). By (2.23) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\theta_{1}:=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta) \quad \text { and } \quad \theta=(\alpha, \beta, \tau) & \Longrightarrow \chi_{\theta_{1}}=\tau_{1}^{-1} \beta_{1}=\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}=\chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \\
& \Longrightarrow \bar{\gamma}_{\theta_{1}}=\gamma_{\theta}^{\prime} \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}:=\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

We recall from (5.2) (see also Appendix B on page 50) that

$$
\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta} \chi_{\theta}=\sigma^{-1}+\kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta}^{-1} \kappa_{\theta}
$$

with the matrices $\left(\kappa_{\theta}, \varsigma_{\theta}\right)$ defined in (3.3). In the reverse direction, consider the initial parameter associated with the bridge parameters (3.3), that is

$$
\theta_{0}=\left(\alpha_{0}, \beta_{0}, \tau_{0}\right)=\left(\iota_{\theta}, \kappa_{\theta}, \varsigma_{\theta}\right) \Longrightarrow m_{0}=\bar{m} \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{0}=\bar{\sigma} \quad \text { by }(3.4)
$$

In this situation, applying the Bayes' map (2.16) we have

$$
\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}\left(\theta_{0}\right)=\theta_{1}=\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \tau_{1}\right)
$$

with the parameters $\left(\alpha_{1}, \beta_{1}, \tau_{1}\right)$ defined below. Using (2.23) and recalling that $\sigma_{0}=\bar{\sigma}$ we also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tau_{1}^{-1} \beta_{1} & =\beta_{0}^{\prime} \tau_{0}^{-1}=\kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta}^{-1} \\
\beta_{1} & =\sigma \kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \bar{\sigma}^{-1}=\sigma \chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta} \bar{\sigma}^{-1}=\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}} \chi_{\theta}^{\prime}=\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}=\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The last assertion comes from the fact that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1} \beta_{1} & =\left(\sigma^{-1}+\chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta} \chi_{\theta}\right) \sigma \chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta} \bar{\sigma}^{-1} \\
& =\chi_{\theta}^{\prime}\left(\varsigma_{\theta}+\varsigma_{\theta}\left(\chi_{\theta} \sigma \chi_{\theta}^{\prime}\right) \varsigma_{\theta}\right) \bar{\sigma}^{-1}=\chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \quad \text { by }(3.4)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using (2.21), finally note that

$$
\tau_{1}^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\kappa_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta}^{-1} \kappa_{\theta}=\sigma^{-1}+\chi_{\theta}^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta} \chi_{\theta}=\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}^{-1} \quad \text { and } \quad \alpha_{1}=\bar{\imath}_{\theta_{1}}:=m-\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}} \bar{m}
$$

We conclude that

$$
\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\mathbb{S}(\theta))=\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}\left(\iota_{\theta}, \kappa_{\theta}, \varsigma_{\theta}\right)=\left(\bar{\imath}_{\theta_{1}}, \bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}}, \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}}\right)=\overline{\mathbb{S}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{m, \sigma}(\theta)\right)
$$

This ends the proof of the theorem.

# Proof of Corollary 3.10 

Using (3.18) we have

$$
r_{\theta(t)}-I=\left(\varpi_{\theta(t)}+\left(\frac{\varpi_{\theta(t)}}{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}-\left(I+\frac{\varpi_{\theta(t)}}{2}\right)
$$

and, on the other hand,

$$
\varpi_{\theta(t)}+\left(\frac{\varpi_{\theta(t)}}{2}\right)^{2}-\left(I+\frac{\varpi_{\theta(t)}}{2}\right)^{2}=-I
$$

as well as

$$
\varpi_{\theta(t)}+\left(\frac{\varpi_{\theta(t)}}{2}\right)^{2} \geqslant \frac{\varpi_{\theta(t)}}{2} \geqslant \frac{t^{2}}{2} \varpi_{I}
$$

Now, using the Ando-Hemmen inequality we find that

$$
\left\|r_{\theta(t)}-I\right\|_{2} \leqslant \frac{1}{t} \frac{\sqrt{2}}{\lambda_{\min }^{1 / 2}(\omega)} \Longrightarrow\left\|\varsigma_{\theta(t)}-\bar{\sigma}\right\|_{2}=\left\|\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\left(r_{\theta(t)}-I\right) \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\right\|_{2} \leqslant \frac{1}{t} \frac{\sqrt{2}\|\bar{\sigma}\|_{2}}{\lambda_{\min }^{1 / 2}(\omega)}
$$

Finally, note that

$$
\bar{m}-\iota_{\theta(t)}=\kappa_{\theta(t)} m \quad \text { and } \quad \kappa_{\theta(t)}=t^{-1} \varsigma_{\theta(t)} \beta
$$

which implies the estimate

$$
\left\|\iota_{\theta(t)}-\bar{m}\right\| \vee\left\|r_{\theta(t)}-I\right\| \vee\left\|\varsigma_{\theta(t)}-\bar{\sigma}\right\| \vee\left\|\kappa_{\theta(t)}\right\| \leqslant c / t
$$

This ends the proof of (3.20).
Using (3.13) we check that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\imath}_{\theta_{1}(t)} & =m-\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}(t)} \bar{m} \\
\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}(t)} & =\sigma \kappa_{\theta(t)}^{\prime} \bar{\sigma}^{-1} \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}(t)}^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\frac{1}{t^{2}} \beta^{\prime} \varsigma_{\theta(t)} \beta
\end{aligned}
$$

Recalling that the Sinkhorn iteration is initialized at $\theta_{0}(t)=\theta(t)=(\alpha, \beta, t I)$ we see that

$$
\tau_{1}(t)^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\frac{1}{t} \beta^{\prime} \beta \Longrightarrow\left\|\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}(t)}\right\| \vee\left\|\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}(t)}^{-1}-\tau_{1}(t)^{-1}\right\| \leqslant c / t
$$

In addition, using the decomposition

$$
\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}(t)}-\tau_{1}(t)=\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}(t)}\left(\tau_{1}(t)^{-1}-\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}(t)}^{-1}\right) \tau_{1}(t)
$$

and recalling that

$$
\tau_{1}(t) \leqslant \sigma \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}(t)} \leqslant \sigma
$$

we arrive at

$$
\left\|\bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}(t)}-\tau_{1}(t)\right\| \leqslant c / t
$$

Using (4.7) and (4.8) we also obtain

$$
m_{1}(t)-m=\frac{1}{t} \tau_{1}(t) \beta^{\prime}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right) \Longrightarrow\left\|m_{1}(t)-m\right\| \leqslant c / t
$$

as well as

$$
m-\bar{\imath}_{\theta_{1}(t)}=\bar{\kappa}_{\theta_{1}(t)} \bar{m} \Longrightarrow\left\|\bar{\iota}_{\theta_{1}(t)}-m\right\| \leqslant c / t
$$

We complete the proof of (3.21) arguing as in the proof of (3.20).

# Proof of Proposition 3.11 

Rewriting (3.11) in a sightly different form, we obtain

$$
\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \varsigma_{\theta(t)}^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}-I=\frac{1}{t^{2}} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \beta \sigma^{1 / 2} \bar{r}_{\theta_{1}(t)} \sigma^{1 / 2} \beta^{\prime} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}
$$

and using (3.21) we see that

$$
\left\|I-\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \varsigma_{\theta(t)}^{-1} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}\right\| \leqslant c_{0} / t^{2}
$$

By (2.6) there is also some $t_{0}$ such that for any $t \geqslant t_{0}$ we have

$$
\left|\log \operatorname{det}\left(\varsigma_{\theta(t)}^{-1} \bar{\sigma}\right)\right| \leqslant c_{0} / t^{2}
$$

This ends the proof of the first assertion.
On the other hand, from (2.21) and (3.11) we also have

$$
\tau_{1}(t)^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\frac{1}{t} \beta^{\prime} \beta \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{\varsigma}_{\theta_{1}(t)}^{-1}=\sigma^{-1}+\frac{1}{t} \beta^{\prime} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \frac{r_{\theta(t)}}{t} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \beta
$$

In this context, formula (3.16) takes the form
$\mathbb{U}_{\theta(t)}(x+m)-\mathbb{U}_{\theta(t)}(m)-2^{-1} x^{\prime} \sigma^{-1} x=\frac{1}{t}(\beta x)^{\prime}\left(\bar{m}-m_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2 t}(\beta x)^{\prime}\left(\bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2} \frac{r_{\theta(t)}}{t} \bar{\sigma}^{1 / 2}-I\right)(\beta x)$.
The second assertion is now a direct consequence of (3.20). Finally, using (3.10) we have

$$
\varsigma_{\theta(t)}^{-1}=\bar{\sigma}^{-1}+\frac{1}{t} \beta \sigma^{1 / 2} \frac{\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}(t)}}{t} \sigma^{1 / 2} \beta^{\prime}
$$

Therefore, by Theorem 3.7 we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{V}_{\theta(t)}(y+\bar{m})-\mathbb{V}_{\theta(t)}(\bar{m})-2^{-1} y^{\prime} \bar{\sigma}^{-1} y= & \frac{1}{t} y^{\prime}\left(m_{0}-\bar{m}\right) \\
& +\frac{1}{2 t} y^{\prime}\left(\left(\beta \sigma^{1 / 2} \frac{\bar{r}_{\theta_{1}(t)}}{t} \sigma^{1 / 2} \beta^{\prime}-I\right)\right) y
\end{aligned}
$$

The last assertion is now a direct consequence of (3.21).

# Proof of (6.2) and (6.3) 

We readily check (6.2) using the decomposition

$$
c(x, y)=\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}[(y-(\alpha+\beta m))-\beta(x-m)]\right\|_{F}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \log \operatorname{det}(2 \pi \tau)
$$

In the same vein, we check (6.3) using the decomposition

$$
c(x, y)=\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}[(y-\bar{m})+(\bar{m}-(\alpha+\beta x))]\right\|_{F}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \log \operatorname{det}(2 \pi \tau)
$$

## Proof of (6.6) and (6.7)

Returning to the Example 6.4 and using (6.2) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
c_{\eta}(y)-c(x, y)= & \frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2} \beta(x-m)\right\|_{F}^{2}+(x-m)^{\prime} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}(y-(\alpha+\beta m))+\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta \sigma\right) \\
= & -\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2} \beta(x-m)\right\|_{F}^{2}+(x-m)^{\prime} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}(\bar{m}-(\alpha+\beta m))+\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta \sigma\right) \\
& +(x-m)^{\prime} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}(y-\bar{m})
\end{aligned}
$$

which yields the formula

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log \int \mu(d y) e^{c_{\eta}(y)-c(x, y)}= & -\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2} \beta(x-m)\right\|_{F}^{2}+(x-m)^{\prime} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}(\bar{m}-(\alpha+\beta m)) \\
& +\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta \sigma\right)+\frac{1}{2}(x-m)^{\prime} \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \bar{\sigma} \tau^{-1} \beta(x-m)
\end{aligned}
$$

This completes the proof of (6.6).
Using (6.3) we also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
c^{\mu}(x)-c(x, y)= & \frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(\bar{m}-(\alpha+\beta x))\right\|_{F}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}[(y-\bar{m})+(\bar{m}-(\alpha+\beta x))]\right\|_{F}^{2} \\
& +\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\tau^{-1} \bar{\sigma}\right) \\
= & -\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(y-\bar{m})\right\|_{F}^{2}-(y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \tau^{-1}(\bar{m}-(\alpha+\beta m))+\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\tau^{-1} \bar{\sigma}\right) \\
& +(y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta(x-m)
\end{aligned}
$$

that yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log \int \eta(d x) e^{c^{\mu}(x)-c(x, y)}= & -\frac{1}{2}\left\|\tau^{-1 / 2}(y-\bar{m})\right\|_{F}^{2}-(y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \tau^{-1}(\bar{m}-(\alpha+\beta m)) \\
& +\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}\left(\tau^{-1} \bar{\sigma}\right)+\frac{1}{2}(y-\bar{m})^{\prime} \tau^{-1} \beta \sigma \beta^{\prime} \tau^{-1}(y-\bar{m})
\end{aligned}
$$

This completes the proof of (6.7).

abstract:
Entropic optimal transport problems are regularized versions of optimal
transport problems. These models play an increasingly important role in machine
learning and generative modelling. For finite spaces, these problems are
commonly solved using Sinkhorn algorithm (a.k.a. iterative proportional fitting
procedure). However, in more general settings the Sinkhorn iterations are based
on nonlinear conditional/conjugate transformations and exact finite-dimensional
solutions cannot be computed.
  This article presents a finite-dimensional recursive formulation of the
iterative proportional fitting procedure for general Gaussian multivariate
models. As expected, this recursive formulation is closely related to the
celebrated Kalman filter and related Riccati matrix difference equations, and
it yields algorithms that can be implemented in practical settings without
further approximations. We extend this filtering methodology to develop a
refined and self-contained convergence analysis of Gaussian Sinkhorn
algorithms, including closed form expressions of entropic transport maps and
Schr\"odinger bridges.
